column2: State Senator John D. Calandra, the Bronx Republican leader and the chairman of the Senate Elections Committee, vowed yesterday to bottle up in his committee any June-primary bill that would retain the runoff primary provision for New York City's mayoral election.

As if they were tumbling off a ride at an amusement park, four jockeys spilled to the ground in the final race at Aqueduct yesterday and inadvertently set up a $52,459 triple payoff. The return was the Big A's largest on a $2 bet.

TRENTON, Feb. 7 State Senator James H. Wallwork, Republican of Short Hills, demanded today that Governor Byrne pay the state for any expenses incurred by the Governor's 21-year-old daughter, Susan, in the use of a state car.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7 A man found dead in a Montreal street after being run over by a car driven by Premier Rene Levesque may have been killed by another impact, according to a coroner's report issued tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Bargainhunting shoppers in December spurred consumer credit to its largest increase in three and a half years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Ballantine Books Inc. paid over $1 million during a telephone auction yesterday to obtain the rights to publish the paperback edition of William Safire's novel "Full Disclosure," according to Morton L. Janklow, Mr. Safire's lawyer and literary agent. Mr. Janklow said he believed the price was the largest single advance ever paid for a first novel.

The American Composers Alliance celebrated its 40th anniversary last night in Alice Tully Hall. There were speakers, Aaron Copland among them. There were narrators, and a good orchestra. There was a world premiere, two New York premieres and a work commemorating the early years of the A.C.A.

Alice Good Smith, a well-known horsewoman and widow of Gerald S. Smith, investment banker who was a leading polo player in the 1920's and 1930's, died yesterday on a visit to Aiken, S.C. She was about 73 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (AP) Walter J. Dilbeck, one-time business associate of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, was sentenced today to 60 days in jail and 10 months' probation for filing a false Federal tax return.

The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday approved the contract granting a full range of disputed wage increases to 55,000 New York City teachers and other school employees although the contract would have to be renegotiated if some of the increases are eventually determined to be illegal.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 7 Salvage crews struggled today to keep more heavy industrial heating oil from spilling out of a barge that struck a submerged rock ledge just north of here and has spewed a 30-mile-long trail of oil up and down the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 President Carter nominated today Adm. Stansfield Turner, who has made a reputation as a military analyst, to be Director of Central Intelligence.

PRIME RHYME In one of his rare public readings, Robert Penn Warren will render his poetry tonight at 7:30 o'clock at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 89th Street. Tickets, at $1.50, are available at the door after 7 o'clock. Stanley Kunitz will introduce the program, which is sponsored by the Academy of American Poets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission asked Congress today for legislation that would authorize it to rule on the takeovers of major railroads.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Kansas City Kings' general manager, Joe Axelson, said today he had requested an investigation by the National Basketball Association into a fight that broke out during yesterday's game between the Kings and Detroit Pistons.
A bookmaker was accused yesterday of killing an ABC-TV film editor in 1975 because the editor wanted to quit betting while he was ahead.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that the four Bell System subsidiaries seeking to refinance $630 million of high-coupon bonds were successful in purchasing $490 million of the securities. A.T. described the savings in interest expense as "substantial."

The revised financial plan of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation was, in effect, rejected yesterday by the State Emergency Financial Control Board on the ground that it was balanced by what the board's executive director described as "false hopes and wish money."
A steadfast commitment to growth stocks in a five-year period of declines for such issues has blemished the oncesparkling record of the T. Rowe Price mutual funds.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 (AP) The pilot of a light plane that crashed into Memorial Stadium was found guilty today of three of the four charges against him.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters) Ivor Richard, the British delegate to the United Nations and chairman of the stalled Geneva conference on Rhodesia, met with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7 Gerald R. Ford returned today to the college campus where he coached football and studied law four decades ago, and he took the occasion to express regret for one of his more controversial acts while President.
C. Russel Deyo, vice president of public relations for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long-lines department, died Saturday at his home in Basking Ridge, N.J. He was 58 years old.

Wendell Spence, a senior engineer at the Nitron division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, has become an issue. He has been named in a suit filed in Superior Court in California by the NCR Corporation, Dayton, Ohio, where he previously worked. The suit seeks to enjoin him, as well as McDonnell Douglas, from using what NCR termed "valuable proprietary trade secrets," to which Dr. Spence allegedly had access.

OSSINING, N.Y. "An Army captain came around and gave my mother a check for $10,000, an American flag and a military marker for my father's grave," Bettye Conyers Hardeman said. "Big deal. There was no letter of apologies. That was in exchange, of course, for a man's whole life."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 7 (AP) The National Football League club owners have agreed to supplement the income of players who retired before 1959 and are age 65 or older, Bill Dudley announced today. The supplementary payment, Dudley said, is intended to provide the player with a total income of $10,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI) Richard B. Austin, senior judge of the Federal District Court here, died today at Ingalls Hospital in Harvey, Ill. He was 76 years old. Judge Austin had been ill for many weeks and had worked on a reduced caseload in recent months.
DINAN, France, Feb. 7 (UPI) Police today dispersed a noisy leftist demonstration marking the start of a two-day visit to Brittany by President Val ry Giscard d'Estaing.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the Grumman Corporation, both suppliers of military aircraft to the United States Government, reported lower earnings for the fourth quarter.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 7 A major nineyear-old archeological excavation on the periphery of the ancient wall of Jerusalem's Old City near the historic Temple Mount is coming to a close after yielding tightly compacted layers of civilization touching, on ancient Jews, Romans, Byzantine Christians, Moslem Arabs, Crusaders and Turks.

Elliott Carter, who returned to the Composers' Showcase series at the Whitney Museum Sunday night, referred in his introductory remarks to a turning point in his music in the late 1940s from a more "accessible" style to one that was "inwardly concerned." Inward it may be, and even elitist. But you couldn't have discerned that from Sunday's crowd, which overflowed the hall and spilled into standing room at the sides.

One of the most splendid displays of water bird decoys in the United States will be the gathering point for a two-day decoy collectors meeting at The Museums at Stony Brook, L.I., this Saturday and Sunday.

Two rebel unionists, expelled from a Florida teamsters' local on charges arising out of their circulation of insurgent literature, have been reinstated on instructions from the parent International Brotherhood of Teamsters:
DENVER, Feb. 4 "Rain here is not a casual atmospheric condition; it is a gift of the Gods," wrote Frank Waters, the New Mexican author.

As New York City prepares for the first full-fledged independent audit of its finances the largest municipal audit ever attempted a politically sensitive dispute is taking shape over who should carry out the path-breaking endeavor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today an application by the Southern Pacific Railroad to buy more than 900 miles of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

John Cornell Jr. of Newsday and Mel Finkelstein of The Daily News shared top honors as the New York Press Photographers Association announced the winners yesterday of its 41st annual contest for the best news photographs of 1976.
Joseph Kallinger accused his defense lawyer and Bergen County of denying him a fair trial in the proceedings that led to his conviction of murdering a nurse, court papers disclosed yesterday.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7 Seven white Roman Catholic missionaries were shot to death by black guerrillas last night at a mission station 37 miles northeast of here. The dead were two priests, a lay brother and four nuns.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 7 The Nassau County Board of Supervisors voted today to grant a 6.5 percent salary increase for 800 managerial employees, but refused to provide larger increases for 89 top-echelon officials.

In hopes of converting a 3-degree shift into a 10 percent fuel consumption reduction, the Board of Education has ordered the lowering of thermostats in all New York City schools to 65 degrees, effective Wednesday.

WALNUT CREEK, Calif. Writing courses have become so popular at Los Lomas High School in this bedroom community on the edge of San Francisco's surburan sprawl that students now have to be screened to get into the oversubscribed classes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Environmental Protection Agency announced today plans for a "national strategy" to crack down on the discharge of harmful industrial wastes into municipal sewer systems.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission gave final approval today to a decision ending the direct advertising of "Spider-Man" vitamins to children.
Why is Shelley's "The Cenci" so rarely performed? The program notes for the Jean Cocteau Repertory's admirable production cite Victorian prudery.

MADRID, Feb. 7 The Spanish Government is about to establish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union for the first time since the Spanish Civil War of the 1930's, a high government source said today. An announcement is expected after Cabinet approval.

Niall O'Shaughnessy of Ireland, who has run the season's fastest indoor mile and 1,000-yard race, will face John Walker of New Zealand the Olympic champion, in the 1,500-meter run at the United States Olympic invitation track meet Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 7 (Reuters) Thailand has sent reinforcements to its Mekong River border after a gun battle with Laotian soldiers, the Thai radio reported today.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 (AP) The Government tonight freed a Socialist leader, Raj Narain, who took Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to court for electoral fraud after she defeated him in the 1971 parliamentary elections.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7 Seven white Roman Catholic missionaries were shot to death by black guerrillas last night at a mission station 37 miles northeast of here. The dead were two priests, a lay brother and four nuns.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Big 10 has arranged tentatively for a playoff game March 8 to determine its representative in the National Collegiate basketball tournament should two eligible teams tie in the conference race, Commissioner Wayne Duke said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 President Carter nominated today Adm. Stansfield Turner, who has made a reputation as a military analyst, to be Director of Central Intelligence.
The first New York blue ribbon individual championship, which ended Sunday night at the Manhattan Club, 228 West 71st Street, proved to be a feminine triumph.

The first of three concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Montclair College Chamber Orchestra, Sunday night, provided a short survey course in modern music since World War II. The well-drilled orchestra, made up of faculty members and students of the New Jersey school, played four pieces, each of which epitomized its decade.

It was not the shrewdness of Soviet negotiators that caused the fees for the rights for the 1980 Summer Olympics to reach a record $85 million, but rather inflation and the growing interest of American audiences in the Olympic events, Herbert S. Schlosser, president of NBC, said yesterday at a news conference.

PRAGUE, Feb. 7 One of Czechoslovakia's leading campaigners for human rights said today that he and his friends, deprived by the authorities of driver's licenses and telephones, had to use public transportation and "walk a lot to keep in touch."

Margaret Park Redfield, an anthropologist closely associated with the work of her late husband, Robert Redfield, who was Hutchins Distinguished Professor of Anthropology at the University of Chica- go, died Sunday in Chicago. She was 78 years old.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 7 (AP) Other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are considering asking Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates to join them in a uniform 1977 price increase of about 7.5 percent following Saudi Arabia's refusal to agree to a compromise of 10 percent for the whole year, the Middle East Economic Survey. reported today.
Racal Electronics of Britain and Applied Digital Data Systems are running neck and neck in their bid to acquire a majority of the shares of the Milgo Electronics Corporation.
Federal agents have captured Ernest Malizia, a major narcotics dealer who escaped from a Federal jail in Manhattan with the help of a Catholic priest more than two years ago.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 7 Legislation was introduced in the State House of Representatives today that would legalize casino gambling in resorts in the Pocono Mountains.

JERUSALEM, Feb, 7 For weeks now, Shimon Peres has been shuttling between Israel's big towns and its boondocks, buttonholing members of the country's Labor Party at kaffeeklatches, conclaves, committee meetings and argumentative gatherings of citizens voluble about where they think the country should be heading.

Well before Stephen Berger arrived home last March to run interference for Governor Carey on New York City's budget, his reputation for political and bureaucratic slugfests had preceded him. Nothing much has happened to disappoint his fans or to mollify his critics.
For periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) over the counter.

The Rangers gained some muchneeded respect by winning an intradivision game with the Islanders Sunday night, but they lost a defenseman for four to six weeks when Dave Maloney suffered a deep cut to the bone on his left wrist.

LONDON, Feb. 7 Two of Sir Harold Wilson's former kitchen cabinet confidants exploded with vitriolic attacks upon each other today, breaking a long British tradition of keeping internal disputes under cover. Before the day was over, the former Prime Minister who resigned unexpectedly last April, had joined in the feud.

OSSINING, N.Y. "An Army captain came around and gave my mother a check for $10,000, an American flag and a military marker for my father's grave," Bettye Conyers Hardeman said. "Big deal. There was no letter of apologies. That was in exchange, of course, for a man's whole life."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The United States has blocked the sale to Ecuador of 24 Israeli fighter-bombers equipped with American jet engines, the State Department said today.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) The price of gold rose today while the dollar was irregular.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 7 (UPI) The European Economic Community imposed heavy duties today on Japanese manufacturers of steel bearings and charged that the products were being sold in the mine Common Market nations at a price lower than those in Japan.
Consolidated Edison and the Brooklyn Union Gas Company are expected to give their natural gas customers rebates on their winter gas bills, nidustry sources said last night.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7 Gerald R. Ford returned today to the college campus where he coached football and studied law four decades ago, and he took the occasion to express regret for one of his more controversial acts while President.

MEDIA, Pa., Feb. 7 (AP) A judge ruled today that W.A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers, must stay in jail while the State Supreme Court studies a request to reconsider its decision ordering a new trial for him.

Make sure you tell them about the bitterness and the outrage, a fellow inmate urged when Andreas Schroeder said that he was going to write a book about his prison experiences. After he had been released and had published a preliminary article on the subject, Mr. Schroeder was deluged with invitations to appear on talk shows at public affairs programs to "describe some of the horrors of the place, the physical an psychic violence...."

A $6 million libel suit by Justice Dominick S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court against The Village Voice and an advertising agency was settled for $50,000 yesterday in a pretrial conference before Justice Bernard Nadel of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 A Congressional committee on drug abuse has found a "very substantial increase" in narcotics use among New York City schoolchildren in the last year year and a half "from the seventh grade on up."

Bruce Jenner knew from past experience that the Sullivan Award was usually given out in early February. He knew this because the award was always given out to other people. Even last year after he had set a world record in the decathlon the Sullivan Award found its way to someone else's trophy cabinet; it went to Tim Shaw, the swimmer.

The new teachers' contract approved yesterday by the Emergency Financial Control Board will provide average benefits of $4,198 over three years for each teacher. However, only the first two years of the pact, through Sept. 9, 1978, were given formal board approval.

Fourteen persons were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on obscenity charges stemming from the alleged sale of pornographic films, several of which depicted young children engaged in sexual acts. Eight of the defendants, whose arrests were announced early last month, were indicted on felony charges for the wholesale sale of obscene material to two undercover police officers who operated a pornographic book store near Times Square.

There are times when dining rooms should sparkle and other times when they should merely glow. Either way, with the flick of a switch, a flock of candles or the help of a tinsmith, mood lighting can transform a galley-sized cubicle, a great hall or the foyer of an apartment into the sort of festive setting all party planners seek.

WASHINGTON There was a high degree of elation here toward the end of last week among the various lobbying organizations that represent the nation's small-business community. They had just won a big victory in Congress on an issue they feared was impossibly lost a few weeks ago, and they counted rising support among the legislators for their position on a different tax plan to create new jobs in the private sector of the economy.

Hugh Shannon, who is the last of the great saloon singers and the progenitor of the contemporary line of singing pianists, is back in town in, of all places, the cocktail lounge of a Chinese restaurant, David K.'s Chung Kuo Yuan, Third Avenue at 65th Street. There is really nothing particularly Chinese about the room to begin with, and once Mr. Shannon gets behind his piano, the atmosphere is pure Shannon.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 7 The Rutgers front line of Abdel Anderson, James Bailey and Hollis Copeland had the kind of night coaches dream of when they go out recruiting big men like these. The trio of fast, lanky players got 64 points tonight as the Scarlet Knights ran away from Duquesne in the second half to whip the Dukes, 90-70, at the old Rutgers Gym.

A good idea, even a great idea, never hurt a musical. Yet oddly enough, a good idea, even a great idea, never saved a musical. "Castaways," a musical that opened last night at the Promenade Theater, has a tremendous idea behind it. But nothing really before it.

NEWARK, Feb. 7 The State Public Advocate and the state's largest electric utility disagreed sharply today over future power needs and the relative merits of nuclear energy and coal as fuels for leectricity generating plants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Dr. David J. Sencer, who helped develop the muchtroubled swine flu inoculation program, said today that he had been asked to step aside as director of the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta.
Special-situation and energy-related issues continued to advance yesterday while the stock market generally closed mixed in slower trading.
A leftish Democrat not yet born again in the Carter faith, while recently questioning the new President's commitment to various reforms, paused long enough to observe:

TRENTON, Feb. 7 The State Assembly tonight voted 53 to 11 against removing criminal sanctions for possession of small amounts of marijuana and hoshish, but the bill's sponsor, Eldridge Hawkins, kept the proposal alive through a parliamentary maneuver.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Carter Administration has brought more women into top-level jobs than any of its predecessors, and it will add others. But it has not satisfied women's groups in meeting the expectations raised by the Carter campaign.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The State Department said today that it had informed the Soviet Union that the United States was "watching with concern" the case of Aleksandr I. Ginzburg, a dissident who was arrested in Moscow last week.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb. 7 (UPI) A University of Florida botanist said today that last month's record freeze went through Florida's Everglades like "giant pruning shears" and caused widespread damage to exotic plants.

Warren D. Chandler, who was secretary of the Publishers Association of New York City for 22 years, died last Wednesday in Sarasota, Fla., where he had been living since 1973. He was 68 years old and a former resident of Larchmont, N.Y.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 7 The West African country of Benin charged in the Security Council tonight that a group of airborne "international mercenaries" in the pay of foreign enemies had attacked Cotonou last month, leaving many dead and wounded.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 The General Motors Corporation, the nation's leading domestic automobile manufacturer, reported today fourth-quarter and full-year sales and profits that were the highest in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Securities and Exchange Commission has found "a number" of insurance concerns that have, like the Government Employees Insurance Company, allotted far less money to meet predicted claims than they will need.

The Western industrial nations are making only slow and uneven progress in their struggle against inflation, according to figures published yesterday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris.

After a bad stumble on the political ice with his failed effort to appoint Theodore Sorensen, President Carter now seeks to restore his balance by nominating an Annapolis classmate, Adm. Stansfield Turner, as Director of Central Intelligence. Admiral Turner's credentials appear, on first inspection, to be impressive. Still, the nomination raises a new question and leaves unanswered an old one.

Well before Stephen Berger arrived home last March to run interference for Governor Carey on New york City's budget, his reputation for political and bureaucratic slugfests had preceded him. Nothing much has happened to disappoint his fans or to mollify his critics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The great bulk of Federal assistance to New York City, estimated at $2.8 billion this fiscal year, is unlikely to be affected by the city's slashes in its budget, the General Accounting Office said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) President Carter today sent three nominations to the Senate for confirmation, including that of W. Graham Claytor Jr. as Secretary of the Navy.

Mickey Lolich, who has struck out more batters than any other left-handed hurler in history, informed the New York Mets yesterday that he would not report to their spring training camp in St. Petersburg, Fla.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 New York State has its official bird, tree, flower, gem, fruit and animal, and if Assemblyman Eugene Levy has his way, it will soon have a State Insect the praying mantis.

The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday approved the contract granting a full range of disputed wage increases to 55,000 New York City teachers and other school employees although the contract would have to be renegotiated if some of the increases are eventually determined to be illegal.

The City University of NeW York, New York University and Columbia University are planning a joint venture on the doctoral level that will make it possible for students at one university to take courses at the other institutions.
The election of a Mayor of the City of New York is in danger of being settled forgive the phrase by default.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 7 (Reuters) The Colorado Party of President Alfredo Stroessner, ruler of Paraguay for the last 23 years, has won a comfortable victory in an election for a new constituent assembly.
William R. Farrell, an advertising executive who retired as director of the Monsanto Company's marketing services department, died Wednesday in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 69 years old.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7 (AP) A 21year-old Princeton University student said today that Pakistani diplomatic officials in Washington had requested a copy of his blueprint for building an atomic bomb.
Delta Air Lines and Braniff International have ordered a total of 30 727-200 jet airliners from the Boeing Company, Boeing announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP) The General Electric Company has come up with two new compounds to replace toxic polychlorinated biphenyls, the man-made chemical that has caused extensive pollution of waterways.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7?The strictest code of financial and ethical restrictions ever proposed for members of Congress cleared the new House reform commission virtually intact today, with the modest level of opposition encouraging its sponsors.

SALVADOR, Brazil, Feb. 5 Jorge Hage, the young Mayor of this city con sidered the pearl of Brazil, sometimes muses that an occasional natural disaster would be about the only solution to the perpetual urban crisis that he presides over.

MANILA, Feb. 7 A major political trial opened here today in a dingy courtroom on an army base outside the capital. The defendants are members of two leading political families and four other men charged with plotting seven attempts on the life of Presdient Ferdinand E. Marcos and fomenting rebellion.

Prices for green (unroasted) coffee deliverable next month on the docks of New York jumped 8 cents, to $2.36 a pound, yesterday. While the nearest contract is exempt from price restrictions, the later deliveries, which are restricted advanced the 3-cents-a-pound limit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) President Carter served notice today that when he leaves the White House for personal or family reasons, he intends to do so secretly even if his destination is a public event.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Damage to the economy from the severe winter has convinced some businessmen that they should support President Carter's proposal to pay most Americans $50, a Congressional committee was told today.
DETROIT, Feb. 7 (UPI) The economist Paul McCracken today called President Carter's economic proposals "a Rube Goldberg contrivance."

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 7 The Westchester Board of Legislators, confused and in disagreement over the impact that a tax-abatement program for business and industry would have on homeowners' tax bills, today scheduled a special Wednesday meeting to consider the plan and vote on it.

The United Hospital Fund of New York announced yesterday that it had founded an Institute for Health Care Studies to develop new approaches to providing health-care services, particularly in urban areas.
"It's got a terrific amount of residual awareness, mothers remember it with great fondness and it's one of the few construction toys that appeals to girls as well as boys."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Government wants to declare land belonging to an oil refinery, an Army rifle range and the Los Angeles International Airport as "critical" to the survival of several endangered species of California butterflies.
Because the top of his head is less than 3 feet below the rim of the basket, many people shrug at Kareem AbdulJabbar's skill. But those people don't understand basketball.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb.7 Battling an outgoing tide under the Golden Gate Bridge, Tomio Ikegawa sailed a battered 25-foot sloop into San Francisco Bay at sunset yesterday, ending an 118day solo journey from Japan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 President Carter warned today that the nation's energy problems remained critical despite moderating weather and the reopening of schools and plants in some areas of the country.

New York City's property-tax base, which dropped by $829 million last year, will shrink this year by about $400 million to $38,427 billion, City Finance Department officials predicted yesterday. In the last 34 years, the total value of taxable real estate has dropped only once before in 1976.
DETROIT, Feb. 7 The Ford Motor Company reduced prices today on its compact and subcompact cars by amounts of up to $50 in an attempt to increase sales of the slow-selling smaller models.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 7 (AP) Voters in the 28 counties of northwestern Minnesota will pick House candidates tomorrow in the first major election of the year. Republicans are hoping it will produce an omen of better things.

Wayne Embry has already watched more than 60 college basketball games. He has seen Kent Benson, the Indiana University center, play five times and has scouted Marques Johnson, the highscoring forward from the University of California, Los Angeles, three times. He plans to see 60 more games, including Benson and Johnson three more times each.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Tuesday, Feb. 8 The massacre of seven missionaries at the St. Paul's Mission northeast of here was a blow to the Roman Catholic church, which has been at the forefront of moves to improve the lives of Rhodesia's 6.2 million blacks.

Leonard A. Lovell, a retired partner of Tippetts-Abbett-McCarthy-Stratton, consulting engineers and architects of 345 Park Avenue, died Friday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J. He lived at 11 Plymouth Road, Summit, and was 69 years old.
The United States Customs Court in New York will soon hand down a decision spotlighting a difficult problem forced by the Carter Administration in international economic policy.

WASHINGTON We cannot, for obvious reasons, forfeit a major position in world affairs. And we must continue to rely on the executive as our principal spokesman internationally. But the retention of a strong world role and the maintenance of an effective defense posture will require that the President and his chief foreign affairs advisers begin to talk more sense to the Congress and to the people.

The credit markets opened trading yesterday with sharp price gains, continuing the strong recovery that began last Thursday. Then, for no discernible reason, the advance stopped, prices drifted back down to close little changed from Friday's levels.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania In a front-page editorial, The Daily News of Tanzania, a Government paper, charged recently that Western consumer efforts to curb coffee purchases because of rising prices were in reality a capitalist plot aimed at poor countries, such as Tanzania, that produce coffee.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 7 Andrew Young, who is on a tour of Africa for President Carter, arrived here tonight for discussions with top Government officials that could ease American-Nigerian relations badly strained for more than a year.

In a signifcant breakthrough in international publishing, American and Soviet companies have concluded negotiations on a private, commercial basis for English-language editions of Russian works and co-productions of important works in the fields of art and medicine. In addition, a history of the Olympic Games, tentatively titled "From Athens to Moscow," will be jointly undertaken before the 1980 Moscow Olympics.
What's red, originated in the Far East and sometimes seems to be taking over the world?

George Booth, the cartoonist, writes hourly reports so that he knows where his time goes. Charlemagne Palestine, a contemporary composer whose creative spirit works best at night, has blacked out all the windows in his loft so that, psychologically at least, there is no day. And Virgil Thomson, the composer-writer, has his telephone calls filtered through his hotel switchboard, denying him the temptation to while away work hours chatting.

CAIRO, Feb. 8 For the first time in more than two decades, an officially accredited political party appealed to Egyptian voters today to reject at the polls a measure proposed by the country's president.

In addition to being a superior technician, Ernesto Bitetti is a distinctively personal guitarist with a supple rhythmic sense and a penchant for understatement. His playing Sunday night at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. was notable for its undulating tempos and whispered dynamic shadings. Whether or not one agreed with all fo Mr. Bitetti's ideas, they were always tasteful and persuasively implemented.

Andy Varipapa, 86-year-old retired Hall of Fame bowler, has proven to be far better at knocking over pins than at prophesying. Years ago, when Varipapa first met Dick Weber at a tournament, he told him: "You'll never make it. You've got to have bigger, stronger wrists." Weber weighed 135 pounds and stood 5 feet 10 inches.

ROME, Feb. 8 A state-owned holding company that is able to stay alive only with heavy infusions of public funds has, generated a major controversy over its financing and has underscored the difficulties of Italy's staterun industries.
A Very Different Love Story, by Barry Stainback (Morrow, $8.95), Bizarre romance.
A classroom discussion at the Collegiate School in Manhattan of Mark Twain's "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court" included the question of moral responsibility to help the destitute.

ATLANTA, Feb. 8 The scramble for the Fifth Congressional District seat vacated by Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, appears to be shaking down into a racial but not racist battle among four candidates, two white and two black.

Janet Guthrie was named yesterday to drive the fastest car ever run at Indianapolis under current United States Auto Club technical limitations. Miss Guthrie, denied a chance at last year's Indy 500 starting field because of admittedly "marginal equipment," will pilot the Lindsey Hopkins Lightning, which Roger McCluskey drove last October at 198.7 miles per hour in tire tests at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. .

TRENTON, Feb. 8 State officials met today with the heads of major industrial customers of the South Jersey Gas Company whose supplies of natural gas were virtually cut off three weeks ago in an effort to help them locate new sources of gas so as to resume normal operations.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan Feb. 8 (AP) President Gaafar al-Nimeiry dismissed his Prime Minister and the rest of his Cabinet today, the presidential press office said. Mr. Nimeiry asked Prime Minister Rashid el-Tahir to continue in a caretaker status until a new Cabinet was formed, a statement added.

A 13-year-old girl and her 23-year-old sister were rescued by the police in a Paterson, N.J., motel room early yesterday morning, three hours after they had been abducted at gunpoint by four men in a shopping mall parking lot in nearby Paramus.

HARTFORD, Feb. 8 Gov. Ella T. Grasso today proposed a $1.876 billion budget reflecting the steady improvement in Connecticut's economy, with some modest new initiatives, no new taxes, and provision for the state gradually to take over the cities' remaining welfare burden.

ST. PAUL'S MISSION, Rhodesia, Feb. 8 Black teen-agers in school uniforms played happily today yards from the spot where seven Roman Catholic missionaries were slain by black terrorists on Sunday, but among older Rhodesians, black and white, disgust at the killings was profound.

MADRID, Feb. 8 The Government announced a major reform of Spain's restrictive political-association law tonight, opening the way to the legalization of most parties including, possibly, the Communists.

It has always been recognized that France is one of the world's strongest bridge-playing countries. In a span of 42 years, the French representatives have won the European team championship seven times, more than the representatives of any other country except Italy.

PRAGUE, Feb. 8 Pavel Kohout, the playwright whose works are banned in Czechoslovakia, expressed concern today that the Government might stage political trials to crush the movement around Charter 77, a human rights declaration.

The Long Island Lighting Company asked yesterday for 15.7 percent annual increase, in electric rates totaling $100,537,000, to take effect early next year. This would include an interim increase of $39.3 million, or 6.1 percent, to start June 1.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8 Three grain exporting companies and a grain elevator concern that they own jointly were convicted here today on Federal charges of conspiring to shortweight shipments to foreign customers over a six-and-a-halfyear period ending last June.

WASHINGTON THE only thing worse than government architecture in Washington, is privately-built architecture-or so it seems when one views the mess that dreary, boxlike office structures have made of the northwest section of downtown. There, since zoning laws pretty much restrict bulk and height of buildings, all architects are left to design are facades, and they play them to the hilt, with each flashy, showy building-front trying the best it can to outshine its neighbors.

PITTSBURGH, Wednesday, Feb. 9 Lloyd McBride, the "official family" candidate for president of the United Steelworkers of American, appeared today to have taken a substantial lead in his race against Ed Sadlowski, the insurgent candidate who has attacked the union's leadership.
Ledlie I. Laughlin, freshman adviser and associate director of admissions at Princeton University from 1928 to 1953, died Monday at his home in Princeton. He was 86 years old.

There's nothing like an acquisition offer to send a stock soaring in this lackluster market, where Wall Street worries about the problems of inflation and possible inroads on profits created by the severe winter weather.

The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday that its pipeline subsidiary would build a $1.55 billion, 750-mile line across Saudi Arabia to reduce shipping time for oil to Europe and the United States.

Kathleen Jones, principal clarinetist of the Puerto Rico Symphony Orchestra, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night with Yvonne Figueroa as assisting pianist. The program offered sonatas by Brahms (Op. 120. No. 2), Franz Danzi and Jack Delano, "Le Tombeau de Ravel" by Arthur Benjamin and, for unaccompanied clarinet, William O. Smith's Five Pieces.

The very nicest Valentines are cars drawn by children, and a kiss or two or three from a loved one. Also acceptable are a car and chauffeur, a full-time cook, unlimited credit at a book store and big, shiny, carat-ful baubles. Most other things are small time but as, alas, most of us are small time, let's consider what's around.

The Quartetto Italiano inaugurated a six-concert series of the complete Beethoven string quartets Monday night at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. The series will continue tomorrow and Feb. 17 with the Italian group, and with the Juilliard Quartet March 22 and 29 and April 19. Each program offers selected examples from different periods in Beethoven's creative life.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 New York's freshman Senator, Daniel P. Moynihan, ended a century-old jinx for Empire State Democrats tonight. It was rather like the old Brooklyn Dodgers winning the pennant after being also-rans for decades. The Senator confirmed that he had been named to a position on the powerful Senate Finance Committee.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest rubber producer, reported yesterday a 63.4 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings.

THE French actress Jeanne Moresu was married in Paris yesterday to William Friedkin, the American director of "The French Connection" and "The Exorcist." Witnesses to the civil ceremony were the French director Alain Resnais and his wife, the former Florence Malraux. Miss Moreau, who is 49 years old, and Mr. Friedkin, 38, had been expected to marry for some time.

Larry C. Flynt, editor and publisher of Hustler, a national men's magazine, was found guilty in Cincinnati yesterday of engaging in organized crime and pandering obscenity. He was sentenced to 7 to 25 years in prison and fined $10,000 on the organized crime charge and six months in jail and $1,000 on the obscenity charge.

And this is a season that has seen quite a few decent plays. This year, almost all of them have come from Britain.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) The dollar eased on European money markets today while the price of gold rose by $1 in Zurich and went up slightly in London.

WASHINGTON The Kennedy Center for the Perform ing Arts, under criticism in the past for its failure to attract in its audiences a larger number of Washington's 75 percent black population, has announced the formation of a National Commission on Blacks to foster more minority participation in the national cultural showcase at both the performing and audience levels.

One of them has seen many mating seasons come and go, but he remains in the full vigor of his maturity. Beneath his whitening pelt beats the heart of an ardent swain. The other is younger, stronger perhaps, but doubtful as to whether he wants to challenge the king of the forest.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 8 (UPI) A former West Point gun instructor, who said he had been cheated on a real estate deal, abducted the president of a real estate company today and marched him through downtown Indianapolis with a shotgun at his head, then took his hostage to an apartment, where he held off the police.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Arthur F. Burns, said today that as private credit demands strengthen, it may become "increasingly difficult" to finance at current interest rates the large Federal deficit expected this calendar year.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 The head of New York State's program of tuition assistance for college students testified today that trying to validate the claims of tens of thousands of students purporting to be financially independent of their parents and, therefore, deserving of grants, had become a vexing problem.

Dr. Harry Eugene Seanor Jr., a former director of pediatrics at the United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y., died suddenly yesterday in his home on Holly Lane, Rye, N.Y. His age was 56.

ROME The Italian Communist Party (PCI) is convinced the Carter Administration will change Washington's previous attitude of the cold shoulder, according to Sergio Segre; the PCI's principal foreign policy expert. He says "the old gap is already closing" and expects there will be a more forthright relationship between his party and the incoming ambassador, Prof.Richard N. Gardner.

Five physicians who once worked part time for the Police Department have taken advantage of a "heart bill" intended for disabled policemen and firemen and are receiving bonus retirement pensions of $21,900 to $25,600 annually from the city.
When the Knicks are good, they are very good. When they are bad, they are very bad.

Those frequent trips to Europe between visits to South America have finally paid dividends for Gordon Bradley, the head coach of the Cosmos, who announced yesterday the signings of two players from Yugoslavia.

NEWARK; Feb. 9 Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City became the third announced Democratic candidate for Governor today and promised to ease the tax burden of people on moderate income through a "decent, fair income tax."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Paul C. Warnke's former superior at the Pentagon said today that the Senate should not approve his nomination as negotiator in arms limitation talks with the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 Faced with strong opposition from the Black and Puerto Rican Caucus and unable to find the votes to assure passage, the State Assembly's Democratic leadership today deferred action on a New York City mayoral primary bill that would provide for a runoff election if no candidate got more than 40 percent of the first vote.

The Franklin Avenue shuttle in Brooklyn, initially targeted for shutdown to help close a $30 million Transit Authority budget gap, will be saved under a plan to be submitted to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority at its monthly meeting tomorrow, according to authority sources.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 American Airlines disclosed today a list of some 70 present and former members of Congress, including Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House and former President Ford, to whom it made illegal campaign contributions of between $50 and $1,000 from 1971 to 1973.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The hope of the Carter Administration during its first weeks in office is to turn aside the wrath of its critics in Congress and elsewhere by giving soft answers.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 A bill giving school districts that have lost classroom time Because of snow or fuel problems a painful choice limiting themselves to seven vacation days for the rest of the school year or losing some of their state aid passed the Legislature today with the support of Governor Carey.

Advertising agencies in their search for new clients frequently must do more than produce merely excellent, effective advertising. Sometimes they even advertise, using newspapers, magazines, direct mail, radio or, on rare occasions, television. A good public service campaign can serve as a showcase. Press coverage doesn't hurt either.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) An easy victory for Eddie Dibbs and a hardfought one for Harold Solomon marked the second round of the $50,000 Miami Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Like a row of dominoes that topples from the movement begun by a single falling piece, the far-reaching plan to streamline the Senate by reducing its committees from 31 to 15 was knocked down last week by the pressures to reinstate a single committee: Veterans Affairs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 Federal Government proposals for stiff new regu lations governing the blending and labeling of American table wines encountered strong opposition from the wine industry today at hearings here.
Braniff Airways has reached agreement with the French and British to provide subsonic service with the supersonic Concorde between Washington and the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport.
MADRID, Feb. 9 Spain and the Soviet Union announced a resumption of diplomatic relations today, 38 years after they were broken off at the end of the Spanish Civil War.

A Fifth Avenue building that formerly housed garment-industry showrooms has been purchased for a reported $2.4 million by a publishing operation associated with the Unification Church of America, headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

MEXICO CITY, FEB. 9 The Mexican Government tonight formally charged nine persons, including two American businessmen, with attempted fraud and falsification of documents in a case involving allegedly overpriced medicines sold to the Government.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 John S. Hastings, a senior judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit here, died Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where he underwent abdominal surgery Jan. 24. He was 78 Years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Following are highlights of the Veterans of Foreign Wars' campaign to reinstate the Committee on Veterans' Affairs:
Mayor Beame yesterday ordered a City Hall review of police pension plans, including the possible elimination of bonus payments of more than $20,000 yearly to part-time police surgeons.

Mayor Beame announced yesterday the nomination of Theodore E. Teah to be a member of the City Planning Commission. The appointment of Mr.Teah, a native of Indiana who has lived in the South Bronx for the last 10 years, is subject to confirmation by the Council under the city's new Charter.
Stock prices fell sharply along a broad front yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average slumping 8.40 points to 933.84.

Despite the partial lifting of the national moratorium on flu vaccinations, health officials in the New York metropolitan region and around the country agreed yesterday that it would take up to several days before the bivalent vaccine for swine and A-Victorian strains of flu could be administered to the elderly and others suffering from high-risk chronic diseases.

HACKENSACK, Feb. 9 A ruling by the State Attorney General's office is expected before the end of the week on a petition by the Public Advocate that all New Jersey nursing homes be required to reserve up to 15 beds for Medicaid patients as a condition of licensing.

Chad Mitchell, who's back at the Ballroom through Feb. 20, reconfirms the fine impression he made there last winter. Mr. Mitchell used to lead the popular Chad Mitchell Trio in the earlymid-1960's, then dropped out of sight and now finds himself living under the threat of a jail sentence for allegedly smuggling marijuana into this country. In the meantime, while his case is appealed, he is trying to rekindle his performing career.
PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9 Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis, who had been convicted a second time of murdering three persons in a bar here 10 years ago, tonight received the same sentences.
First, it was Memphis, where a star of the movie "Deep Threat" was convicted on charges of conspiring to transport obscene material across state lines.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) Britain's Labor Government today awarded its fifth round of oil exploration licenses for drilling in the North Sea and other offshore areas.

The top trouble-shooter in dealings between the New York City Board of Education and the city's 32 community school districts, Alfredo Mathew Jr., narrowly escaped injury after he was fired at in an apparent murder attempt, the police reported yesterday.

The name that four jazz musicians who have been playing at Stryker's, at 86th Street and Columbus Avenue, on the last two Tuesday evenings use is both provocative and apt Double Image. The primary focus of the group is on two musicians named David David Friedman and David Samuelseach of whom plays both vibraharp and marimba, changing places at the two instruments from one selection to another and even in the midst of a piece.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 A record national harvest of oranges, despite the recent freeze damage to Florida's big crop, was predicted today by the Agriculture Department.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 9 The American "citizens' band" craze has suddenly caught on in Mexico even though all the equipment must be smuggled into the country and is subject at any moment to confiscation as contraband.

With only three more states needed to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment, the North Carolina House of Representatives voted for the measure yesterday 24 hours after it had suffered a setback in Idaho, United Press International reported. The amendment went to the Senate in North Carolina.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8 John A. Phillips's life hasn't been the same since he became Princeton University's Tiger cheerleader, started his own pizza-delivery business and designed an atomic bomb.

The New York cocoa market was roiled yesterday by reports that the Hershey Foods Corporation and other leading chocolate manufacturers were planning to reduce the size of their products as well as raise prices, which Hershey announced during the day.

WASHINGTON Feb. 9 With the happy zest of a confident candidate, President Carter today took his message of government reform and reorganisation to several thousand Federal employees, assuring them that none would lose their jobs and urging them to take seriously their role as a bridge between the bureaucracy and the people.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The Maine Congressionel delegation has announced proposals, including an appeal to President Carter, to help resolve an Indian claims suit to two thirds the land in the state.

JERUSALEM. Feb. 9 The presence of Syrian troops in southern Lebanon near the Israeli border has been the focus of diplomatic footwork, a source for rumors, a vast amount of press coverage and speculation and a spate of comments by political and military figures, giving rise to a mood that combines confusion and tension.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Aquilino Boyd unexpectedly resigned today as Foreign Minister of Panama, raising doubts about the resumption next week of negotiations with the United States on a new Panama Canal treaty.

North Jersey residents who may have noticed a yellowish or orange flame in their gas jets instead of a blue one were advised yesterday by officials of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in Newark that there was no cause for alarm.

Determined to be positive about life's passage, Jim Hyland celebrated his 40th birthday by bringing a big bottle of champagne to the dining-room table as his wife and seven children watched. He popped the cork and quickly caught the bubbling geyser with his mouth. But the gush knocked his one false tooth into his windpipe and left everyone gasping along with Jim as he was rushed off to Long Island Jewish Hospital.

A Bankrupt garment manufacturer facing murder charges in the deaths of his former wife and a woman companion in their Connecticut home was found dead in his Manhattan walkup apartment Tues day, apparently a suicide, the police said.

Random House, one of the major publishers in New York, which is a subsidiary of RCA Corporation, the broadcasting and electronics conglomerate, is expected to be sold to the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles, the newspaper conglomerate with strong interests in book publishing.

There's an awful lot of whimsy going to women's heads. Combs, barrettes and flowers are the least of it. The fad carries on from threading a pearl or two in one's hair, to gathering it up into wisps fastened with brightly colored rubber bands.
TOKYO, Feb. 9 (AP) Japan's iron and steel exports last year totaled a record 37 million tons, up 23 percent over 1975, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.

LONDON, Feb. 9 Four Irishmen were found guilty of six murders today. The men, members of the I.R.A. Provisionals, refused to plead and the court entered a not guilty plea for them. They left the dock after calling the trial a "farce" and "political."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The Government was reported tonight to be on the verge of taking unusual measures to bring more heating oil to the East Coast from abroad without driving up prices, already at record levels.
OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 9 (UPI) A mandatory 25 percent reduction of water consumption for 1.1 million East Bay Municipal Utility District water users has gone into effect because of the drought.
WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Feb. 9 (AP) Connecticut's daily lottery will begin March 16, but faulty tickets have postponed the resumption of the instant lottery, the State Gaming Commission said today.

The commotion in the liberal community about President Carter's proposals to stimulate the economy deserves a closer look. The dispute, although among friends, is basic: Can the programs designed to fight recession be distinguished from those needed to combat chronic unemployment?

A podiatrist who said he was appalled when asked to contribute to a fund to bribe an official in efforts to block the proposed elimination of podiatry services from reimbursement under Medicaid reported the plot to Nicholas Scoppetta, the Commissioner of Investigations. That was 14 months ago.

And when the clock had ticked off the final seconds, the Sabres were the celebrants instead with a 2-1 victory over the New York Rangers.
A nervous Government and corporate bond market yesterday rose slightly early in the day and later retreated to close with moderately large declines in prices.

"Seventh Avenue," based on the doorstopper of a novel by Norman Bogner, is the third "Best Seller" this season to be serialized by NBC on Thursday nights, after "Captains and the Kings" and "Once an Eagle." Tonight, at 9 o'clock, we get, the first two hours of a total of six, with the miniseries continuing Feb. 17 and ending Feb. 24.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Feb. 9 Floyd Wilkie, an assistant ski school director at this secluded White Mountains resort, was instructing a "shortie" ski class and expressing his teaching preference for the "shortie" technique.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Nearly one is three American workers gave up their jobs and changed careers during a five-year period, the Labor Department found in its first major study of career, switching.

Marcos. They were sentenced to-six years at hard labor and fined $1,300 each.
LONDON, Feb. 9 Queen Elizabeth flew off tonight on a Silver Jubilee tour of Commonwealth countries in the Pacific.

Ford.

Two boys believed to be 12 to 14 years old were seen carrying a 30-pound cobblestone that later crashed through the windshield of a car on the East River Drive during the rush hour Tuesday afternoon and killed a 24-year-old woman passenger, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 American friends of Park Tong Sun, a central figure in the Korean bribery charges here, have disclosed that Mr. Park has asserted that he was the organizing force behind the formation of a bank that is under Federal investigation here.
Americans favor a constitutional amendment to replace the Electoral College with direct popular choice of the President by a 5-to-1 margin, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) President Carter announced today exceptions to his conflict-of-interest guidelines so that two top Pentagon appointees would not be required to sell large stock holdings in two corporations.

A survey of Roman Catholics on the East Side of Manhattan indicates that sharp declines in attendance at mass over the last decade have resulted from a loss of faith in the supernatural rather than disagreement with the church's moral teachings or changes in ritual.
The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that supplies of home heating oil continued to decline last week, falling by nearly 7 percent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 "In 1975, we almost brought Israel to their knees after the Yom Kippur War," charged candidate Jimmy Carter in his second TV debate with President Ford, "by the so-called reassessment of our relationship to Israel.... In the first 70 days of the Police Department's crackdown in Harlem on narcotic traffickers, almost 2,000 drugrelated arrests were made, Mayor Beame said.

The second officer of wrecked oil tanker Argo Merchant testified yesterday that the ship's gyrocompass may have been malfunctioning days before the disaster, not just hours United Press International reported.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 On being designated today as the first New Yorker on the top-ranking Senate Finance Committee in a half-century, Senator Daniel P. Moynihan called for easing New York State's tax burden and for a "very hard look" at Japanese trading practices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Hopes for a quick settlement of the National Football League's player-owner disputes seemed close to collapse today after two days of negotiations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 There is a peculiar, almost venomous intensity in some of the opposition to Paul Warnke as President Carter's chief arms control negotiator a feeling beyond the usual policy disagreement in a democracy. It is as if the opponents have made him a symbol of something they dislike so much that they want to destroy him.

The Ford Motor Company yesterday became the first automobile manufacturer to announce definite plans to buy millions of the fingernail-sized electronic devices called microprocessors tiny computers on chips of silicon to control fuel usage on cars of model years beyond 1978.

James Greene, executive vice president of the American Express International Banking Group, expressed doubt yesterday that the private banks would be able to sustain their increasing share of the debts owed by less developed countries.

Marshall Chapman, who's at Reno Sweeney through Saturday opening for Louis St. Louis, is a tall, lanky country singer from Spartanburg, S.C., by way of Nashville. Miss Chapman gave every sign at her Tuesday debut set of being a potential country, and even rock, star.

The New York Times Company reported yesterday that it earned $9.18 million, or 81 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1976, up from $1.42 million, or 13 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 5 Federal mediators, at the request of the management of the financially troubled Washington Star, scheduled a meeting for tomorrow afternoon between the management of the paper and the unions representing its workers.

Yet the hope of President Jose Lopez Portillo is to achieve what even the least cynical Mexican still believes can't happen here: a government both competent and incorruptible.

One of the most-popular conventions in modern tournament play is "Drury." When partner has bid one spade or one heart in third seat, a two-club bid asks him to bid two diamonds if he has a minimum or subminimum hand. This will often permit the partnership to remain safely at the two-level when each player has about 11 high-card points.

TRENTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) A toll-free New Jersey state income-tax hotline will begin operating tomorrow to help state residents prepare their returns.

Justice Cortland A. Johnson, a member of the State Supreme Court from 1943 to 1961 and a senior judge until 1967, died Saturday at his home, 67 Hilton Avenue, Garden City, L.I. He was 85 years old.

The New York City Ballet Guild will hold a cocktail party and auction this evening on the promenade of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, to raise money to help make up for the losses sustained by the company during the recent strike.

On the day and days following a request by a transplanted English woman for a source for English "bangers" (sausages) this desk was deluged with replies from readers, most of them recommending with heartfelt praise the bangers made and shipped by McArthur's Smokehouse in Millerton, N.Y. Many of them sent catalogues and we heard from the smokehouse owner as well.

Branding the New York City school custodians' operation as "corrupt" and "sick to its core," the deputy school chancellor said yesterday that he would remove the system's longtime chief of custodians and ask the Board of Education to call in the State Investigation Commission to conduct a thorough inquiry into the $100 million-a-year program.

GLEN HEAD, L.I. There are those who love the Sea Cliff Elementary School, with its patchwork cinderblock facade, with its three styles of windows, and with the skylights and walls that leak heat faster than the venerable boilers can pump it out.

A Federal environment monitor estimated yesterday that cleanup efforts led by the United States Coast Guard would "probably not pick up more than 10 percent" of 420,000 gallons of oil spilled 10 days ago into the Hudson River by a grounded barge north of Bear Mountain.

Swift on the attack, bruising on defense and strong in goal in the final period, the Rangers crushed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 8-3, at Madison Square Garden last night, scoring six goals in the middle period. It was the the most productive period of the season for the Rangers, matching the National Hockey League high for goals in a period this season, achieved by Montreal.

WASHINGTON No wars are going on anywhere. The nation is in a time of relative prosperity. Interesting new faces are in the news, and no new scandals or old hatreds poison the public atmosphere.

PARIS, Feb.13 (AP) Bellino II, who was feared to be aging rapidly when the season began, won the Prix de Paris today for the third straight year, the first trotter in 20 years to accomplish that feat.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 (AP) Pam Higgins sank a 3-foot putt for a par 4 on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today to capture a $50,000 tournament of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association. The victory was worth $7,500.

The first foreign head of government to visit Jimmy Carter's White House is another new President, Jose Lopez Portillo, and their meeting today is a symbol of the traditional amity and the intense interdependence between Mexico and the United States. Yet the nature of that interdependence is such that, regardless of the amity, there are no easy, short-term measures Mr. Carter can take to help his guest cope with Mexico's formidable problems.

The newly formed resident troupe of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the BAM Theater Company, will initiate its first season next month with Langdon Mitchell's comedy "The New York Idea" and Anton Chekhov's "The Three Sisters." The company, which is headed by Frank Dunlop and Berenice Weiler, includes Rene Auberjonois, Blythe Danner, Denholm Elliott, Tovah Foldshuh and Rosemary Harris, among others.

The Swiss dramatist Friedrich Durrenmatt, best known for "The Visit," has the most lively concept of the ab surd in his plays, which tend to burst across the stage like firecrackers, always surprising, always loud and yet not always significant. There are exceptions his "Play Strindberg," a gloss on Strindberg's own "Dance of Death," is one, and "The Physicists," which is just being restaged at the McCarter Theater here, is probably another.

Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan was recently reported as saying that cuts in the Fire Department's manpower may have been less harmful than expected. Statistics were printed, ostensibly to reassure the citizens that the risk factor, though not diminishing, has nevertheless not increased.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 13 (AP) Yum Dong-Kyun of South Korea won a unanimous decision over Jose Cervantes of Colombia today and retained the World Boxing Council's light featherweight boxing title. CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 13 (AP) The court appointed trustee of the defunct Hamilton Bancshares Inc. has filed suit against directors of the company and the Chicago-based accounting firm of Arthur Anderson Company, seeking $155 million to repay creditors and shareholders, plus punitive damages.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Joan Claybrook, a lobbyist for Ralph Nader's consumer causes here, has been nominated by Transportation Secretary Brock Adams to be the administrator of the National Highway Transportation Safety administration.

After falling fast in January and bouncing back forcefully but briefly early in February, the credit markets last week took a break from all that excitement. Some recitalists attract polite and attentive audiences, some attract noisy gatherings of fanatics, and a few, such as Frederica von Stade, seem to draw around themselves circles of friends and lovers. Miss von Stade's song recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday, perhaps the most consistently winning program that she has yet presented in New York, quickly turned into just such a love feast. They will then seek a longrun strategy to help the needy get the fuel they, must have in ways they can afford.

WASHINGTON Growing numbers of criminologists and politicians are urging tougher sentencing as a way of reducing street crime. They argue that increasing the number of offenders sent to prison will decrease the crime rate, either by removing the more prolific criminals from the streets or by deterring others from yielding to temptation.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 14 Representative Henry B. Gonzalez said today he had won the support of the House majority leader, Jim Wright of Fort Worth, and the chairman of the House Administration Committee Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of New Jersey, in his bid to oust Richard D. Sprague as staff director of the committee to investigate the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Bell said today.

Time Inc., the nation's leading magazine publisher, reported yesterday a profit increase of 62 percent in the fourth quarter and a rise of 49 percent for all of last year, when revenues topped $1 billion for the first time. The company also disclosed that its common shares would be listed on the London Stock Exchange today.

The New York City Health Department voiced concern yesterday over the fact that sulfur-dioxide levels in the air had increased since four major fuel-oil distributors were allowed limited variances starting Feb. 3 to market higher-sulfur oil in the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Low-income citizens of Davenport, Iowa, in a case that could shape Federal policy, have won a consent decree in Federal court compelling their city to spend less Federal money on tennis courts and more on housing for the poor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Belownormal temperatures with occasional warm days are expected over most of the Eastern United States during the next 30 days, the National Weather Service said today.

Ron Andrews, the league's publicist, said that as far as he could determine Hill was the first player to score 5 points in his first N.H.L. game.
LONDON, Feb. 14 Anthony Crosland, Britain's Foreign Secretary, is "dangerously ill" in a hospital at Oxford, the Foreien Office said today.
A limit advance in coffee futures prices, a limit decline in cocoa and further gains in cotton were among the highlights in the commodities markets yesterday.

The curtain came down on the first day of the 101st Westminster Kennel Club last night in Madison Square Garden with the nation's greatest winning bitch in the history of all breeds and the top working dog of 1976 taking the terrier and working groups. One of the world's older symphonic groups the Zurich Tonhalle Orchestra made its first New York appearance last night in Carnegie Hall. Debt to member firms of the New York Stock Exchange by margin account customers increased in January for the secand straight month by $310 million to a record $8.27 billion, the Big Board reported yesterday.

Unable to win amnesty for New York City policemen accused of misconduct in last autumn's demonstrations, and barred by his own organization from negotiating a contract without amnesty, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association resigned yesterday.

Macdonald, launched into a polemic against the Communist threat to the church and the country posed by the insurgents.
