BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 15 (UPI) Vietnam accused the United States today of using undercover military agents in Thailand and teams of Green Beret troops in Laos to sabotage peace in Southeast Asia.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 15 Organized labor is preparing another major legislative drive to obtain passage of a new construction industry picketing bill similar to the one President Ford vetoed last year.

Rifles and muskets such as those owned by Frederick Cowan, as well as shotguns, can be purchased anywhere in the state except New York City without a permit by anyone who is over 18, a state police officer said yesterday. But all counties require a license to purchase pistols such as the four that Mr. Cowan was carrying.

William Dowell Rhew, retired secretary of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived on Fairchild Road in Sharon.

A detente in the cold war that has long embittered relations between organized labor in the United States and Canada may be a significant byproduct of last week's elections in the 1.4-million-member United Steelworkers of America.
Joseph Moncure March, a poet and screenwriter, died Monday in a Los Angeles nursing home. He was 78 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

HONG KONG, Feb. 15 (AP) Chinese leaders have indicated to David Rockefeller that they want to settle the dispute over Chinese assets frozen in the United States and private American claims in China, the Far Eastern Economic Review reported today.

Samuel DeMilia, the new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, takes office facing the same problem that forced his two immediate predecessors to quit within the last nine months: anything he can get from the city the membership is likely to turn ...
Wheat and corn futures prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as soybeans futures prices were mixed and those of oats declined.

"Finian's Rainbow," the E.Y. (Yip) Harburg-Burton Lane-Fred Saidy hit musical, which ran on Broadway for 725 performances starting in 1947, has been selected as this summer's attraction at the Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, L.I. Under the direction of John Fearnly, it will be presented at the 8,200-seat outdoor theater from June 30 through Sept. 4.

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 15(AP) Denmark's Social Democrats, who have governed as a minority since January 1975, scored significant gains in general elections today as voters responded to Prime Minister Anker Jergensen's call for a mandate to tackle unemployment, mounting foreign debts and labor disputes.

THERE IS A ROW of old Gothicfronted houses on Fourth Avenue at 11th Street behind Grace Church that the church's former rector dismissed three years ago as "a blight, an embarrassment, an albatross around my neck." The rector, Dr. Benjamin Minifie, wanted to tear the houses down to build a much-needed gymnasium for the Grace Church School.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 The State Senate voted formal support today for an unusual lawsuit the chairman of its Insurance Committee brought quietly late last year against the State Superintendent of Insurance.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) The total cost of major new United States weapons has registered its highest jump in more than six years, the Pentagon reported today.

Trying to scotch continuing rumors that he is really interested in running for City Council President rather than Mayor, Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan ruled out the Council Presidency yesterday with an unequivocal statement that would have made General Sherman proud.

Don King was in town yesterday to announce his promotion of a 12-round heavyweight fight March 17 in Puerto Rico between George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, and Jimmy Young. King also announced that the World Boxing Association lightweight championship, a 15-rounder between Roberto Duran of Panama and Jose Marquez, the fourth-ranked challenger from Puerto Rico, would be on the same card.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15(AP) The United States and the European Economic Community signed an agreement today recognizing the new American 200-mile coastal fishing zone.
It's too bad that the New York State Open Meetings Law has become known as the "sunshine" law rather than the "sunlight" law. Sunlight clarifies but sunshine glares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 A Securities and Exchange Commission staff investigation that is still in progress has in its preliminary stage been severely critical of both high New York City officials and officials of major banks, who coordinated their activities at the outset of the city's fiscal crisis, according to persons familiar with the investigation.

The New York Times will publish, beginning March 17, a new Thursday section about the home, it was announced by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher. Called The Home Section, it will emphasize furniture and furnishings, design and decoration, landscaping and gardening, and home entertaining and life styles.

Whatever happened to the Class of '76? The last time anyone looked, its members were getting diplomas and worrying about getting jobs. Their college years, by all reports, were a time of seriousness no more of that demonstrating and carrying on that preoccupied their older brothers and sisters.

A bill to permit thousands of qualified elderly tenants in rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments to carry forward a part of their present rent-increase exemptions when they move was approved yesterday by the New York City Council's General Welfare Committee.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 15 A week before the Israeli Labor Party's highly charged nominating convention, the governing party is reeling from the latest in a series of scandals and political setbacks that raise serious questions about the future of the party, which has dominated Israeli political life since the country was founded in 1948.

DIANE VON FURSTENBERG princess, author, dress company president, cover girl and mother of two slipped off a patent leather pump, folded a slim calf under a slim knee, settled back against a valentine-pink satin pillow, tossed her head in such a way that the curls ended up looking like something that had just left Kenneth's, and meditated for a moment. The secret to life, she said is organization.

At 8 in the morning, it is still dark. Leningraders, bundled so they look like barrels on legs, rush to catch buses on the large square dominated by the golden-domed Cathedral of St. Isaac. Under a street lamp, a woman in a headscarf and many sweaters sweeps at the light dusting of snow with a long broom. She resembles the largest of those wooden dolls-within-dolls that tourists snap up.

TRENTON, Feb. 15 A New Jersey insurance company specializing in writing industrial accident insurance became so worried a year ago about the decline in manufacturing jobs in the state that it hired a research company to make a detailed study of what was wrong.
NEW ROCHELLE, Feb.15 The New Rochelle police began today to investigate Frederick W. Cowan's link with a militant racist organization, believed to be the National States Rights Party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) There is a "very high degree of certainty" that drought in California and other Pacific Coast states will continue for at least the next nine months, the Agriculture Department said today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) The motorman of an elevated train has told a Federal investigator that all brakes failed shortly before his train rammed the rear of another Feb. 4, killing 11 persons.
PANAMA, Feb. 15(AP) Panama and the United States resumed high-level negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty today on the resort island of Contadora off the Panama coast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has proposed creating a new agency with authority to set limits on rising health care costs for the country, Administration sources said today.

CROWN ACCUSTOMED What would George Rose be expected to do as the "Interlude" star this afternoon at Town Hall? Will he talk about his 25 years in theater? His training in the English classics, his 30 movies, his television work or his Tony-winning role in "My Fair Lady"?

MIAMI BEACH In contiguous meeting rooms in the Fontainebleau Hotel, the presidents of the three television networks yesterday held discussions on programs and ratings with executives of their affiliated stations. The CBS meeting, in the room between the other two, was interrupted by occasional bursts of applause from the NBC group on the right and by frequent exuberant clapping from the triumphant ABC affiliates on the left.

VIENNA, Feb. 15 (AP) For the second time in three days, the Czechoslovak authorities have taken a Western journalist off the Prague-Vienna express train, searched him for material on the human rights movement and forced him to walk two miles with his luggage to get across the border into Austria.
OTTAWA, Feb. 15 (AP) An additional 12 billion cubic feet of natural gas has been licensed for emergency export to the United States, the National Energy Board said today.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday fourth-quarter net income of $71.7 million, equal to $1.14 a share, or four times the $17.7 million, or 20 cents a share, earned in the corresponding final quarter of 1975. Net sales of $1.6 billion were up 46 percent from $1.1 billion in the prior year's period.

Suppose you were told of a liquid that would ease the pain of insect bites or sunburn, loosen the fierce grip of a corroded bolt, impart a gleam to the top of a loaf of homemade bread, open a clogged drain, help prolong the life of cut flowers, tenderize tough meat, clean windows, banish odors, remove stains, restore luster to patent leather and lend zest to salads.

Arthur O. Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, was presented yesterday with the Big Apple Award for "outstanding commitment to New York City" by the New York chapter of the National Home Fashions League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The Justice Department has more than 100 grand jury investigations of criminal antitrust violations pending and intends to tell Federal judges "clearly and unequivocally" that convicted violators should spend time in prison, an official of the antitrust division said today.

The High School of Music and Art and its affiliated High School of Performing Arts, now occupying separate facilities uptown and in midtown, will be combined early next year in the building that now houses the Martin Luther King Jr. High School in the Lincoln Center area, school officials said yesterday.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Feb. 15 (AP) Cary Adgate, held up at the start for more than a minute by faulty timing equipment, turned in the fastest time for both runs and won the men's slalom today at the United States national Alpine championships.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, Feb. 15 (Reuters) A court here imposed jail sentences today on 176 leftists for plotting to overthrow King Hassan and establish a people's republic in Morocco.

Six teen-age boys armed with a chain and a steel-studded belt terrorized passengers on two BMT subway trains in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, beating and robbing three persons, one of them a 79-year-old man, the Transit Authority reported.

Neither the Jets nor the Mets moved an inch yesterday as the principals in the Shea Stadium controversy met with Mayor Beame at City Hall and then Gracie Mansion in an effort by the Mayor to stem the Jets' threatened shift to New Jersey.
ROME, Feb. 15 (AP) The Vatican, a male fortress a decade ago, has since granted women an increasing number of jobs, but its ban on women priests bars women from any executive or decisionmaking posts.

A VERY FISHER HALL'S appraisal period went into a new phase on Monday night with the appearance there of the Cleveland Orchestra under its music director, Lorin Maazel. Until Mr. Maazel conducted his all-Beethoven program, the only orchestra to have played in the remodeled hall was the New York Philharmonic.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 The first goal ever credited to a goaltender in the 60-year history of the National Hockey League was nullified an hour and a half later tonight by the official scorer and not the opposing team.

Less publicized than sunshine laws possibly because their prospects are dimmer are sunset laws. Like sunshine laws, they seek to open up government; they require government agencies periodically to prove they are needed. Senators Muskie of Maine and Percy of Illinois are now championing Federal sunset legislation of the kind adopted by various states.

Nazi war souvenirs or, as he prefers to call them, "Germanic Second World War items," make up almost a quarter of the volume of business that Roderick Jones does in military memorabilia. A retired Air Force man, he is happy in the business he knows best and says he has "no qualms whatsoever" about that percentage.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., Feb. 15 (UPI) Thirty pedigreed Afghans, including four breeding bitches and four litters of puppies, died this morning in a fire at the Sunny Shay Grandeur Kennels.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 Domestic new-car sales were up 19.1 percent in early February from last year as the industry recovered some of the business lost last month because of the weather, according to reports from the four domestic companies.

HARTFORD, Feb. 15 An eight-member panel that visited nuclear installations in the state says that the latent hazards of radiation posed by such plants may have been understated by studies on the subject. And it called for the establishment of an agency independent of the utilities to check the plants regularly for possibly hazardous operations.

FOR 10 YEARS or so, beginning in 1876, when they leased a theater at Broadway and Spring Street, Ned Harrigan and Tony Hart were the toasts of the city's immigrant population. Irish, Germans, Italians and Jews, if they could understand the language, paid hard-earned dimes and quarters for an evening of knockabout comedy, sentimental songs, melodrama and elaborate scenic effects.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 A Securities and Exchange Commission staff investigation that is still in progress has in its preliminary stage been severely critical of both high New York City officials and officials of major banks, who coordinated their activities at the outset of the city's fiscal crisis, according to persons familiar with the investigation.

IT'S NOT that cooking ever really went out of style. But, for a while there, it wasn't easy for a liberated woman to admit that it was fun. After all those centuries of oppression, who could dare to love the smell of simmering soup, or confess to a passion for homemade granola, let alone pate de canard en croute?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico called today for the establishment of "a reasonable world order" and an international system of "economic rights and duties" to help developing countries overcome their economic problems.
American industry cut back production sharply last month as a result of the bitter cold weather and resultant shortages of natural gas, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.
RICHMOND, Feb. 15 The opening of the shad season in Virginia has been a nightmare for the state's fishermen and a prospective disappointment for lovers of shad roe.
VIKHROLI, India, Feb. 15 With tearful kisses and warm hugs, Lillian Carter paid a nostalgic visit today to the public health clinic where she had served as a Peace Corps nurse 10 years ago.

The American Jewish Congress announced resumption yesterday of its travel program to Mexico, suspended late in 1975 when Mexico voted in favor of the United Nations resolution equating Zionism with racism.

A YEAR ago this month, Federal District Judge John J. Sirica suffered a massive heart attack while delivering a speech. Although the former Watergate judge had no heart beat and was "legally dead" for four minutes, a deputy Federal marshal saved his life and his brain by immediately doing mouth-tomouth breathing and chest compression until hospital rescuers arrived.
Two police officers captured a holdup suspect yesterday after he reportedly fired a shot at them in the basement of a drug store at 144 Eighth Avenue near 17th Street.
As the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund enters its final weeks, many of its loyal supporters are contributing a second time.

The struggle over which of two companies is to acquire the Miami-based Milgo Eletronics Corporation, whose revenues have totaled $40 million in each of the last two years, has turned into one of the sharpest merger battles in the history of the electronics business.

Here are some of the ways in which vinegar comes in handy. Unless otherwise specified, the vinegar in question is white vinegar. Not only is vinegar a time-honored remedy for insect bites and sunburn, it also soothes bruises, chapped hands and hives.
The "death ray" is still in the realm of science fiction, but lasers powerful enough to inflict significant damage are moving toward the arsenals of the Soviet Union and the United States.

A dedicated policeman, a survivor of the Italian campaign in World War II, a former high school football star, a man who worked all his life for an elusive goal independence and a young immigrant from India: they bade loved ones goodbye Monday morning and went off to work. None returned.

"Jules Feiffer's Hold Me!" an entertainment drawn from Mr. Feiffer's cartoons and sketches of the last 20 years, will move Saturday from the Subplot Cafe at the American Place Theater to the Westside Cabaret Theater, 407 West 43d Street, for an indefinite run.

Jay F. Morris, a Government official, conducts an unusual talent search each year. As director of the President's Commission on Personnel Interchange, he heads a seven-year-old program that puts Government middle managers into corporate jobs for a year and brings corporate executives into Government for a year.
SEATTLE, Feb. 15 The American Bar Association rejected today a proposal by some of its members that the A.B.A. urge the repeal of all state death penalty laws.

Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl became the fourth Sealyham in Westminister history to go best in show as the twoday event ended last night at Madison Square Garden. The selection was a popular choice with the crowd of 8,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The nomination of Kenneth S. Axelson, former J. C. Penney corporate officer, as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury has been held up by Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal pending the completion of an investigation in New York into alleged kickbacks and other improprieties involving construction contracts at J.C. Penney Inc. headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is facing suits from hundreds of asbestos workers who say the Government failed to warn them about a disabling lung disease.

MUNICH, West Germany Lenin sent a memorandum to his commissar for external affairs, Georgi Chicherin, in 1921 and it makes impressive reading today. The great revolutionist predicted that the capitalists "will open up credits for us for the purpose of supporting Communist parties in other countries.

GENEVA, Feb. 15 The Carter Administration assured the 30-nation disarmament conference today that it was giving the "highest priority" to achieving international accords banning all nuclear testing and outlawing chemical weapons.

Alan Ayckbourn's six-character comedy. "Absent Friends," will make its American debut this spring at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, replacing the previously announced presentation of Arthur Miller's "The Archbishop's Ceiling."

TORREMOLINOS, Spain Six players Florin Gheorghiu of Rumania, Stefano Tatai of Italy, Garcia Padron and Juan Bellon of Spain, and Larry Christiansen and I of the United States were tied for first place after four rounds of the Costa del Sol International Tournament in the Cervantes Hotel here.
Jersey City got a baseball team yesterday, its first in organized baseball in 16 years.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 Stephen Chinlund, appointed to head the State Commission of Correction last July, was criticized tcday as being unduly deferential to the Department of Correctional Services, whose operations the commission is charged with monitoring.

The General Motors Corporation, which has been trying for two years to conclude an agreement with Poland for a $1 billion truck plant, "will have to go another way" if no accord is reached within three or four months, according to Reuben R. Jensen, executive vice president in charge of G.M.'s overseas operations.

Andrew Gold, who has been Linda Ronstadt's musical director for several years now is emerging as the latest wunderkind of Los Angeles pop. He has recorded with Carly Simon, James Taylor, and Maria Muldaur, and has written songs for Leo Sayer and Judy Collins, among others.

Alexander's Inc., one of the metropolitan area's largest retail chains, is in "serious negotiations" with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to open the first department store in the World Trade Center, the retail company disclosed yesterday.

ESSEN, West Germany, Feb. 15 (Reuters) Krupp, the West German industrial group, said today it had concluded a Barter deal with Iran under which it would obtain crude oil in return for industrial equipment.
FRANCISTOWN, Botswana, Feb. 15 Hundreds of young black Rhodesians are moving through an overcrowded camp outside Francistown each week, heading for guerrilla training camps in neighboring Zambia.

The Sony Corporation introduced yesterday a consumer service that transfers home motion picture color films or 35 millimeter slide transparencies to videocassettes for viewing on the company's Betamax television recorder players.

Stanislas Idzikowski, who was a leading dancer in Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, died Saturday in a London nursing home. He was 82 years old.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP) No new bargaining sessions were scheduled today as contract talks remained suspended in the 10-day old strike against Rockwell International car and truck component plants in six states.

A BABY'S first bath is often a short trip from tension to bliss. At first the parent feels awkward, stiff-armed, settling the baby into the water, and as the water touches the baby's skin the child starts to wail. But soon the soothing reality of it prevails. Large, warm hands stroke new skin. Warm water gently touches the top of the head and makes the thin hair sway like seagrass. Child and parent are tranquil.

In an attempt to comply with Federal regulations and get more "upwardly mobile" families into its 241 projects, the New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday a sharp increase in the maximum income a family could have and still be admitted to the city's low-rent public housing.

"Monsters," a pair of one-act plays co-starring James Coco and Robert Drivas, will be presented by Adela Holzer at the Astor Place Playhouse, 434 Lafayette Street, on March 10. The two plays are "The Transfiguration of Benno Blimpie" by Albert Innaurato and "Sideshow" by William Dews.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has asked leaders of Congressional tax committees temporarily to suspend new privacy provisions in the tax law that he has contended would impede investigation of political corruption and so-called white collar crimes.

Hoping to break a deadlock on New York City's debt problems, Mayor Beame proposed yesterday that the Municipal Assistance Corporation be given new power to go to court to force the city to balance its budget and adhere to strict fiscal controls in the years ahead.

A 19-year-old youth was fatally shot by two New York City policemen yesterday after he allegedly lunged at one of them with a knife when they surprised him on a Bronx roof where they had been sent to investigate reports of gunfire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 White House sources said tonight that Howard Samuels, former head of the New York's Off Track Betting Commission, and Jay Solomon, a shopping center developer in Tennessee, were the only two persons being considered by President Carter to head the General Services Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission today ordered two big credit card companies, an oil company and two major department store chains to refund more than $3 million to consumers who have overpaid their bills.

President Carter, in messages to the leaders of Britain and France, has reaffirmed the decision of the previous Administration authorizing a 16-month test of Concorde landings in Washington and New York City. But the President's press secretary said yesterday that Mr. Carter still thought the authorization had been a "mistake" and that the President had said in his messages that he "cannot direct" authorities in New York as to what decisions they should make.

PHOENIX, Feb. 16 (UPI) Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, appeared voluntarily before a grand jury today to contradict a report that he wanted to raise "havoc" on a Navajo Indian reservation.
WASHINGTON In an era of minicomputers and multinational conglomerates, the individual inventor might be assumed to be a relic of a simpler time.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 Governor Carey asked the Legislature today to lift its 88year-old ban on drilling for natural gas under Lake Erie.

SOURCE AND SAFARI Gail Rubin's new collection of 42 color photographs of wildlife from Biblical times, now on view through April 24 at the Jewish Museum, is the result of a one-woman camera trek across Israel, with the Hebrew Bible as a reference guidebook.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, Feb. 17 (UPI) Princess Vibhavadi Rangsit of Thailand insisted that her helicopter pick up two wounded policemen in a guerrilla area and was killed by Communist groundfire, the police said today.

Eve Merriam, poet and teacher, had long wanted to write a feminist play, and having found role reversal to be a useful device in her feminist theory classes, she decided to use the device in her revue, "The Club." In that "musical diversion," now at the Circle in the Square Downtown, four Victorian gentlemen spend an evening at their for-men-only club, talking and singing of women.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 16 (AP) Negotiators for the American Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers have reached a tentative settlement less beneficial to workers than agreements the union made earlier with Ford, Chrysler and General Motors.

A new series called "Y New Music" devoted interestingly if somewhat idiosyncratically to music for pianos and percussion presented the second of two concerts Tuesday night at the 92d Street Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 16 The leadership of Al Fatah, the major Palestinian guerrilla group, today blamed "erroneous behavior and contemptible practices" by splinter groups within the Palestinian ranks for fighting between Syrian troops and Palestinian elements near refugee camps here last week.

What if grinning strangers kept walking up to you on the street and saying your first name over and over like it was the title of a hit musical that has run too long to be permitted to close? So, sympathize with Bella.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill, Feb. 16 (UPI) Chicago Democrat, Thomas Hynes, was elected president of the Illinois Senate early today on the l86th ballot, ending a bitter six-week fight.

Joe Ely, a country-rocker from Lubbock, Tex., who's at the new Lone Star Cafe through Saturday, is a pleasant enough performer. If one encountered him and his amiable five-piece band in a Texas club, one could appreciate them as a high-class bar band. Mr. Ely looks rather like Arlo Guthrie, and he spins out his repertory including many originals of western swing, rockabilly and quasi-poetic laments in steady succession.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Despite efforts to prevent or reverse its ratification, the Equal Rights Amendment to give women constitutional protection against discrimination appears to be progressing slowly.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 At a raucous sometimes screaming session of Parliament, Israel's major opposition political party attempted today to capitalize on a scandal involving the ruling Labor Party and to win approval of a motion ordering an inquiry into the Labor Party's finances.

There are three major inhibitions on the Carter Administration's effort to stimulate the economy enough to cure unemployment. The first is fear of reigniting inflation. Consumer prices have slowed down from the double-digit ...

"After all the depressing news this winter about fuel shortages, inflation and other effects of the cold weather, stock buyers may need an external spark to stimulate them," Newton D. Zinder, an analyst at E.F. Hutton Company, said yesterday morning. "Perhaps American Telephone directors will help at their dividend meeting today."
RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 16 (AP) All but three of the Cleveland Barons were paid their overdue salaries today, Harry Howell, acting general manager of the National Hockey League team, reported.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 16 Mark Twain, who described his 1885 visit to Vassar as "ghastly," has just become the pride of the old college.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 The Falstaff Brewing Corporation, based in San Francisco, was charged today by a Federal grand jury with conspiring with a New Orleans brewery and a beer industry lobbyist to use a $30,000 bribe to obtain the passage in 1974 of a Louisiana law that has saved the two companies $900,000.

With the plant boom, everybody and his uncle in the South began growing plants. All that was needed was an old garage with the roof torn off and redubbed a greenhouse. The market is now flooded with contaminated plants from undetermined sources. Here is some advice for the prospective plant buyer:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The House Ways and Means Committee, in a drafting session on the tax aspects of President Carter's economic stimulus package, voted today to cut off a proposed tax rebate to those earning a gross income of more than $30,000 a year and to try to reach more poor families with the money.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 (AP) Attorney General Griffin B. Bell says that he will increase efforts to prevent aliens from entering, the United States illegally.

A rubber match between Notre Dame and Manhattan, teams that have been up and down, is the feature of tonight's college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. In the first game, which begins at 7 P.M., struggling Fordham plays Lafayette.
The F.B.I. has admitted illegally placing a listening device in the offices of a New Jersey organized crime figure, Simone DeCavalcante, in the mid-1960's, it was disclosed yesterday in Washington.
SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Feb. 17 (AP) Louise Yim, a legislator, educator, and women's movement leader, died here today. She was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) An American scientist and a European scientist are to fly in orbit together when the first Spacelab is launched in 1980, the National Aeronautics Space Administration said today.

The continued snow shortages in most of the West's high-mountain country caused plans yesterday for the World Cup events scheduled next month for Sun Valley, Idaho, and Heavenly Valley, Calif., to be altered.
DENVER, Feb. 16 (AP) Bobby Jones hit nine of 10 field-goal attempts, and finished with 23 points tonight as the Denver Nuggets crushed the New York Nets, 116-102.

Gerald H. Trautman, chairman of the Greyhound Corporation, has threatened to abandon his company's listing on the New York Stock Exchange, saying, "I don't feel the exchange should get into the internal affairs of a corporation."

The United States has always placed high value on local control of schools, and nowhere is this tradition more visible than in its method of supporting public elementary and secondary schools. The basic means of raising school funds is the local community's principal source of revenue for all purposes: the property tax.

The New York Jets burned another bridge behind them and advanced closer to New Jersey yesterday when the National Football League rejected the "compromise offer" of the Mets on staying in Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) New claims for unemployment insurance benefits for the week that ended Feb. 5 rose to the highest number in nearly two years because of heavy layoffs caused by the severe winter weather and fuel shortages, the Labor Department reported today.

United Airlines branded as "dangerous" and "potentially devastating" yesterday an American Airlines proposal for new discount fares between New York and California that would lower the price of a round-trip ticket from $412 to $227 if booked a month in advance.

TRENTON, Feb. 16 An insurance industry spokesman told a legislative committee today that an important segment of the industry believed a competitive state-operated insurance fund might be needed to prevent New Jersey's auto insurance system from collapsing.

After the first two weeks of its scheduled eight weeks, the series of programs at Michael's Pub based on Alec Wilder's radio series, "The American Popular Song," which, in turn, was based on Mr. Wilder's book of the same title, has dropped the trimmings of the radio production the between-song discussions of songwriters and songs and is concentrating on the songs themselves.

Reports of continued unsatisfactory weather conditions in the growing areas of the country as well as improved export business sent grain and soybean futures prices up again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Specific goals for the hiring and promoting of women by the National Broadcasting Company were included in a $2 million agreement that was presented in court yesterday as a proposed settlement of a sex discrimination suit by women employees of NBC.

Mayor Beame said for the first time yesterday that rent control and New York City's other rent regulations had apparently contributed to the decline in value of the city's apartment buildings, but at the same time he reiterated his support for strict regulation of the rents of all apartments.

VIENNA, Feb. 16 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that an evolutionary process was going on in the Palestine Liberation Organization that might eventually lead to a "smaller solution" in the Middle East than the one hard-line Palestinians were still advocating.

The controversial $1.6 billion Westway project in Manhattan was branded "environmentally unsatisfactory" yesterday by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. The proposal has been approved by the Secretaries of Transportation in both the Ford and Carter Administrations.

An indictment against a youth, who reportedly was in a group that allegedly invaded and damaged a black family's home on Staten Island Aug. 16 was dismissed Tuesday by Judge Theodore Barlow in the State Supreme Cour, in Staten Island.

J. Henry Smith, New York City's Human Resources Administrator, charged yesterday that Governor Carey's administration would "subvert" Congressional intent by withholding $14 million in Federal day-care money that the city expected to get under a bill signed by President Gerald R. Ford last summer.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 16 Earlier this week, President Idi Amin of Uganda accused President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania of involvement in an attempt to topple the regime of the Uganda strongman.
A dividend increase by American Telephone and Telegraph gave the stock market a lift yesterday. Prices made a broad advance in accelerated trading.

A class action lawsuit charging that the International Paper Company knowingly withheld pessimistic earnings forecasts while reporting markedly improved profits was brushed off by International Paper as "just another lawsuit."

DETROIT, Feb. 15 Had it not been such a bizarre incident, the fatal shooting of 45-year-old Bettye McCaster might have been recorded on the police blotter here as just another chapter in the nation's tragic story of violence and crime.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 16 Mark Twain, who described his 1885 visit to Vassar as "ghastly," has just become the pride of the old college.
MOSCOW, Feb. 16 (AP) Isaak Y. Boleslavsky, a chess grandmaster and journalist, has died after a short illness, the newspaper Sovetsky Sport reported today. He was 58.

MADRID, Feb. 16 Political Madrid is back on its feet and buzzing. The liberation of a general and a right-wing former Justice Minister as bizarre as their original kidnappings has lifted a roadblock from Spain's incipient democracy. Political wheeling and dealing is back in fashion.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) Judge Marcus Anwyl-Davies ordered a woman reporter out of his court here today for wearing trousers.

John F. Dowd, chief editorial counsel for Time Inc. for 28 years until his retirement in 1973, died Tuesday in Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, after suffering from heart disease. He lived in Plymouth, N.H., and was 60 years old.
John F. O'Leary, Federal Energy Administrator, told the House energy and power subcommittee yesterday that the strategic oil reserve program is "an embargo insurance policy for America."

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 16 Reruns of such network series as "Hawaii Five-O" and "The Rookies" are being sold to local stations in heavily edited forms, with most of the more violent sequences deleted. "The Rookies," in fact, has lent itself to such editing that the programs, which had been an hour in length when they played on ABC, have been compressed into half-hour shows for syndication.

Working with the knowledge that 60 percent of airline pleasure travelers are business travelers on their days off, United Airlines is for the first time combining its business and vacation travel advertising campaigns in an $11.5 million summer effort with a little kicker.
The Anaconda Company became the second aluminum producer to announce production cutbacks in the Pacific Northwest because of the growing drought conditions in the area.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 16 The jury in the Joanne Chesimard murder trial listened today to state police radio-tapes calling for patrol cars to help in the impounding of a white Pontiac on the New Jersey Turnpike that the state says was the vehicle used by the killers of Trooper Werner Foerster in May 1973.
When Frances Smith returned to her Harlem apartment after a week in the hospital last month, she found that a pipe had burst in a vacant apartment above her.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that S.D. Leidesdorf, a large national accounting firm, ineptly failed to uncover fraud by a shipping-company client that collapsed in 1972.

Beginning today, in a series of dives that call to mind a Jules Verne adventure, scientists will descend 9,200 feet below the surface of the Pacific Ocean to explore and sample eruptions of superheated, metal-rich water from the sea floor.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 16 In a bid for a third term, Mayor Paul Soglin of Madison placed second in a primary election yesterday, receiving less than 31 percent of the vote while a younger, conservative candidate received 39 percent. Four other candidates were eliminated.

Jules G. Haft, a financier and philanthropist who was a partner and vice president of Robb, Peck, McCooey Company Inc., trading specialists on the New York Stock Exchange, died Tuesday night at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 78 years old.

OTTAWA, Feb. 16 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Government, facing public pressure to control inflation and stimulate employment, today announced spending estimates that promised to hold official expenditures in the next fiscal year to the lowest rate of increase in several years.
BOGOTA, Colombia As a major coffee exporter, Colombia has proposed a plan that could, if widely accepted, prevent further coffee price increases and perhaps reduce prices gradually.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The Federal crisis of a new farm program like one now before the Senate could be "substantial," running into several billions of dollars, a study by the Congressional Budget Office said today.
"We were sitting on a powder keg here in Red Bank when Drew came to town in 1971 to represent a black famiy that was suing the town for alleged racial harassment," attorney Martin Barger recalled.

WBAI-FM's management, which last Friday took the station off the air to foil a takeover by the staff, yesterday disconnected the station's business telephones as staff and management remained at odds over union recognition and future programming.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) As many as 38,000 members of the armed services are drawing food stamps and thousands more would be eligible for the aid if they were not moonlighting or did not have working wives, a Pentagon study says.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 (UPI) Guy Lafleur's second goal of the game with 6:44 gone in the third period gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-4 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

Hoping to break a deadlock on New York City's debt problems, Mayor Beame proposed yesterday that the Municipal Assistance Corporation be given new power to go to court to force the city to balance its budget and adhere to strict fiscal controls in the years ahead.
The president of the New York Board of Rabbis said yesterday that the city "stands practically paralyzed in the face of rampant criminality on the streets, in subways and in schools."

DETROIT, Feb. 16 American auto production is expected to total 198,246 units this week, an increase of 22.3 percent from last week's 162,114, according to the trade paper Automotive News. It said that output would be 11.2 percent ahead of the 178,776 cars built in the year-earlier level.

The Madison Quartet was formerly named the Amici Quartet, but the change does not mean its members are any less friendly to one another these days. The string group, which gave a concert Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, takes its new name from Madison County, N.Y., where Colgate University is situated. The Madison is a quartet-in-residence at the school, once known as Madison College.

Twenty-one elevator repairmen at city housing projects who allegedly billed the city for overtime averaging $50 a day while they were out fishing, at race tracks, in bars or just doing nothing, were indicted yesterday by a Kings County grand jury on forgery and other charges.
Richard Harkness, an important personality in the formative years of NBC-TV's news coverage, died yesterday at his winter home in Naples, Fla. He was 70 years old.
A would-be robber was thwarted at a Brooklyn bank yesterday when the teller told him she couldn't decipher his handwriting.

The World Trade Center has offered to rent space to the New York Stock Exchange to accommodate all or part of its operations, industry sources disclosed yesterday. A similar offer had been made to the American Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Lifetime security a guaranteed job and a guaranteed income for life would seem to be an audacious concept for an American worker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) Two Washington-area music promoters were ordered today to testify at a public hearing on "payola," a form of broadcastingindustry bribery that the Government began investigating in 1964.

FISHERS ISLAND, L.I. To Francis Doyen, Town Justice and the local Mobil Oil purveyor, to Tony Marshall, owner of the Bouton Services Construction Company, and to Henry Walsh, owner of Fisher Island's only food store, it doesn't make sense that a pretty, easy-paced and virtually crime-free community should be hurting for enough citizens to keep the place going.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) President Carter's chief energy adviser, James R. Schlesinger, told Congress today that passage of a Federal strip mining reclamation law was "a prerequisite" to a national energy policy making greater use of coal.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 16 Westchester County Executive Alfred B. DelBello signed an agreement today with Pan American World Airways to run the county-owned airport under a management arrangement thought to be unique among domestic airports.

COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Feb. 16 The state of emergency under which Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike ruled since March 1971 lapsed today as a result of last week's recessing of Parliament. By law, the President must proclaim a renewal of the emergency each month and then have it announced in Parliament.

A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York ruled yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange cannot be sued under Federal securities laws by either limited partners or subordinated lenders of brokerage firms. It did not rule on whether the exchange might be sued by those who buy stock in publicly traded brokerage firms.

LANCELOT, By Walker Percy, 257 pages. Farrar, Straus Giroux, $8.95. In Walker Percy's fourth novel, "Lancelot," a Southern gentleman confronts the decadence of America in the 1970's and is driven nearly insane by it.
The van with out-of-state license plates came to a halt in front of Green Pastures, a popular plant store at 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. A young man bounced out and into the store.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that until the Palestine Liberation Organization revised its national charter to recognize Israel's right to exist it had no basis for participation in a conference on the Middle East.

Alwin Nikolais's "Tower," which was presented Tuesday evening at the Beacon Theater in Program C as part of the joint season with Murray Louis, started out life as part of a full-length work, "Vaudeville of the Elements." But it has existed so long as a separate entity that one despairs of ever seeing, the total work again. It is a dance in which the human race gets a cool going over from the choreographer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Airline passengers are complaining in record numbers to the Civil Aeronautics Board about delayed flights baggage handling, overbookings and other shortcomings in service.

Rosalynn Carter agreed yesterday to be a patron of the Marion Anderson salute, to be held Feb. 27, the contralto's 75th birthday, at Carnegie Hall. Mrs. Carter will sit with Miss Anderson in her box during the benefit concert, sponsored by Young Audiences, a nonprofit organization devoted to introducing millions of young people each year in classical music, theater and dance. Featured in the concert will be Leontyne Price, Clamma Dale and Shirley Verrett.
Abraham Dickenstein, founder and past president of the Ampal-American Israel Corporation, died Wednesday in his home in Tel Aviv. He was 76 years old.

Dr. David Jay Bachrach, a past president of the New York Society of Osteopathic Physicians and Surgeons and the New York State Osteopathic Society, died Tuesday in Leroy Hospital after a short illness. He Iived at 245 East 63d Street, and was 73 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) Consumers were cautioned today that 19,000 cases of pretzels, some distributed nationwide, are sprinkled with lye crystals that can burn the tongue, mouth and throat.

WESTPORT, Conn. From the outside, the Saugatuck Congregational Church stands like the glistening white, steepled centerpiece of so many other New England towns. Unlike so many other churches that bustle for a few hours on Sunday and spend the rest of the week in dignified repose, the Westport church is alive round the clock.

VIENNA, Feb. 16 (Reuters Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations today criticized Czechoslovak police for ordering a New York Times correspondent off a Vienna-bound train and forcing him to carry his luggage two miles into Austria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Overriding the objections of its chairman, the House Select Committee on Assassinations adjourned today without discussing what action should be taken regarding its controversial general counsel, Richard A. Sprague.

PORT STANLEY, Falkland Islands, Feb. 16 (AP) A British official arrived today to consult with 1,900 hardy British settlers over their future and that of the wind-swept islands they inhabit in the South Atlantic.

MILWAUKEE A great deal of confusion exists in the public mind regarding the natural-gas shortage and the price increase approved by the Federal Power Commission, now being contested in the courts. For clarification, let us consider a few fundamental facts.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 16 (AP) Diomedes Olivo, a former major league relief pitcher, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Santo Domingo Hospital center. He was 56 years old.

COTABATO, Philippines, Feb. 16 Watchful by day, tense at night and anxious about the future, the Moslems and Christians of the most troubled region of the Philippines live under a cease-fire that the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos tells them will be turned into lasting peace. They have their doubts.

Charging widespread irregularities in the operations of a Bronx drug treatment program, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin announced yesterday that he was halting immediately ail city payments to the Hispanic Association for a Drug Free Society, also known as SERA.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 (UPI) President Jorge Rafael Videla has told high military officers that the Government plans a gradual return to democracy in Argentina starting next year, press reports said today.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 16 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today explicitly recognized the existence of the European Common Market as negotiations opened on a fisheries agreement.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 Last night, the chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and two utility chiefs forsook their customary polished circles for a drab, smallish courtroom here and a judge "tired of listening to lawyers."
ALBANY, Feb. 16 Women who are beaten by their husbands and other victims of domestic violence would be given greater legal protection under terms of bills introduced today in the Legislature.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 Had it not been such a bizarre incident, the fatal shooting of 45-year-old Bettye McCaster might have been recorded on the police blotter here as just another chapter in the nation's tragic story of violence and crime.

In the latest of a record number of favorable dividend actions this year, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday raised its quarterly dividend by 10 cents to $1.05 a share, or $4.20 a share on an annualized basis.

BERKELEY, Calif. The deans of California's great state law schools are a sober lot, not given to hysteria. And so one listens when they say this: If a recent decision of the State Supreme Court stands, they will soon have virtually no black of Chicano students and the same will be true of California's medical and other professional schools.
The erratic Knicks and the more erratic Walt Frazier needed a lift in morale and the Chicago Bulls provided it last night at Madison Square Garden.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. Feb. 16 New Rochelle, beset by a troubled reputation even before Monday's rampage by a racist killer, decided last night to spend $10,000 to improve its image.

NEWARK, Feb. 16 A proposal that would reduce direct aid to state colleges and channel the money into tuition assistance to students was assailed today by Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutgers, the State University, who said the report had been written "as if it were about soybeans rather than about higher education."
TRW Inc., a widely diversified industrial company, reported yesterday increases of 16.4 percent in fourth-quarter profits.

The amount of "questionable transactions" allegedly made by the Boeing Aircraft Company in Japan was put at $16.7 million by Hiroichi Sakai, a member of the Clean Government Party, according to a United Press International report from Tokyo.

Mary Beame was among the women who applauded the introduction of Gucci's first beachwear collection at a luncheon at the St. Regis yesterday, though she didn't really think she'd try to get into the minimal bikini. She didn't have to. The Gucci collection of swimsuits includes some perfectly covered one-piece maillots, which are, after all, the newest things to be worn by the sea, lake or pool.
PARIS Female cooks in restaurants in France are successfully using their own national association to further the cause of women's haute cuisine.

LYNDHURST, Feb. 16 The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission intensified today its negotiations for ownership of a 12.3-acre junkyard in North Arlington where construction of a new garbage compactor is to start by April 15.

The trustees of Cornell University yesterday announced the election, as expected, of Dr. Frank H.T. Rhodes, a former academic vice president of the University of Michigan, as the university's ninth president.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Feb. 16 (AP) A mortar shell exploded outside a target area here in a training exercise today, wounding 15 officers and enlisted men, a spokesman at this Army base said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) E. Howard Hunt Jr., a former White House consultant and convicted Watergate conspirator, will be paroled from prison two days earlier than originally scheduled so he can make a court appearance next week, the Parole Commission said today.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16 (UPI) Carlos Pellicer, the poet and critic, died today at the age of 77. He had been taken to a hospital yesterday afternoon suffering from hypertension.

Further evidence of the slowdown in the nation's economic recovery caused by the recent cold wave was provided yesterday when the Commerce Department reported a record 27 percent decline in the number of new houses begun during January.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) The dollar firmed today against the strong European currencies of Switzerland and West Germany. The British pound kept up a modest improvement, and the price of gold moved up 25 cents an ounce.

ANCHORAGE, Feb. 16 Representatives of private investors in Saudi Arabia are discussing with an Alaskan Indian corporation, Koniag, Inc., the possibility of joint bidding in a Federal offshore oil and gas lease sale tentatively scheduled for November of this year, officers of Koniag said today.

TRENTON, Feb. 18 A bill that would ban the production and use in New Jersey of 16 chemicals identified as carcinogenic, or cancer-producing, encountered opposition today fron organized labor and industry, whose spokesmen said that such legislation would be disastrous to the state's economy.
MANILA, Feb. 18 Defense Secretary Juan Ponce Enrile said today that 1,441 persons were under detention in the Philippines for what he called charges of "crimes against national security."

Sutton of Manhattan, the first major black candidate for Mayor of New York City, opened his campaign headquarters yesterday in a grim corner of another borough Queens with the help of Rocco Barbella, better known as Rocky Graziano, the former middleweight boxing champion.

The Reliance Electric Company announced in Cleveland that its board had approved the acquisition of the Reliable Electric Company of Franklin Park, Ill., for 1.59 million shares of Reliance's common stock valued at about $48 million.

The Board of Education said yesterday that it was opposed to legislation that would compel the adoption of a "direct" school custodial system to replace the traditional arrangement, which has come under fire for alleged corruption, waste and nepotism.

A detective accused of extorting money from narcotics suspects was acquitted in State Supreme Court yesterday after a trial at which Deputy Mayor Nicholas Scoppetta and several well-known present and former Federal law enforcement officials testified as character witnesses for both sides.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 18(Reuters) Rotterdam, normally the world's busiest port, came to a standstill today when a strike spread to all dockworkers.

PRAGUE, Feb. 18 (Reuters) A Czechoslovak pop singer, Marta Kubisova, banned from singing here since 1970, today asked artists around the world to help stop "the process of suppression of civil rights" in Czechoslovakia.

AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 18 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that President Anwar el-Sadat's latest proposal for a Palestinian-Jordanian link had narrowed the gap between Israel and the Arab states for negotiations at Geneva. He added, however, that "major differences" remained.

St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Bartley Galvin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Don Thaddeus Galvin Jr., to Robert Flinn Ottaway, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Palmer Ottaway. Both families are of Grosse Pointe Farms.

The Aztecs sacrificed human beings atop their sacred pyramids not simply for religious reasons but because they had to eat people to obtain protein needed in their diet, a New York anthropologist has suggested.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Nearly a month after the departure of Henry A. Kissinger the State Department remains in the throes of uncertainty, marked by a rapid turnover of personnel and a reassessment of key policy issues but also by a mood of buoyancy, in the Foreign Service, which sees evidence of open debate in the hierarchy for the first time in years.

The 1977 Festival of ExperimentalPersonal Films by Women, coordinated by Sylvianna Goldsmith, has opened at the Women's Interart Center, 549 West 52d Street, and will run through Feb. 27. Under direct orders from Harold L. Fisher, acting chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's police chief, Sanford D. Garelik, yesterday redeployed 108 additional policemen to train and station patrols to help curb a recent upsurge in subway crime.

LOS ANGELES Over millions of years, huge quantities of organic matter were created in the Rocky Mountains, locked in as a rock-hard substance called oil shale. Heat this rock to 900 degrees Fahrenheit and these organics produce oil comparable to imported and domestic crude oil. In Colorado, Utah and Wyoming there are nearly two trillion barrels of shale oil in place. It is the largest potential source of recoverable oil in the world.

They appeared together Thursday evening at the New York State Theater.

SAN FRANCISCO The San Francisco Ballet is the oldest extant classic ballet company in the United States, having been originally formed by William Christensen in 1937. William's brother, Lew Christensen, became director of the company in 1951 and in 1973 he was joined by Michael Smuin as associate director. Today both Lew Christensen and Michael Smuin, his former pupil, are named as joint directors.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, says it may begin selling a solarpowered hot water heating system for homes next year.

AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 18 The Government of Jordan reacted with indignation tonight to the report published in Washington today that King Hussein had secretly received millions of dollars in the last 20 years from the Central Intelligence Agency.
Wheat futures rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, with heavy buying spurring prices near the close.

Anthony T. Ulasewicz, the retired New York City police officer who worked as a confidential investigator for former President Richard M. Nixon, was sentenced yesterday to one year of unsupervised probation for filing false income tax returns for the years 1971 and 1972.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Administration stoutly defended President Carter's letter to Andrei D. Sakharov today in the face of Soviet warnings that official American expressions of sympathy and support for Russian dissidents could damage relations between Moscow and Washington.

Donna E. Shalala, treasurer of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, is expected to be nominated as an assistant secretary for the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, it was learned yesterday.

TOKYO, Feb. 18 (AP) The United States has notified Japan that its fishing quota in the 200-mile United States fishery zones has been set at 1,190,960 tons for 1977, the Fisheries Agency said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) President Carter today withdrew the nomination of Malcolm Toon, a career diplomat, to be ambassador to the Soviet Union, a post Mr. Toon now occupies under a temporary appointment.

VIENNA, Feb. 18 For Christa Waldheim, younger daughter of the United Nations Secretary General, it was a coming-out party so Old World as to seem anachronistic.
"When you're trading, so many things enter into it," said Robert J. Fraiman as he tried to convey what it's like for a specialist on the busy floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

The Aztecs sacrificed human beings atop their sacred pyramids not simply for religious reasons but because they had to eat people to obtain protein needed in their diet, a New York anthropologist has suggested.
Swift and Company, the meat packing and processing unit of Esmark Inc., announced yesterday that it would close five of its meat plants on Aug. 18 because of poor earnings.

MORRISTOWN, Feb. 18 Officials who govern the state's 21 counties plan a reorganization of their association. Leanna Brown, the former director of the Morris County Board of Chosen Freeholders, disclosed today.

Rabbi and Mrs. Irving Koslawe of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shari Ann Koslowe, to Jack Dweck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Dweck of Brooklyn. The couple plan to be married on June 5.

STUDENTS call Mercy College in Yonkers "the asphalt campus" or the shopping center college." Tucked into a corner of the upper mall at Cross County Shopping Center, the college is at the heart of a promoter's paradise a 71.4 acre commercial complex at the hub of suburban Westchester County with 80 retail stores and 5,400 free parking spaces.

Oliver Smith has had such a dream for the Manhattan Center, which I think still could be that ideal: a theater de- voted to dance and of the proper opera house proportions.

Belgium is observing through commemoratives and countless other ways the 400th anniversary of the birth of the great Flemish artist, Peter Paul Rubens. With other countries joining in, and many more to come, Rubens Year 1977 will be a prime occasion for collectors.

Metropolitan Orestes P. Chornock of the Carpatho-Russian Greek Catholic Diocese in the United States, who was pastor of the St. John's Greek Catholic Church in Bridgeport, Conn., died Thursday morning at the Bridgeport Hospital after a long illness. He was 93 years old.

MICHAEL KAHN was pleased, but not content. The New Jersey Drama Critics had cited him as best director for his staging of "The Heiress" at the McCarter Theater in Princeton. Six years ago Winthrop Faulkner, a Washington, D.C., architect, and his wife, Jeanne, an interior designer, bought a 200-year-old stone barn near Middleburg, Va. Because it was huge 80 feet long and 40 feet wide they decided to convert only half of it into living quarters, a weekend retreat, leaving the rest unfinished. That turned out to be a wise decision, because in the time they have owned it, heating costs have skyrocketed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 While no public announcement has been made, confidential sources disclosed this week that the Howard Hughes Medical Institute has lost a seven-year struggle to retain a favorable status under the 1969 Federal law that reformed tax rules for foundations.
BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP) Enrollments at New England colleges are on the decline for the first time since the record-keeping was started in 1960.

Lynda Ann O'Donnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. O'Donnell of Guilford, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. George's Roman Catholic Church, to Jeffrey Burke Carroll, son of Sidney Burke Carroll of New York and Thomas S. Carroll of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Daniel McSheffrey performed the ceremony.
MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Feb.19 (AP) Maurice Robinson scored 21 points as West Virginia upset Notre Dame, 8l-68, today. The smaller Mountaineers (15-9) gained an early lead and never trailed in the game.

WITH ONE EYE on Greenwich's affluent residents, another on the community's rapidly increasing transient work force and a hand extended in help to the female population, the Connecticut Women's Bank is preparing to open its doors.
AFTER 20 years on the scarred battlefield of the proposed Route 7 Expressway between Norwalk and Danbury, the environmentalists appear at last to be yielding ground to the highway builders.
THE days have lengthened sufficiently now for New Jersey's indoor-outdoor gardeners to get some houseplant chores out of the way before it's time to turn energies toward the outdoors.

New York State's Public Service Commission has taken an important step toward ending telephone company domination over the sale of equipment. As long as it meets certain standards, customers should be able to buy and install their own apparatus instead of, as is usually the case, renting from their phone company, the commission said last week.

Though 65 is the age when most business executives retire, shipping magnates usually go on forever. So it seemed noteworthy when C.Y. Tung, the shipowner from Hong Kong, declared recently that 43 years in the business is enough.

A near-capacity audience of almost 4,000 operagoers, expecting the curtain to rise on Poulenc's "Dialogues of the Carmelites" were routed from the Metropolitan Opera last night by the acrid fumes of a tear gas canister set off in the house while the musicians were tuning up.

IT is at once disturbing and heartening to write about the Long Island Professional Artists Guild exhibition on view at the Union Carbide Building in New York City. And it would perhaps be best to rid ourselves of the disturbances immediately, for in that way we can end on an upbeat note.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 In each of the six pro golf tournaments played thus far this season, the winner was either the leader or co-leader at the end of the third round. If that pattern holds up in the finale of the 51st Los Angeles open tomorrow, Tom Purtzer will win.

THE AMERICAN SHAKESPEARE Theater at Stratford, which has in recent years been trying to change its status as a New York summer outpost into one that has thrown in altogether with its home state, has declared a long intermission that will, if all goes well, end next year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered tuna bolts to submit to boarding for investigations of whether they used forbidden fishing methods that allegedly kill a large number of porpoises.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) Charles O. Finley, the Oakland A's owner, sold a relief pitcher, Paul Lindblad, to the Texas Rangers today for $400,000 and set up another confrontation with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

BLUE POINT THE Ursuline Convent here was built same 40 years ago as a small house for teen-aged girls who had decided to devote their lives to the service of the church. Today the convent is seeking to care for nuns at the end of that life of service.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 19 The body of the Anglican Archbishop of Uganda was secretly buried by Uganda authorities yesterday, forcing the cancellation of funeral services that had been scheduled for tomorrow.

Four workers at a New Rochelle moving company were murdered last week by a disgruntled employee who then killed a policeman during a siege of the plant; the siege ended after the killer took his own life. The episode emphasized anew the impossibility of identifying such potential murderers despite the clues they present.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 The sport in which one can compete at the highest levels regardless of age is yacht racing. The best example would be George Van, a pixie from Detroit who happens to be 73, although one could never suspect it, and whose skills include swimming, socializing and steering.

WHILE other Princefonians were enjoying the pastoral pursuits of summer, Donald Warnock was redecorating and stocking the Princeton Gourmet, a store that has been in business locally for 23 years and one that he bought six months ago.
The political spillover from the rancorous Co-op. City strike poses the possibility, according to some politicians, that the Liberal Party might win its first seat ever in State Assembly.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 19 An agreement signed Wednesday in Federal Court in Manhattan between White Plains officials and preservationists has set March 18 for the start of demolition of this city's historic courthouse.

Snow-making machines, propelled by jet engines, smother some of her words. She repeats that she has lived in Simsbury, Conn., for seven years and she is lonely. Her neighbors want to talk about plants and homes, she wants to talk about politics and poetry.

Andres Segovia gave his only New York recital of the season on Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall. The hall was filled; the stage in back of him held as many people as the law allows.

Thanks to "The Moviegoer," "The Last Gentleman" and "Love in the Ruins," readers have come to expect a good deal of Walker Percy. His virtues, in this age of mostly terrible fiction, are notable. Though he cares about plot and character, making fic-, tions that easily translate into movies, he is a serious, even moderately philosophical novelist not at all ashamed of his seriousness.

BOHEMIA, N.Y., Feb. 19 Scattered around the country are dozens of school districts a few of them here in eastern Long Island that exemplify a curious phenomenon. Their enrollments are continuing to expand while most of the school systems around them are retrenching.

The correct answer, according to a preliminary report of the 1974 National Census of Agriculture, just released, is any one of these figures. It all depends on which defenition of a farm is used, and there are three definitions in the census report.

The word "contemporary" in his subtitle refers to poetry published since about 1959: older poems are invoked to illustrate some of the traditions in which poetry has been written during the past twenty years or so.

Collectors of British things are about to experience something like our Bicentennial. Great Britain is marking the Jubilee Year celebrating the accession of Queen Elizabeth II to the throne. On Feb. 2, 1952, while Elizabeth and Prince Philip were deep in the African bush country on a tour, she was notified of the death of her father, George VI.

Allbritton, the millionaire banker from Texas who bought control of the financially troubled Washington Star for about $28 million in 1974, reappeared on the newspaper's masthead in Sunday's editions after an unexplained absence of two weeks but as chairman of the board rather than publisher.

Dr. and Mrs. Robert George Hicks of Greenwich and New Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Patricia Hicks, to Kevin Joseph Kelleher, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Michael Kelleher of Ansonia, Conn. A June wedding is planned.
Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles is one of the most uncommon pitchers in baseball, but he suffers from the most common weakness in golf: the slice.

I AM a small Paterson employer who is struggling to overcome the never-ending profit threats to my business's survival. The current Blue Cross rate increase request should serve as a warning that this added burden will help to drive more small businesses like mine beyond the unprofitable margin into oblivion.

LONDON, Feb. 19 Anthony Crosland, the British Foreign Secretary, died before dawn today at the Radcliffe Infirmary in Oxford, where he had been taken after suffering a stroke last Sunday. He was 58 years old.
JESS J. PEARCE, the Dobbs Ferry village historian, was recalling growing up along the Hudson more than half a century ago:

FOR some 65,000 residents of Essex County, the postman is bringing a surprise. No it's not tax-rebate checks they're due in April but it is something that, at least for many of those living in 12 towns in the area, will be just as valuable.

The Consumer Price Index rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in January, double December's rise and the largest monthly increase since July 1975. Moreover, the impact on retail prices of the severe cold weather late last month has not yet been fully reflected in the statistics.

IN the film "All About Eve," a Hollywood-bound theater director defends his move by saying "Wherever there's magic and make believe and an audience there's Theater." He defines theater as encompassing everyone from the Lone Ranger to Sarah Bernhardt, and concludes with: "The theater's for everybodyyou included, but not exclusively so don't approve or disapprove. It may not be your theater, but it's theater for somebody, somewhere."
HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Feb. 19 People hereabouts are undoubtedly scratching their heads over the Great Carbon Tetrachloride Spill.

Ron Lesser says he's a gambling man. He operates movie houses in Mt. Kisco, Yorktown and Peekskill, N.Y., and books films for himself and several other theater-owners. Like his late father, he has been in the business all of his adult life.
Deborah Hayes Seaman and Christopper Leo Kuhn were married yester- day in the Westover School Chapel in Middlebury, Conn., by the Rev. John Gibson, an Episcopal priest.

Clark M. Clifford, President Carter's personal emissary, has begun consultations in Athens, Ankara and Nicosia seeking a solution to the conflict on Cyprus and an end to tensions between Greece and Turkey. Previous attempts by Washington to influence Greece and Turkey and their co-patriots on Cyprus have led to resentment in those countries and, despite signs of a new willingness among the disputants to compromise, Mr. Clifford's role will be difficult.

Kathleen Acheson Thompson, an associate editor with Scholastic Magazines Inc., and John Stuart McCurdy, an account supervisor with Richard K. Manoff Inc., advertising agency, were married yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The nation's labor unions have begun to make clear what they will ask from employers and from the Federal Government this year. Both sets of requests, and the responses they evoke, could have a substantial effect on the economy.
While the current group of pro football players awaits the details of the new pact with management to determine their degree of satisfaction, another contingent is expressing gratitude.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 19 The Tarrytown Board of Trustees has unanimously approved amendments to its zoning ordinance that would severely restrict the ability of the Unification Church, founded and headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, to build a university complex here.
This Thursday evening at 9:30 on Channel 13 Captain Jacques Ives Cousteau and his youngest son, Philippe, will launch the first of six half-hour specials docu- menting men's rape of the planet earth.

PACE PLEASANTVILLE, one of three Pace campuses Manhattan and White Plains are the other two is perhaps a microcosm of the post-Vietnam small college. The current student is more prone to be concerned with classwork than with spending time objecting to university or government actions.
Two of three local basketball teams achieved success yesterday in a college tripleheader at Madison Square Garden that attracted 13,697 fans.

"Ashanti to Zulu," which has been awarded the 1977 Caldecott Medal for excellence in illustration, is a large, colorfully illustrated book that strives "to introduce the reader to 26 African peoples by depicting a custom important to each." A single custom can hardly convey much that is meaningful about any culture, and in that sense the book is severely limited. Within those limitations, however, interesting facts abound.

MUZAFFARNAGAR, India The old man stroked his scraggly white beard thoughtfully as his friends, nodding agreement, pressed close around to hear his streetcorner pronouncement: "We can't let the Government get away with all this coercion in family planning. I'll vote for anyone who is against it."

WASHINGTON No one has ever voted for them, and their names, even in Washington's most-in circles, are not exactly on the tip of anyone's tongue. Working for Congress as the chief technicians of tax legislation, both Bernard (Bobby) Shapiro and Ward Hussey much prefer anonymity.

Today is a $13,100 day for members of Congress, Federal judges and other officials. This is the effective date of the first meaningful Federal pay raise since 1969. It is to be welcomed. High officials should not be left so unprotected against inflation that they must grope for outside income or abandon public service. The new raise is necessary and just.

Henry Kissinger's sale of his memoirs to Little, Brown for $2 million and of his television services to NBC for an estimated $1.5 million demonstrates once again that high public office can lead to instant wealth. Mr. Kissinger is not alone. Former Presidents Nixon and Ford are also engaged in book and television projects, while lesser figures in their and previous administrations have successfully capitalized on their years in office.

Mr. and Mrs. Earl Fleisig of Westbury, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Fleisig, to Roger Greene, son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray J. Greene of Riverdale, the Bronx. The couple plan to be married in April.
With each game, the National Basketball season is turning into a nightmare for the Knicks.
SAN DIEGO, Feb.19 The times were terrific but the races were even better at the San Diego Indoor Games last night on the famous fast track of the San Diego Sports Arena.
From Miami Stadium in Florida to Desert Sun Stadium in Yuma, Ariz., baseball training camps will begin rustling this week. And the big news this year is just that: They will begin rustling on time.

Q: How does one prevent mildew forming in the bathroom? Ours has a window which is kept open in the summer, and the room is heated in the winter, but we have ugly mildew in the grout and on any damp cloth used in the room. M.S., Scarsdale, N.Y.

Panama and the United States have resumed formal negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty that both sides want but are unlikely to agree upon quickly. The parties are still far apart on terms, and there are political factors in Panama and Washington that may mean delay even if the negotiators should reach agreement.

WAINGAPU, Indonesia, Feb. 13 On a hill overlooking the harbor of this town of grass-roofed huts and tin-topped shacks there stands a $2 million collection of buidings topped by a huge circular dish that sparkles in the noonday sun.

EVERY year Connecticut disposes of more than 100,000 tons of sewage sludge that, although it can serve as an excellent soil conditioner and fertilizer, is usually burned or buried.

One of my favorite events on baseball schedules is Old-Timers' Day. Many clubs hold theirs in connection with an event, like the 20th anniversary of winning a pennant.

One wishes CBS would move "Who's Who" to another hour or another night of the week and give it a chance to survive. On Tuesdays, in the 8 to 9 P.M. slot, it must compete with "Happy Days" and "Laverne and Shirley" on ABC, which is like Dennis the Menace com peting with Attila the Hun. The outcome is not in doubt.

Seedsmen know the way to a gardener's heart. The grow-from-seed geraniums they introduced a few years ago are a smashing success. With minimum effort the seeds take hold when started indoors and the plants grow quickly into magnificent size for the garden with beautiful, colorful flowers. Everyone who has tried them finds a special delight in raising their own geraniums from seed.

Three of the 10 best earned-run averages in the National League last year belonged to Tom Seaver, Jerry Koosman and Jon Matlack, and the best team average belonged to the New York Mets. But once that glittering fact is established, the tide creeps in.
