The way I see it, here is a man a father faced with those awful college tuition bills simply trying to make ends meet. I mean, Brendan Byrne has shown us the way, just as a Governor and first citizen of his state should.

It made no boasts of offering "the best" or "good quality"; for illustration, it had only a small stylized drawing of the scales of justice. The advertisement appeared only once, in a Sunday newspaper.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has proposed creating a Federal agency with authority to control the cost of hospital services, a leading factor in the nation's rapidly rising medical care bill. The proposal reflects the Administration's belief that cost control is a prerequisite for establishing a national health-care insurance system.

In the Tenants Voice office, a windowless room above a Kings Highway storefront in Brooklyn, Jackie Goldman, a reporter, is complaining about missing pencils, misspelled words and the heat. "It's too hot in here," she jokes. "Let's go on a rent strike!"

Doris Pinner, a freelance photographer, was married yesterday afternoon in Stamford, Conn., to Melvin A. Brenner. He is vice president of schedules and industry affairs for Trans World Airlines. As frigid temperatures began moving across much of the country again last week and threatened to deliver another body blow to the dwindling supplies of natural gas and other heating fuels, the heavy cost of the American energy crisis of 1977 was being toted up in the nation's capital and elsewhere.

BOSTON Not everyone dotes on Roman art. The girl is rare who capitulates on Valentine's Day before the gift of a lifesize marble bust of an unsmiling and noseless Imperial administrator. A Roman conjugal sarcophagus is undeniably a beautiful thing, with its evocation of embraces that con- tinue after death; but, once again, not everyone wants it about the house.

Brooklyn Tech took the Brooklyn title and Van Buren captured top honors for Queens yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League borough indoor track championships at the 102d Engineers Armory. Bronx and Manhattan schools will compete Friday at the same site.

The old wooden house once commanded much of the site; now it seems shunted aside for the new arrival. But while the two buildings are in one sense utterly different, they are in another way quite the same; the suburban corporate headquarters is really the country estate of our time.

Insulation may be good for America, but for homeowners, a dollar spent isn't always a penny saved. "Five hundred dollars and it didn't do a bit of good," said Ruth Spiro of Brooklyn about her family's efforts to warm an icy den by insulating the outside walls. "We really can't see any kind of improvement."

UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 20 The Knicks discovered a full-court press and the capabilities of their veterans this afternoon and buzzed past the Nets at the Coliseum, 100-80.

To help stimulate the economy and create jobs, President Carter is proposing to allocate $4 billion for public works the construction of new schools, sewers, roads and whatever else local governments would like from a Federal list of qualified projects. Madeline W. Einhorn, widow of Bernard W. Einhorn, who was a general partner in Kuhn, Loeb Company, was married yesterday afternoon to Cart Glick, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Neuberger Berman.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 20 (AP) Venezuelan officials denied emphatically today a report that President Carlos Andres Perez received payments from the United States Central Intelligence Agency while he was the Interior Minister.

Vance that prospects for a Middle East settlement this year were not good unless the United States was prepared to put pressure on Israel to make major concessions after the Israeli elections in May. One of the most complex international military problems that faces President Carter and his Secretary of Defense, Harold L. Brown, is the modernization and reorganization of the tactical nuclear weapons force committed to the North.

ROCKY FLATS, Colo., Feb. 20 On the barren Great Plains here today the Federal Government unveiled six little windmills straining at the knots of breeze sweeping from the Rockies in an experiment testing the thesis that, for some energy requirements, smaller may be better.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 New York State, with the sixth highest unemployment rate among the states, is receiving $55.8 million this quarter in special antirecession Federal funds to rank first in per-capita aid, according to an analysis of the national program released today.

DENVER, Feb. 20 Top officials of 18 Western states who came here today to meet with Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus on the drought expressed shock, anger and astonishment over the Administration's proposed plans to cut from the next Federal budget funds for 18 major water projects around the country.
ROME, Feb. 20 During the recent visit by Vice President Mondale, a State De partment official remarked that American policy toward Italy was basically unchanged under the Carter Administration.

GUTTENBURG, Feb. 20 The son of an 86-year-old widow led a demonstration today against a nursing, home to protest the shortage of Medicaid beds that is keeping his mother in a hospital weeks after she should have left.

Jan De Gaetani has been creating a good deal of excitement with her recitals this season at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. Saturday night she sang the last of her three concerts there, and one can only subscribe to the breathless accounts of the previous ones.

LONDON, Feb. 20 The House of Commons faces a significant procedural vote tomorrow on a bill to grant limited selfgovernment to Scotland and Wales, a proposal that has dismembered the parliamentary temper if not yet, as its critics fear, the United Kingdom.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) Most American families spend more than half their income on food and housing, including utilities, a study by two faculty members at the University of Kentucky has found.

ENUGU, Nigeria, Feb. 16 Biafra is only a distant memory. Seven years after its towns were overrun and its starving population fled panic-stricken into the jungle, the area occupied by the one-time rebel state of the Ibo people in eastern Nigeria is staging an economic comeback.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 20 James P. Falvey, the director of the Eltra Corporation and a former Deputy Assistant Secretary in the Defense Department, died yesterday here.

MIAMI, Feb. 20 Ondine, Huey Longs pale blue whale out of New York, sailed around the Lipton Cup course as swiftly as a stock car zooming around the speedway at Daytona and today was declared the overall winner of the 110-mile race which begun on Friday and ended here yesterday.

Col. Earl Henry Blaik, U.S.A. (Ret.), celebrated his 80th birthday last week, more than somewhat to his surprise. It wasn't the discovery that he was 80 that surprised him, but rather the fact that he celebrated at all, and especially the way he celebrated.

A group of eight Columbia and Dutchess County towns is giving serious consideration to a plan to take some of New York City's sewage sludge and turn it into a composted product for application to soil in parks and forests.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20 The Carter Administration has moved to speed up the Federal Government's long investigation into alleged malpractices in the huge Central States pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Team- sters.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 20 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, after receiving support for his mediation efforts from Saudi Arabia, arrived here today to learn that Syria doubts quick progress can be made toward a Middle East solution.

Alexis Weissenberg is a pianist of such relentless brilliance that his performance can hypnotize anyone who knows the keyboard and its problems. The Bulgarian-born virtuoso surmounts difficulties without seeming effort, even when the case under study is so fearsome a monster as Rachmaninoff's Concerto No. 3 in D minor, which he performed at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon with Michael Tilson Thomas and the Buffalo Philharmonic.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 20 While Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has been touring the Middle East, envoys have been sent to the area by France and the Soviet Union.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 In his fantasies Tom Purtzer figured he would win his first pro golf tournament by staging a rally. Today he had to manufacture a comeback situation. After blowing a three-shot lead he had held at the start of the final round, Purtzer fell one shot behind and then worked his way up through four ties and went on to win the Los Angeles open by one stroke over Lanny Wadkins.

INZELL, West Germany, Feb. 20 (AP) Eric Heiden, the teen-aged speedskater from Madison, Wis., and 20year-old Kim Kostron of St. Paul captured the overall championships today in the world junior competition. Each of them set world records in one or more events on the way to the titles.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 California officials are urging local communities to "think the unthinkable" to prepare for the possibility that terrorists or others might obtain nuclear weapons and use that threat for extortion.

PRINCETON, Feb. 20 About 75 placard-carrying demonstrators representing a coalition of New Jersey and Philadelphia organizations opposed to death-penalty legislation chanted and picketed yesterday for an hour and a half opposite Governor Byrne's home, Morven.

Pinchas Zukerman is the most amiable, sweet-tempered of violinists, one who seems incapable of making a strident tone or curving a phrase without a suavely elegant caress. His recital yesterday afternoon at Fisher Hall with Marc Neikrug at the piano consisted of music that mostly suited his temperament. It may have been a bit limited in mood and a shade somnolent here and there, but the sounds were never less than ravishingly pretty.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 (AP) The German Red Cross said today that it had raised about $475,000 in West Berlin to aid Americans suffering from this winter's bitter cold weather.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 21 The President of Venezuela has declared that a newspaper article linking him to alleged payments from the Central Intelligence Agency formed part of "a maneuver against Venezuela," and suggested that high American officials were behind the action.

YOUNG AND WILLING Daniel Adni, a 26-year-old Israeli, is tonight's pianist in the latest program of the Young Concert Artists series, in which the nonprofit, management unit introduces new classical talents to New York audiences. The program starts at 8 o'clock at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. near Lexington Avenue. Door admission is $2.50 and $3.50.

WINDHOEK, South-West Africa, Feb. 21 (UPI) About 200 Angolan villagers have fled to South-West Africa to escape new fighting between Angolan Government troops and guerrillas, an official in the border region said today.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 21 Henry Jordan, an all pro defensive tackle on five Green Bay Packer teams that won National Football League championships in the 1960's, died today at the Milwaukee Athletic Club. After a workout, he collapsed in a rest room. Oxygen and heart massage were administered, but he was pronounced dead at the scene. He was 42 years old.

After nearly a year's divisive struggle over who was going to head the Tenants Association of the St. Nicholas Houses a federally subsidized low-income development in Harlem Minnie Moore recently emerged victorious with 159 of the 300 votes cast, a total that exceeded the area's vote in the Democratic primary.

Dr. Ross Thalheimer, a psychologist who was executive director of the Community Guidance Service and founder also of the American Institute for Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis, died Sunday after suffering a heart attack at his home, 161 West 54th Street in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

VISALIA, Calif., Feb. 21 (AP) A gang trying to gain control of narcotics in central California was involved in the kidnapping of a man convalescing from open heart surgery, the authorities said today, adding that the gang may have kidnapped the wrong man.

The United States Tennis Association is seeking to buy the West Side Tennis Club in a twofold move: to end constant bickering over renewing the club's contract to conduct the annual Open championships and to facilitate plans for renovating West Side in expectation of drawing greater crowds to the tournament.

Donald M. Dowd, a radio announcer on the Don McNeill "Breakfast Club" from 1943 to 1955, died yesterday in Punta Gorda, Fla., where he had been living sinc his retirement from ABC in 1970. He was 72 years old.

BORDENTOWN, Feb. 21 Representative Robert A. Roe, Democrat of Wayne Township, announced his candidacy for Governor today by calling for an end to the state income tax and the convening of a state tax convention to come up with a replacement.

MIAMI, Feb. 21 An all-Spanish radio station here ceased broadcasting today on orders from the Federal Communications Commission. An effort will be made later this week in Congress to renew its license, temporarily at least.

Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut and United States Representative Frederick W. Richmond said yesterday that "bureaucratic bungling" by state and local governments had left 1.5 million eligible New Yorkers without food stamps and had deprived the state of up to $300 million a year in Federal financing.
George Van Gorder, retired board chairman of McKesson Robbins, Inc., died Sunday at the Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 81 years old and maintained homes in Sarasota and Bronxville, N.Y.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 21 "Roots" those cultural, familial, racial and social links to our personal pasts were very prominent here yesterday, during the fourth annual Oscar Micheaux Awards ceremony of the Black Film Makers Hall of Fame.

"Our body" says Dr. Samuel Dunkell, "is at all times a part of our own particular way of relating to the world." This is no less true in sleep, which turns each of us, as the author puts it into a pantomimist. It is not only in dreams that we act out our defenses and our desires, but in our sleep positions.

They are the most loving of adversaries: parents who smoke and their children who object. But they are also implacably unyielding, unless the parent renounces the habit or the child gives up in defeat. Usually, the confrontations result in a stand-off that leaves children upset and parents guilty but still smoking.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (UPI) The Democratic Socialists Organizing Committee adopted today a program calling for a guaranteed job for every American who wants to work.

A subcommittee of the House of Representatives will hold a two-day hearing next month on the Federal investigation of the teamsters' Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund, it was disclosed yesterday.

Leaders of the municipal employee unions yesterday rejected as "vague" and "unacceptable" Mayor Beame's proposal to strengthen the Municipal Assistance Corporation, but they said they were prepared to negotiate with both the Mayor and the banks on the means to return New York City to credit worthiness.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Feb. 21 "If you tell people here a hurricane is coming, they will tell you it won't hit Ocean Grove," said Ed Holl, the proprietor of Nagle'S Pharmacy. "Right or wrong, people feel very secure around here."

If both members of a partnership pass on the first round of bidding and the fourth player opens with one spade or any higher bid it is hardly ever right to come to life. Even when the action appears normal on the face of it, there is a considerable danger that it will backfire, giving the opponents information that they can make good use of.
Three New York City publications published investigative articles over the weekend on the rise and prominence of Carmine Galante within organized crime.

Even as Cyrus R. Vance, the United States Secretary of State, was introducing himself to Israeli leaders last week on the first leg of his Middle East tour, Israel's new Central Bank governor. Arnon Gafni, was doing the same around New York's financial community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Although New York led all other states in Federal aid received in the fiscal year 1976, it slipped from sixth to 10th place in per capita assistance, new figures from the Treasury Department showed today.

Two days ago, a top jockey at the Fair Grounds track in New Orleans agreed to accept a $2,000 fine and a suspension for using an illegal battery device to make a horse run faster in a Feb. 5 race there.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 21 The Indian Express, this country's largest newspaper, carried a front-page picture of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi the other day, as it had so many times in the last couple of years.

Members of Parliament indignantly urged the British Government yesterday to help Sarah Spencer Churchill, widow of Winston Churchill, pay her rent and other debts, "As the greatest servant the state has ever had," said John Stokes, a Conservative member "it seems incredible and quite disgraceful that Sir Winston's widow, at the age of over 90, should be in financial hardship.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 21 (UPI) The police today occupied the National Educational University campus, which the Government charged had become a center of propaganda for Maoist Communists and a clandestine arms depot.

A holiday crowd of 27,585 horse fanciers at Aqueduct saw Steve Cauthen emerge from a one-day "slump" yesterday, as he triumphed in the first, second and fourth races. Cauthen, who had nine mounts, also turned in a thirdplace showing in the fifth race.

HOUSTON, Feb. 21 America's natural gas shortage is fundamental, according to many experts in the industry and in government, and the resulting economic disruptions and personal hardship cannot be prevented in the next several years.
SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 21 (AP) The two rival candidates claimed victory today in El Salvador's presidential elections.

DENVER, Feb. 21 Politics, foreign policy and world trade could soon be disrupted by the drought that has hit the Western United States, speakers told a jammed session today at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 Proposals for reorganizing the state court system, due to be submitted to the voters in a referen dum next November, are embroiled in a partisan dispute in the Legislature that could nullify the whole package.

A 25-year-old man, reportedly annoyed at the throngs of pimps and prostitutes congregating in the hallway of his Harlem apartment building yesterday afternoon fatally shot one of the loiterers and wounded another, according to the police. The suspect was shot in the hip when he fired in the direction of two policemen, and they fired back at him.

LONDON, Feb. 21 Prime Minister James Callaghan tonight chose as Foreign Secretary David Owen, who at 38 is the youngest man to hold that position since Anthony Eden was appointed in 1935. Dr. Owen, who is a physician, has been serving as Minister of State in the Foreign Office, the No. 2 man there.
The American Numismatics Society has just received a collection of ancient coins that, to its delighted officials, is the closest thing to pennies from heaven $500,000 worth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 The Central Intelligence Agency apparently made use of friendly foreign intelligence services to help it obtain information about United States citizens traveling abroad, according to documents that the agency has declassified but not made public.
The pangs of birth are assailing the various regional councils formed to implement the new 200-mile fisheries legislation, which takes effect March 1.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 The Chrysler Corporation today reported net earnings of $119.2 million, or $1.98 a share, for the fourth quarter of 1976 more than triple the $34.9 million it earned during the same period in 1975.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 21 Rabbi Yisrael Alter, leader of the Gur sect of Hasidim, died in Jerusalem yesterday. He was 82 years old.
Dale B. White, a senior editor of U.S. News World Report, died yesterday of cancer in George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 59 years old and a resident of Oakton, Va.

The wife of Carlos Alberto Torres, the man being sought in connection with terrorist bombings that have occurred in New York and in other cities over the last three years, has disappeared, the police said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 A visit to the White House by Vladimir K. Bukovsky, the deported Soviet dissident, which had been scheduled for tomorrow, has been postponed until early next week, an Administration official said today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 21 (AP) Catholicos Khoren I has announced he will step down in May as spiritual leader of 600,000 members of the Armenian Orthodox Church in four Middle Eastern countries and the United States.

A cherry-topped birthday toast to George Washington was lifted yesterday at the Morris-Jumel Mansion, the general's 1776 headquarters in Washington Heights, and more than 500 Boy Scouts staged a ceremony at the scene of his 1789 Presidential inauguration at Federal Hall, 26 Wall Street.

In his 1977-1978 budget, Governor Carey asks for $27.3 million in grant money for the New York State Council on the Arts nearly $3 million less than he requested last year. This may be a disturbing portent for the future of the arts in New York State, but a graver one is a proposal tucked away in his budget.
MADRID, Feb. 21 As representative democracy dawns in Spain, the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church is urging its bishops and priests to stay out of politics.
Anna Kosof, WBAI-FM's station manager since last September, said she had been hired "to create change substantial change" and that that is what she intended to do.

The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange are "extremely close" to finding a formula that will permit them to merge, according to Wall Street sources. The sources added, however, that certain unresolved issues might delay the merger.

WESTFIELD, Feb. 21 "We feel that every child has a right to belong to someone out there," says Phyllis Gold, the founder of Spaulding for Children, a free adoption service for so-called "hard to place" children.

Radio City Music Hall reverberated to the sound of salsa for the first time on Sunday, and it seemed to be an ideal setting for the music. The hall's arsenal of effects the rising stage, strobe lights, mirrors insured visual interest, and the acoustics seemed almost perfect for the biting brass and chattering percussion of a typical salsa orchestra.

ATLANTA, Feb. 21 (UPI) Chief Justice H.E. Nichols, striving to "move the legal system of Georgia into the 20th century," said today that the State Supreme Court would experiment with allowing cameras and tape records in its chamber.
Jacob Holman, a former school principal and real-estate broker, died yesterday in his Manhattan home. He was 91 years old and lived at 285 Riverside Drive.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 21 Church groups here and abroad are understood to be seeking to maintain publicity about the three deaths in Uganda last week in the hope of spurring international protests or inquiries into allegations of mass murder by the Amin regime.

MARICOPA, Calif., Feb. 18 Jerry Cappello looked around his 1,500 acres of farmland here in the southern end of the state's huge Central Valley and said he would be able to plant only 350 acres this year. Like other farmers in the area, he owns land that is among the richest in the world when it is properly irrigated but that is now drying up because of a 17-month-long drought.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 21 At the end of his Middle East mission, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that although Arabs and Israelis had expressed to him a strong desire for peace, they remained "deeply divided" on how to resolve the key issues that have blocked a settlement.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 21 (UPI) The newspaper of the Tanzanian Government said today that President Idi Amin of Uganda personally shot and killed his country's Anglican Archbishop last Wednesday.

QUEENSTOWN, South Africa, Feb. 21 (Reuters) Thousands of black refugees could die of malnutrition and disease in a camp near here unless immediate help is forthcoming, the leader of the camp's medical team said today.

MONTREAL, Feb. 21 The Montreal coroner said today that Premier Rene Le vesque had "unavoidably" killed a man with his car Feb. 6 and was not criminally responsible for the accident.

TRENTON, Feb. 21 Governor Byrne has backed down a bit from his endorsement of a suggestion by Governor Carey of New York that the New YorkNew Jersey metropolitan area try to get the 1984 Summer Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) Senator William Proxmire today called for legislation prohibiting companies from participating in the Arab boycott against Israel, even if it resulted in American workers' losing their jobs.

Vince Mutarelli, a junior at Mount St. Michael Academy, posted the fastest time by a schoolboy yesterday for the 1,000-yard run in the metropolitan area this reason. With a clocking of 2 minutes 16.4 seconds, he lowered the meet record by more than a second in the New York division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association sectional track and field indoor championships at the 102d Regiment Armory.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Feb. 21 "If you tell people here a hurricane is coming, they will tell you it won't hit Ocean Grove," said Ed Holl, the proprietor of Nagle's Pharmacy. "Right or wrong, people feel very secure around here."

Bertram David Wolfe, the scholar, writer and one of the country's foremost experts on the Soviet Union, died yesterday at the Santa Clara Valley Medical Center in San Jose, Calif., at the age of 81. His death came hours after he had suffered severe burns when his bathrobe caught fire from a wall heater.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 21 T. Cullen Davis, a 43-year-old Forth Worth oil man, will go on trial tomorrow for the murder of his 12-year-old stepdaughter, Andrea Wilborn, in the family's $7 million Forth Worth mansion.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 The domestic auto industry, confident of a spring sales surge and trying to recover from winter plant shutdowns, is scheduling production of 916,000 cars in March, highest monthly total since the Arab oil embargo over three years ago.

COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Feb. 21 (UPI) The pro-Moscow Communist Party of Sri Lanka has ended its coalition with the Government, and Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike said today she might have to reimpose a state of emergency to ward off chaos.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 21 (Reuters) Clark Clifford held intensive talks with Turkish leaders today and reported progress on the problems troubling relations between the United States and Turkey.

LONDON, Feb. 21 Two British journalists and a former British soldier were ordered held without bail for seven days today by a Magistrates Court here. They were charged with violating the Official Secrets Act.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (Reuters) President Carter said today that he would prefer that Quebec remain part of a united Canada but that "that is a decision for the Canadian people to make."

Girding Itself for hostile Congressional hearings, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has retained A.A. Sommer Jr., the former Securities and Exchange Commissioner, as special counsel and Washington strategist.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 The green T-shirts read, "Jasper Track Is Back," and Manhattan athletes wore them with defiant pride today after winning the Metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field championships.
BREWSTER, N.Y., Feb. 21 (AP) Funeral services were scheduled for tomorrow for a Brewster man who fell and hit his head after fainting from excitement at seeing his newborn son.

GOSHEN, Vt. Provide a cross-country skier with any kind of excuse these days, and he'll don his skis and be gone. No longer is the justification for a five-mile march through the woods in sub-zero weather just a "need to exercise." The modern tour of the ski trails has switched from need to ingenuity.

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 22 (AP) South Korea's Ambassador to the United States has resigned and is being replaced by a veteran diplomat and former Foreign Minister, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

The International Business Machines Corporation, Wall Street's perennial favorite as a growth stock, decided yesterday that its best investment now is in its own shares. The company that produces more than half of the world's computer hardware is offering to buy up to 4 million of its shares at $280 net in cash for each share which adds up to a potential outlay of $1.12 billion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Four of the men arrested during the Watergate breakin have agreed to an out-of-court settle ment that will give them $200,000 from former President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 campaign fund, a lawyer for the four men said today.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 22 Kialoa, the big white 79-foot ketch from Los Angeles, which sails the oceans of the world, came barreling into the harbor here today leading the fleet of 74 yachts in the annual Miami-to-Nassau race, which began yesterday afternoon.

A special grand jury investigating whether high-ranking police officers maintain an organized system of collecting bribes from operators of illegal enterprises has indicted Deputy Inspector Daniel F. McMahon on charges of perjury. The indictment, announced yesterday by Special State Prosecutor John F. Keenan, alleges that Inspector McMahon testified falsely when he denied having received money from officers below the rank of captain when he was working in the Harlem area in 1970 and 1971.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Michael B. Lien, a former staff photogapher for The New York Times, died today at University Hospital in Baltimore of injuries sustained in an automobile accident Dec. 4. He was 40 years old.

But the panel also said that there had been a decrease in the last several months in the numbers involved, and it charged that "more subtle" forms of torture were now being employed.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) The price of gold continued a rise in Europe today and closed in London at its highest level since mid-November. The dollar had a mixed day.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 22 (UPI) The United States special envoy, Clark Clifford, concluded two days of talks with Turkish leaders today and declared that the views of both sides on the Cypress issue were very close.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 22 A bistate coalition similar to the Port Authority could resolve the growing problems of race tracks in the metropolitan area, in the view of two of the most powerful figures in the sport.
Highlighting activity in the commodity markets yesterday were rises in prices of gold and silver futures both here and in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (Reuters) President Carter has postponed for one year the United States contribution to a proposed $1.5 billion loan to Portugal from a group of industrialized countries.
MADRID, Feb. 22 (Reuters) Spanish authorities said tonight that they had smashed an arms-making plot by extreme rightists and detained 10 people.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The Carter Administration said today it was cutting $200 million from the most controversial of the Government's nuclear-energy programs, the fast breeder reactor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 President Carter proposed a revised budget today for the fiscal year 1978 that projects a $57.7 billion deficit to make room for his economic stimulus package and for a set of priorities that puts more emphasis I than former President Gerald R. Ford did on energy and domestic social programs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) The Supreme Court today let stand a lower court decision that a company controlled by Robert L. Vesco must pay a $2.4 million legal debt owed by Mr. Vesco.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) The Texaco Oil Company has reserves in the Gulf of Mexico containing more than 500 billion cubic feet of natural gas but failed to produce from these reservoirs because of its "desire to maximize its profits," Congressional investigators said today.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 With a month-long deadlock broken at the last minute, the Legislature tonight set June 7 as the date for primary elections in the state this year, with a runoff election to follow on June 21 if a candidate for any of the top three offices in New York City does not get at least 40 percent of the vote.

Insisting that "I'm not still fighting the Battle of Waterloo," the Duke of Wellington appeared at the Sotheby Parke Bernet gallery yesterday to take possession of a military tunic of Napoleon Bonaparte's that was captured at the 1815 battle in Belgium.

HUEHUETLA, Mexico, Feb. 19 The high prices being paid for coffee in American supermarkets are beginning to benefit the impoverished farmers of this Indian village high in the Mexican sierra, five hours by donkey from the nearest road.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22(AP) Slate Department cablegrams made public today said that growers in Brazil were withholding coffee to get higher prices. But a State Department official asserted that Brazilian producers had not artificially created higher prices and added that he did not agree with the cablegrams.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 22 Israel's governing Labor Party, beset by scandal and defections, opened its nominating convention here today with cries for unity, boosterism and speeches from leaders of the Socialist International who had been invited for the occasion.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 22 Enrolled Westchester Republicans, who once outnumbered Democrats by more than 2 to 1, now lead them by only 15,485. The County Board of Elections, in figures released today, gave the Republi cans 172,661 enrolled voters to 157,176 for the Democrats as of last Dec. 31.

Two "highly professional" robbers escaped with what authorities would describe only as a very large amount of money including part or all of a deposit of receipts from three nights of racing at Yonker Raceway yesterday morning from a Yonkers bank.

QUEEN ELIZABETH and other members of England's royal family, possibly including the Queen Mother, are participa ting in a series of nine one-hour documentaries tracing 900 years of Britain's monarchy. The television programs, entitled "Royal Heritage," are to be the major contribution of the British Broadcasting Corporation to the observance of the 25th anniversary of the Queen's ascension to the throne.
UNION, Feb. 22 Arthur Cacella of East Brunswick, president of Amateur Astronomers, Inc. says he never tires of looking at the sky. "It changes all the time, but it remains beautiful," he says.

SHERBURNE, Vt., Feb. 22 A "substantial amount" of money has been demanded of officials of the Sherburne Corporation, manager of the Killington Basin ski area, by an unidentified caller who said he had hidden explosives around the busy ski resort, the police reported today.

Sam Rivers, the jazz saxophonist and composer, has been leading a big band on Monday nights at Storyville, 41 East 58th St. Although he has recorded one big-band album, "Crystals," and is putting the finishing touches on another, Mr. Rivers's reputation still hinges on his abilities as a tenor saxophonist. This is not really surprising, for he is probably the most gifted, original and audacious contemporary player on that instrument.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has sent her first group of staff appointments to the White House, Administration sources said today.

DENVER, Feb. 22 A group of plant scientists warned today that despite the vast increase in the use of chemical pesticides and better farming methods, about half of world food production still was being destroyed by insects, weeds and animals.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the short interest in the month ended Feb. 15 decreased 612,364 shares to 26,261,329 shares. The short interest on Feb. 13, 1976, the year-earlier level, totaled 25,647,279 shares.

The Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill 1929 musical, "Happy End," will be the fourth and final production of the Chelsea Theater Center's current season, beginning subscription performances on March 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

DETROIT, Feb. 23 American auto sales dropped 7.5 percent in mid-February from last year and analysts cited the aftereffects of the January weather.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Jubilant Republican Party leaders said today that the upset victory of Arlan Stangeland in a special Congressional election yesterday in Minnesota heralded the party's resurgence in 1978.

Thomas J. Cuite, the City Council majority leader, announced yesterday that the special Council redistricting commission would hold its final meeting at 11 A.M. tomorrow at City Hall and adopt new lines for 33 councilmanic districts the same day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee voted 9 to 3 today to restore all but about $20 million of the $154 million in public-works money that it had recently slashed from allotments for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)--The Senate Intelligence Committee unanimously recommended today that Adm. Stansfield Turner be confirmed as Director of Central Intelligence.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 23 Alfred B. DelBello. the Westchester County Executive who is seeking to replace Consolidated Edison as the major supplier of power in the county, conceded today it might be "a matter of years" before that objective could be achieved.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 An order from the New York State Division of Alcoholism halting admissions to five rehabilitation centers around the state drew sharp criticism today from State Senator Joseph R. Pisani and the president of the State Association of Councils on Alcoholism.
The New York Yankees, with one of baseball's higher-priced collection of players voted last year against giving their four batboys any share of World Series money.

Patrick O'Neal, the actor, was sued for $280,000 in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday by an advertising agency that said he had failed to disclose that he was a former alcoholic when he signed a contract to make two television commercials about beer.

Joanne Beretta, who plays an Edwardian gentleman in "The Club" at the Circle in the Square, is now also doing an after-theater performance as herself on Mondays and Tuesdays at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street.

Judge Henry F. Werker has decided that a sex-discrimination complaint filed by women employees of The New York Times can proceed as a class-action suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
Dr. Norman M. Weinrod, an obstetrician and gynecologist, died Tuesday at his country home in East Quogue, L.I. He was 63 years old and a resident of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

He outmaneuvered his main opponent in Congress, Jack Brooks of Texas, by visiting with the members of Mr. Brooks's committee and winning them over to his approach. Mr. Brooks has found himself treated in the press as an obstructionist.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 23 (Reuters) A 16day nationwide building strike ended today when union and management representatives reached a compromise on wages and improved vacation benefits. Building workers, who struck to back demands for a 2 percent increase in basic wages, will get 1 percent immediately and half a percent next July. Vacation bonuses will also be increased.

Mary Martin and Ethel Merman, who have been to the Broadway musical what Guy Lombardo is to New Year's Eve, held a news conference yesterday morning to make a disclosure: For the first time in their careers, the two singers will co-star on a Broadway stage.

With all the theatrical activity that goes on in New York, it is not surprising for two versions of a classic play to surface at roughly the same time. But the arrival of "The Cherry Orchard," directed by Alan Schneider, at Juilliard's Theater Center, almost simultaneously with that of Andrei Serban's "Cherry Orchard" across Lincoln Center Plaza at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, did raise a few eyebrows.
The Chemical Bank was indicted yesterday on a charge of having failed to report 500 cash transactions, amounting to $8.5 million, as required by the Federal Bank Security Act.
OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 24 The sentencing of Wendy Yoshimura, who was convicted last month on charges of illegally possessing a machine gun and explosives, was postponed today until March 17.
STONINGTON, Conn., Feb. 24 S. Whitney Satterlee, a retired New York City banking executive, died yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years old and had resided at 6 Gold Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 A justice Department spokesman said today that a six-year ban on the use of the terms "Mafia" and "Costra Nostra" apparently is ended, after Attorney General Griffin B. Bell made several references to the "Mafia" at a meeting with reporters.

NATURE abhors a vacuum, we were told in school. But nature's likes and dislikes don't affect what we see in the gal leries. If someone leaves a vacuum around it is likely to stay there until someone else comes alone and fill it up.
A stocky young robber held up a Chemical Bank branch in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, escaping with $20,000 and leaving seasoned detectives shaking their heads in wonder.
Marsh McLennan Companies has acquired a 30 percent interest in the Hudig-Langveldt Group of Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The price was not disclosed, but it was probably in excess of $10 million.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 24 (AP) A twin-engine state plane crashed into a home in a Harrisburg suburb and exploded today, killing Pennsylvania's state Republican chairman, the state Transportation Secretary and seven other persons.

John A. Coleman, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange from 1943 to 1947 and a leading fund raiser for the Roman Catholic Church, died of a heart failure Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 75 years old.

She possessed one of the outstanding voices of the century, and she broke racial barriers to become one of America's most honored women, but to the 24 members of Marian Anderson's extended family she is simply "Aunt Marian."

St. Peter's College, which had spent much of its season losing close basketball games, turned it around last night at Madison Square Garden by overcoming a 14-point deficit and defeating Seton Hall, 90-89.

Yesterday was doomsday. You hadn't noticed? Despite the fact that Mars, Saturn and Uranus were in "bad aspect" in relation to each other for the first time in 25 years, the end did not come yesterday, and astrologers seemed miffed.

A group of seventh-grade girls knocked on the principal's door at Junior High School 136 in the South Bronx yesterday, the second day of a strike by school maintenance workers. They were carrying a poster with a hand-lettered message: "We want our custodians back."

PRINCETON, Feb. 24 New Jersey will need 20 nuclear reactors by the year 2000 to provide for its electrical energy need unless an aggressive conservation program coupled with development of alternate generation systems is begun immediately.

BUFFALO, Feb. 24 (AP) Jim Lorentz scored a first-period goal, the rookie goalie Don Edwards recorded his second shutout and the Buffalo Sabres won their eighth game in the last nine by blanking the Philadelphia Flyers, 2-0, in a National Hockey League contest tonight.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) Gary Player tamed gusty breezes that swept the Inverrary Golf and Country Club course today for a fourunder-par 68 and took the first-round lead in the $250,000 Jackie GleasonInverrary Classic.
The stock market posted its fifth consecutive decline yesterday in continued slow trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level in more than three months.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra's concert in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night was more like an exercise in sound than anything else. Melody, harmony and musical structure were present in varying degree, but it was the quality and diversity of sonorities that held the interest.

A Galanos for $75? A Mainbocher or $95? It isn't a joke, it's for real. True, the couture clothes at Fabulous Fashions, 387 Avenue of the Americas near Waverly Place, date to the 1960's, but then most of them have never been worn and besides, such things tend to be timeless.

Lack of heat forced the closing yesterday of 16 New York City schools with nearly 17,000 pupils, and at many other schools teachers and youngsters had to wear coats in their damp, cold classrooms as boiler-room workers refused to cross picket lines set up by striking school cleaners and handymen.

The Rev. Martin F. Buckley, who served in several Roman Catholic parishes in the New York metropolitan area and was an Army chaplain for 30 years, died Monday at his home in Port Jefferson, L.I. where he lived in retirement with his sister, Charlotte Peterson. He was 63 years old.
A 16-year-old Ossining youth, one of four youngsters in northern Westchester County to come down with Reye's Syndrome in the last two weeks, died yesterday in the County Medical Center in Valhalla.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 Some drunken drivers will have to undergo treatment for alcoholism, and auto insurance rates will be reduced for thousands of drivers because six penalty points will be removed from their records.

Bank trust departments, mammoth managers of other people's money, made Dow Chemical and the American Telephone and Telegraph company their favorite additions to stock portfolios in the final quarter of 1976. This was a period when many issues declined in price and then staged a sharp year-end rally.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 24 (AP) The Tennessee Valley Authority was ordered today to halt any work on the $116 million Tellico Dam project that might harm the habitat of the snail darter, a threeinch fish on the Federal endangered species list.

THE DUMP is open two days a week, and our town is roughly divided into those who visit it Wednesday and those who so- cialize there over the back of pickup trucks and trailers on Saturday. Having been part of the Wednesday contingent for some time now. I find it very difficult to switch.

Prices of soybean futures advanced 10 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chica- go Board of Trade, again pulling up also the prices of the soybean products and grains traded on the same exchange. Yesterday's rise in soybeans brought the twoday advance to 31 cents a bushel.

Interest in ballet has grown so remarkably in recent years that one of the most crowded spots along Madison Avenue these days is the Norman Crider gallery-bookshop, which is paying tribute to Anna Pavlova through this weekend with a special exhibition.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 The State Board of Regents is considering a revised school calendar that would require all schools to close for five weeks next winter to conserve fuel. Under the proposal, school would begin next Sept. 1 and end June 30, 1978.

In its first action since it was formed three months ago, the New York City Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board has approved partial real-estate tax exemptions for nine private projects to cost $33.7 million.

Recently, a reader questioned the use of the word "Canuck" by New York Times columnist William Safire, Mr. Safire asked Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau for his opinion of the word's current usage and meaning, and received the following reply.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 A short-lived rollback of automobile insurance premiums took place today as Democrats and Republicans in the State Legislature sought to score political points on a volatile subject.

OF ALL the myths and misperceptions that afflicted the life of art in the great age of the Impressionist masters, perhaps the most preposterous was the notion that these inspired artists represented some radical repudiation of the past. The truth was exactly the reverse, of course. Manet, Renoir, Pissarro all worshipped at the shrine of the old masters.

President Carter's revision of the Ford budget shows the advantages and dangers of inexperience. Although total expenditures were increased to advance the goal of economic stimulus and recovery, the budget is noteworthy for two sets of politically daring reductions. The President proposed delays, leading to cuts, in defense and in some major water projects.

Pepsico Inc., the nation's second largest soft drink producer, reported yesterday an 18.6 percent rise in fourth-quarter profits and 27 percent for all of last year with a marked improvement in profit margins.

Shortly after John Rosselli testified before a Senate committee that he had participated in Central Intelligence Agency plots to kill Fidel Castro, a Washington friend asked him if he wasn't afraid for his life. The 70-year-old Mafia figure appeared unconcerned: "Who'd want to kill an old man like me?" he asked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that he was still troubled by some of the unanswered questions surrounding the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. nearly a decade ago, and that he might try to answer them by interviews with James Earl Ray, Dr. King's convicted murderer.

Busy as professional musicians are, they are always willing to come together in new alignments to make a different kind of music. This is what happened in the case of the six-year-old New York Philomusica, which begins a series of 12 concerts around the city this weekend.
A 26-year-old Brooklyn College psychology major who was to have been married next month was shot and killed yesterday during a robbery while driving a taxi in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Melyille Corporation has found $315,000 of questionable transactions in an investigation covering the last five years, according to a filing made available today at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Federally financed task force seeking to curb prostitution and pornography in midtown Manhattan received tentative financing for another year yesterday after its director was ordered to discontinue using an investigative technique that he had called critical to the project's success.
Representative Henry S. Reuss, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said yesterday that "banks should pay less attention to the man in Singapore and more attention to the man in Nassau County."

THERE IS PROBABLY something for everyone to dislike in Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra," an overinflated play that floats over the theater like a pompous dirigible in search of a mooring. However, that having been said, the production of the play by Ellis Rabb, which opened last night at the Palace Theater, is not at all bad, even if somewhat conventional in its concept of Egyptian grandeur and Shavian dialectic.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24 George Meany said today that organized labor would be willing to serve on a labor-management committee to advise President Carter on economic policy should the President decide to form one.
The Chemical Bank was indicted yesterday on a charge of having failed to report 500 cash transactions, amounting to $8.5 million, as required by the Federal Bank Secrecy Act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The most maligned man in the Carter Administration gave a lesson in political geography to White House budget officials last week as he fought to save the projects of some of his 535 constituents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Senate unanimously confirmed today the appointment of Adm. Stansfield Turner to be Director of Central Intelligence. The 53-year-old naval officer, a native of Chicago, will assume his new duties at once. He had been serving as comander of Allied naval forces in southern Europe.

If the Plains Baptist Church were located anywhere but in Plains, Georgia, its decision to dismiss its minister would not make much of a story. But during the Presidential campaign, owing to the prominence of a native son, this church became a symbol of sorts, and its vote to lift the ban on black worshipers assumed a symbolic significance.
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Feb. 24 Who gets what water has once again become a crucial issue in this state.

SEATS," an uncommon exhibition of the furniture three centuries have sat upon, opened at the Yale University Art Gallery this week and will remain on view through April 24. The show, which should prove of major interest to collectors of antique furniture, is historically wide ranging, and it is also democratic. It includes everything from rare Chippendales carved for aristocrats to the more common Windsors on which farmers and factory workers paused.

PLAINS, Ga., Feb. 24 (AP) Billy Carter says he was misquoted in a report that the resignation of the Rev. Bruce Edwards as pastor of the Plains Baptist Church was precipitated by the minister's adoption of a non-Caucasian child.

HOPEWELL, Va., Feb. 24 (UPI) An out-of-control sulphur tanker, dropping its anchor in a fruitless effort to stop, smashed into a bridge over the James River today, knocking out two huge sections and dumping at least two vehicles into the water.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) The Army Corps of Engineers recommended today that the Government scrap plans to complete the Cross Florida Barge Canal, a controversial waterway between the Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico which has already cost more than $60 million.

The new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Samuel DeMilia, said yesterday that he would seek to go back to the bargaining table with the city in a new effort to work out a satisfactory agreement.

Even developers agree this isn't right."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Patricia R. Harris, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, called today for an increase in Federal assistance to cities by $750 million next year, with most of the money to go toward a new "action" fund for cities with serious deterioration problems.

LONDON, Feb. 24 Horrified by what has been happening in Uganda, yet powerless to do much of anything about it, the British are casting about for some means of keeping as far from these shores as possible the man they consider the villain of the piece Field Marshal Idi Amin, President for life of Uganda.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Securities and Exchange Commission, responding partly to fears of some members of Congress that foreign investors may secretly acquire large stakes in American companies, adopted rules today to expand the amount of information publicly available about corporate ownership. Many large investors not now clearly subject to such disclosure will be forced to tell the commission of their holdings whenever they exceed 5 percent of a company's stock.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 The mood is glum on both sides of North Broad Street. The Newspaper Guild's strike against The Inquirer and The Daily News continues into its 17th day, with negotiations at a standstill since Tuesday.

DENVER, Feb. 24 (AP) The election of Prof. Arthur Jensen, the controversial psychologist, to the American Association for the Advancement of Science was reaffirmed today despite a member's claim that it was an endorsement of racism.

HONOLULU (UPI) A crippled Liberian tanker leaking millions of gallons of crude oil along a slick 50 miles long exploded in flames 360 miles west of Honolulu yesterday. All but one of the 39 crewmen aboard were rescued.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The House of Representatives voted today to triple the amount of money now available to states and communities to pay for public works construction for the purpose of creating jobs.

New York State's new lottery, which started last September, was expected yesterday to bring in for the state an estimated total of $90 million by the endof the current budget year, or $30 million above the first estimates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 President Carter said today that recently published reports about the Central Intelligence Agency's contacts abroad have prompted some foreigners who had been providing important information to the United States to question the secrecy and safety of their roles.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 Voicing their first major dissent to Governor Carey's proposed budget, Republican leaders in the New York State Senate today said they would reject the Governor's plan for welfare cuts and would propose their own an 8.9 percent across-the-board cut in both home relief and aid to families with dependent children.

LEE KRASNER's current show at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, was born three years ago in her East Hampton, L.I., barn. Poking around her studio there, Bryan Robertson, the critic and exhibition organizer, came upon a cache of oil and charcoal drawings Miss Krassner had done from 1937 to 1940 at the famed Hans Hofmann school here in New York.

In November 1974, Sergiu Luca, the Rumanian-born, Israeli-trained virtuoso violinist, began his campaign to present music in the perspective and context of the times in which they were conceived: at two Tully Hall recitals, he played all the unaccompanied partitas and sonatas of Bach using a baroque bow and an instrument returned to the baroque manner with a loosened soundpost, gut strings and lower tunings.

If there were a Tony Award for theatrical insouciance, the leading contender this season would have to be Lynn Milgrim, the willowy young actress who is winning applause as the very model of topless poise in "Otherwise Engaged."
Goldie Drell Paley, the mother of William S. Paley, Chairman of CBS, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 95 years old.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 24 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that he would include his political rival, Defense Minister Shimon Peres, in his Cabinet if, as expected, he is returned to office in the mid-May general elections.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 24 (AP) A University of Utah student whose body was found in mountains east of Salt Lake died of exposure Sunday night or Monday morning, the State Medical Examiner said today.
ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 24 A move from the subzero cold in Minnesota to the tropical climate of Florida has not warmed Calvin Griffith to the idea of spending money lavishly on baseball players.

FOR a few sickening moments it looked as if heavy drama ("The Fall of the House of Bartolo") were going to replace light comedy ("Il Barbiere di Siviglia") at the opening performance of the New York City Opera's spring season on Wednesday night. A huge section of the revolving set toppled over toward the orchestra pit as the final scene was about to start in Rossini's comedy, which starred Beverly Sills as Rosina.

John Burlineson McTigue, aretired partner of Andrew McTigue Sons, a Far Rockaway real-estate and insurance concern, died yesterday in Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, L.I. He lived at 128 North Wood Lane, Woodmere, and was 83 years old.
The nation's money supply grew sharply during the week ended Feb. 16, the New York' Federal Reserve Bank reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 24 In a new movie called "The Late Show," actors and actresses spend considerable time drinking Pepsi-Cola, and signs and a truck advertising the No. 2 cola appear on the screen regularly.
HAYWARD, Wis., Feb. 24 More than 1,800 skiers, a record field for the United States, will start Saturday in the 55-kilometer Birkebeiner ski touring race over the rolling country of the Badger State.

The Beneficial Corporation of Wilmington, Del., has reached an agreement in principle for the purchase of all of the receivables of the finance group of the Interstate Securities Company, a subsidiary of the ISC Financial Corporation of Kansas City, Mo.

Andre Eglevsky spoke Wednesday evening with quiet authority on the art of partnering and had members of his ballet company demonstrate the fine points to a rapt audience at Town Hall. As one of the great male dancers of our time, who can command the performing stage, he similarly dominated the all too short presentation of "The Art of the Pas de Deux" with his own wit and wisdom.

BONN, Feb. 24-President Carter has expressed regret to former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany about publication of "unsubstantiated rumors" that Mr. Brandt had taken money from the Central Intelligence Agency.

KATE AND ANNA McGarrigle put out a record early last year that was as beloved by the critics as it was ignored by the public. This particular critic raved about it, but so did a lot of others so many that a full year later, when thousands of better publicized albums had come along to challenge its memory, the disk still placed No. 5 in Robert Christgau's annual poll of 66 rock critics nationwide.
Starting next month, New York horseplayers will have only themselves to blame if they can't get their handicapping homework done on time.

SOUTH CHARLESTON, W.Va., Feb. 24 (UPI) Three tons of carbon tetrachloride seeped out of a ruptured tank at the FMC Corporation chemical plant today, threatening communities down the Kanawha and Ohio Rivers for the second consecutive week.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 24 Prominent church sources here, including some who have recently left Uganda, have said that the current turbulence in that country began a month ago with the opening of a Government campaign against Christian churchmen and members of the predominantly Christian Lango and Acholi tribes.

Mary Martin and Ethel Merman, who have been to the Broadway musical what Guy Lombardo is to New Year's Eve, held a news conference yesterday morning to make a disclosure: For the first time in their careers, the two singers will co-star on a Broadway stage.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 24 A war that began with a machine-gun attack on a remote homestead on the night of Dec. 22, 1972, has become a struggle for survival for Rhodesia's 270,000 whites, even though the fighting has been confined mostly to the vast reaches of this country's bushland. But now there is contern that the attacks by black insurgents could spread into the towns and cities.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 With public intoxication scheduled to be decriminalized on May 9, state officials began today a series of meetings designed to acquaint law enforcement and health officials with the provisions of the new law and to develop guidelines on how alcoholics will be handled and referred for treatment.

The credit markets, after drifting lower yesterday in the wake of their sharp decline Wednesday, sold off further late in the afternoon in a reaction to the Federal Reserve's report of increases in the nation's money supply.

BINGO STARR, the beloved Beatle of yesteryear, yearns to be known as Ringo Starr, movie star. That's why he has tackled the challenging role of a mad Hungarian direc- tor who masterminds the comeback of his sensuous, blond former wife in "Sextette." Mr. Starr clearly has his histrionic work cut out for him, since his leading lady is one of filmdom's most seductive scene-stealers: Mae West.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. On Jan. 7, 1776, the greatest fall of snow that had been known in England in the memory of man began. The Gentleman's Magazine reported snow drifts of "incredible depth. . . flocks of sheep buried, carriages of all kinds overturned or detained upon the roads; the mails retarded; post-boys and travellers frozen to death in pursuing their usual occupations, the intercourse between town and town interrupted."

Miss Van DeVere will stay with "Sly Fox" until May, and then she will start working seriously on a one- woman show about Victoria Woodhull. Everyone in theater, it seems, now wants to do a one-man, or one-woman, show, but Miss Van DeVere wants to do one out of conviction.

American business now plans to spend $139.8 billion on new plants and equipment in 1977, McGraw Hill publications said yesterday. The figure, about 2 percentage points higher than last fall's estimate, represents an increase of 15 percent over capital expenditures of $121.23 billion in 1976.

The regular National Hockey League season is over for Don Murdoch. The Rangers hope their high-scoring rookie will be ready for the opening of the Stanley Cup playoffs the first week in April, but his injury and those to other Rangers make it questionable whether the New York team will be in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

Archibald N. Galloway, a lawyer specializing in municipal bonds and counsel to the law firm of Willkie Farr Gallagher, died Wednesday during a visit to New York City. He was 66 years old and lived in Vero Beach, Fla.
Coffee, cocoa and gold futures prices continued to rise yesterday while those of farm products, such as soybeans, wheat and corn fell.

Arthur Levitt, the New York State Comptroller, released a report yesterday that was sharply critical of administrative practices and security procedures at Manhattan Psychiatric Center, the state mental hospital complex on Wards Island. But officials from the State Department of Mental Hygiene and directors of the hospital complex said Mr. Levitt's report was based on information already "two years old."

"The chic thing this year is people," writes a cheese-shop operator from First Avenue. "I guess it started with Jimmy Carter trying to get the Government interested in the existence of people, which could be wrong, as I am not really a keen analyst of these things.

A Federal investigation is continuing into "the kind of conduct" alleged in indictments involving the Chemical Bank, United States Attorney Robert B. Fiske Jr. said yesterday in Manhattan.

The nation's second largest coffee roaster increased wholesale prices on vacuum-packed coffee yesterday by 40 cents to a record $3.68 a pound.

Three of last season's New York Yankee batboys have refused to accept the $100 offered each of them in place of regular World Series shares, which were voted down by Yankee players. "The Yankees were cheapskates," said Walter Gershoff, a batboy who was let go before the Series, "and we want everybody to remember them as cheapskates."

Christopher as Deputy Secretary of State after inquiring briefly into his possible knowledge which the nominee denied of the Army surveillance of civilians in the late 1960's. NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25 Fouls stopped Pete Maravich before the Knicks could tonight and the Jazz guard scored 68 points as New Orleans routed the New Yorkers, 124-107. Maravich's total was the most ever scored by a backcourtman in the National Basketball Association and his pro career high. Only Wilt Chamberlain and Elgin Baylor scored more points in N.B.A. games.

Leonard L. Leddington, a former news editor for the NBC "Today" show, died Thursday at the Veterans Hospital in West Haven, Conn. He was 59 years old.

Robert E. Darling's production of Wagner's "Der Fliegende Hollander" at the New York City Opera was not too kindly greeted at its premiere last fall. Subjective considerations aside, there are firm objective reasons why its return Thursday night was a far more gratifying success.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 25 (AP) A high school newspaper editor has won a Federal court battle to publish an article on birth control over the objections of her Principal and school board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today that he intended to seek a price-fixing arrangement for wheat with Canada that would effectively set a world price on bread grain. WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) President Carter became a grandfather for the second time when 25-year-old Caron Carter, a daughter-in-law, gave birth tonight to a 7-pound boy. The family said that the boy would be named James Earl Carter 4th.

Shirley Mathews, a harpsichordist who made her New York debut in 1964 in Carnegie Recital Hall, returned there Thursday night for a program of works by Handel, Couperin, Rameau, Bach and Jacques Duphly. Now on the faculty of the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore, Miss Mathews gave an admirably academic account of the music. It could not be faulted in matters of clarity, articulation, ornamentation and general style.

WASHINGTON Sometime in the next month or so, Congress is expected to approve legislation giving President Carter the authority he wants to reorganize the executive branch. Under the legislation, the President will be able to recommend the creation, abolition or restructuring of Government agencies and the transfer of agencies from one department to another. Each recommendation will go into effect automatically unless the House or Senate votes within 60 days to block it.
