TOE LINE Trisha Brown is a choreographer who does all sorts of interesting dances. Some time ago she climbed the wall at a museum and her field, if you hadn't guessed, is modern dance. Today at 12:30 P.M. Miss Brow, and four members of her dance company will give a demonstration-lecture at Pratt Institute's Memorial Hall. She will speak and dance at the same time in one number.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Feb. 28 The Suffolk County Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelley, a Republican, charged tonight that the criticism of him in last week's report by a special state prosecutor was an attempt by the Democratic Party in the state, "beginning with the Governor," to destroy his career.

Looking something like Pooh Bear with his head stuck in a honey jar, the protagonist of "20 Years After the Man in the Iron Mask" hangs around limply all evening wearing an iron contraption over his face.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 28 The Federal Government said today that it would sue the State of Maine to recover land for the Passamaquoddy and Penobscot Indian tribes unless an out-of-court settlement was reached by June 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) A debate before the Senate Armed Services Committee on the appointment of Paul C. Warnke as the disarmament negotiator failed to materialize today when the Administration declined to send supporting witnesses.

The normally volatile commodity futures markets were even more so yesterday, with limit gains again in coffee and cocoa, a sharp rise in cotton, strong advances in metals and a convulsive session for grain and soybean traders in Chicago.

PRINCETON, N.J. Feb. 28 Renaldo Nehemieh of Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School tied his national indoor high school record in the 60-yard high hurdles with a 6.9 clocking and Tren ton Central captured the team title at the New Jersey all-group track meet today at Jadwin Gymnasiura.

Thomas E. Mullaney reports that the widespread conclusion is that inventories of many goods are at such low levels that a major rebuilding effort will have to be undertaken by the second half of the year. Page 45.

The Metropolitan Opera will present 20 productions next season, four of which will be new, 13 will be revivals and only 3 will be held over from this season. Two of the new productions will be borrowed from the San Francisco Opera, Donizetti's "La Favorita" and Massenet's "Thais." The other two are Verdi's "Rigoletto" and Wagner's "Tannhauser."

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 Argentina's military Government said today that the Carter Administration was interfering in the internal affairs of this country by reducing military aid to show its concern for human rights.

A couple of Romantic rarities Listz's "Malediction" for piano and strings and the Sixth Symphony of Anger Hamerik turned up Sunday night at an excellent Tully Hall concert by the New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra, a 12-member string ensemble founded and conducted by Raffael Adler.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Carter Administration told a Senate subcommittee today that it had reversed the Ford Administration's policy and would support passage of a law barring American companies from taking part in an Arab economic boycott of Israel.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 28 New York harness racing, in the doldrums from a business standpoint for many months, finally got a shot in the arm tonight as Roosevelt Raceway opened its 150-night 1977 season.

The Government and the teamsters' union were poised for a showdown yesterday as the Labor Department prepared to go to court if necessary to remove the union president, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, as a trustee of the union's major pension fund.
GARY, Ind., Feb. 28 Gary's City Hall is a drab, two-story brick building that stands in the shadows of a boarded-up Holiday Inn on which the city once built its hopes for a downtown economic revival.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 28 President Amin met today with a small group of Americans working for Uganda Airlines as pilots and ground crews and told them that the people of Uganda were their "brothers and sisters."

School cleaners and handymen returned to work yesterday after a five-day strike that had produced refuse pile-ups, the shutdown of 24 schools, and shortened days with reduced heat and no food in New York City's 994 public schools.
Governor Carey is to meet with Liberal Party leaders tomorrow to discuss a possible Democratic-Liberal coalition in the mayoral campaign in New York City.

The brutally cold weather has caused suffering for many Americans. But no group has been hit harder than migrant farm workers and their children, particularly in the southeastern United States. Officials estimate that more than 100,000 migrants in Florida alone have been laid off because of the cold.

EAST BRUSWICK, Feb. 28 Calling the current plan for a comprehensive system of mental health care "a paper revolution." State Senator Alexander J. Menza said today that he believed bills before the Legislature to improve and expand county facilities with state aid would fail and that it would take "a long time in this state to get anything going for the mentally ill."

A former sales agent for the Grumman Corporation has charged that two onetime close associates of President Kennedy were taken to a key business meeting in early 1974 to intimidate the agent into selling his contract to represent the planemaker in the sale of F-14's to Iran.

Now is the time for all good European fashion designers to pay a seasonal visit to their New York friends. Their collections for next fall are being prepared in their workrooms, their spring styles are beginning to sell here, and isn't it a good idea to help things along with a personal appearance or two?

POTOMAC, Md., Feb. 28 (AP) Cherished medals and mementoes from Senator John Glenn's career as an astronaut were among items stolen from his home here Saturday, the Montgomery County police reported today.

The Kysor Industrial Corporation of Cadillac, Mich., reported that its executive committee would recommend to its board that the offer of Bliss Laughlin Industries to buy Kysor be rejected. No reason was given for the rejection. Last week Bliss Laughlin made an offer to buy Kysor for a minimum of $32 million.

The spirited efforts, unfortunately unavailing, of the 72-year-old Countess of Sallsbury who ran briskly away from Henry VIII's executioner should point a moral to declarers at the bridge table. When the ax is about to descend, do everything you can to escape it.
SPRAY, Ore., Feb. 28 In the next few days, Mike Griffith, who owns a general store here, will return about $100 worth of aerosol spray products to his wholesaler.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 28 (AP) Peter Fleming and Sandy Mayer, both from New Jersey, scored victories today in the opening round of the $175,000 national indoor tennis championships.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (AP) Corky the killer whale gave birth today to a 6-foot, 125-pound calf, believed to be the first time a killer whale has ever been born in captivity during the ten years the mammals have been held, officials said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal today rejected proposals of 10 companies to use foreign vessels for delivering liquid propane gas between American ports.

A standing-room-only, boisterous crowd of 4,500 saw Rich Silvera and Ron Glover team for 42 points and lead the City College basketball team to a 69-66 victory over Hunter College last night at City's Mahoney Gymnasium. The Beavers' victory, in the tournament finale of the City University of New York, gave them the conference crown for the second straight season.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 25 With Lieut, Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam now its undisputed leader, Ethiopia's secretive council of military rulers has turned from a collective revolutionary body into a one-man dictatorship.
HOLTVILLE, Calif., Feb. 28 At the Texaco station in this Imperial Valley farm town with a 3,686 population, Henry was pumping gas when a traveler asked, "Any millionaires live here?"

Representative George V. Hansen, an Idaho Republican, yesterday asked that the House subcommittee on domestic monetary policy investigate loans by the Marine Midland Bank to Panama, saying they may be a reason why the New York bank appeared at the top of a "problem list" drawn up by the Federal Reserve Board.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28 (AP) Dennis Maruk of Cleveland scored off a defenseman's skate in the opening period and later set up a goal by a linemate, leading the Barons to a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League game tonight.
A killer who left a 24-year-old woman fatally stabbed in her bed was being sought yesterday by New York City detectives.
Friends, I know there are graver events begging for attention in 116 world capitals and the White House press office, but what in the name of Dan Beard is going on with the Boy Scouts?

TRENTON, Feb. 28 Consultants from the Fels Center of Government at the Wharton School in Philadelphia will conduct a 10-month study of New Jersey's Department of Transportation with an aim toward improving the productivity and efficiency of the agency.

Governor Carey's commission on postsecondary education intends to recom- mend today that two new and primarily state-financed systems of public higher education be established to replace the existing City and State Universities.

Eddie (Rochester) Anderson, the gravelvoiced comedian who played Jack Benny's valet for more than 30 years, died yesterday at the Motion Picture Country House and Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 71 years old and had been under treatment for a heart ailment since December.
The American Express Company announced yesterday top management changes after Howard L. Clark decided at the age of 61 to step down as chairman and chief executive officer April 25.

A business promoter was allowed to become one of the principal officers of New York State's largest lottery-vending company despite a state investigation that found he was suspected of having received financial backing from organizedcrime figures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether individual states may regulate the presence of oil tankers in their ports and waterways to prevent oil spills or whether the states must depend instead on the Federal Government to do the regulating.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 The Legislature will vote this week to give Buffalo, the state's second-largest city, a new fiscal tool that may allow it to return to the bond market for the first time in three Years.

From a distance, through the Times Square foreground of mongrel leisure and merchandized desire, the sight of two new 45-story apartment towers standing empty can seem as eerie as Stonehenge. What are they doing there? Did they break loose from the East Side during some midnight convulsion of the fiscal crisis?

"George is going to do what George wants to do, I have a hunch," said Donald E. Creamer, chairman and chief execuive of Creamer/iFSR, as he formally announced the arrival of George Lois as president of the agency. As for George, he talked about synergism a lot.

A business promoter was allowed to become one of the principal officers of New York State's largest lottery-vending company despite a state investigation that found he was suspected of having received financial backing from organizedcrime figures.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 28 The Sudan today joined the loose political command established in December by Syria and Egypt to coordinate strategy toward Israel.

Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, has warned the coaches and players that a continuation of "punching and fighting will be met with stern measures" by his office, including ejections from the game, fines and suspensions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Nonprescription drug advertisements should be scrutinized in advance by panels of behavioral scientists if the language used in them to make claims differs from that approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use on package labels, according to Robert Choate, chairman of the Council on Children, Media and Merchandising.

LOME, Togo, Feb. 28 (Reuters) The African boycott of sports events involving New Zealand will be widened to include any country maintaining sports links with South Africa, the Organization of African Unity Ministerial Council decided at a meeting today.

While differing viewpoints abound in economic circles on many aspects of current business conditions and the outlook, there is one important area, at least, on which there seems to be a high degree of consensus. It involves

Children's Express, a monthly magazine written by youngsters 13 years old and under, has been investigating institutions that house children in trouble. Following are excerpts from the first article in a planned series, to start in a forthcoming issue. The person interviewed, a New Yorker, is identified only as Thelma, 15, to protect her identity.

WASHINGTON, FEB. 28 (UPI) President Carter's press secretary said today that The Washington Post had asked for White House guidance before disclosing alleged payments by the Central Intelligence Agency to King Hussein of Jordan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 More evidence that the American economy was hard hit in January by the severe cold weather and drought showed up today in two key Government indicators of business activity.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 President Idi Amin of Uganda today postponed for a second time a meeting he had scheduled with the more than 200 Americans living in his country.

A Seattle archeologist has challenged the popular view that early human hunters were responsible for the great wave of extinctions that killed off most of the large mammals in North America between 10,000 and 13,000 years ago.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 Governor Carey's proposed $100 million cut in the state's personal income tax will almost certainly not survive the legislative bargaining over the 1977-78 budget, key members of both parties said today.

An alliance has been formed between the Public Schools Athletic League and the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association that will result in a basketball game between the champions of the two leagues.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 Dave Kingman joined the New York Mets in their fourth workout of spring training today, but continued his holdout for a long-range, $3 million contract that could lend to a money revolt by other stars of the team.

Negotiations on New York City's latest fiscal emergency broke down yesterday afternoon when leaders of the municipal labor unions stormed out of their talks with bankers at City Hall, and Mayor Beame accused the banks of stalling and holding "a gun at our heads."

Four community school boards in New York City that had refused to collect ethnic data required for state and Federal surveys were superseded yesterday by Chancellor Irving Anker. At the same time, Mr. Anker lifted his earlier supersession orders on Districts 20 and 21 in Brooklyn, which have since complied with orders to collect the data.
Innovations in computers and data processing are badly outstripping the ability of corporate internal auditors to monitor such systems, a Stanford Research Institute study has concluded.

Five young inmates at the Nassau County Correctional Center in East Meadow, L.I., have been indicted on charges that they sexually assaulted three other male inmates in the youth tier. According to District Attorney Denis Dillon's office, authorities learned of the incidents, said to have taken place Feb. 12, when one of the young victims told a priest the following morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The national Labor Relations Board ruled today that it would no longer consider whether a union discriminated by race or sex before it certified the union as the bargaining agent for a group of employees.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 Two nurses, both citizens of the Philippines, go on trial in Federal court here tomorrow, accused of being the killers who terrified a Veterans Administration hospital at nearby Ann Arbor in the summer of 1975.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (UPI) Employees of The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, a Hearst Corporation newspaper that has been nonunion since it was struck 10 years ago, voted last night to be represented by a single union. The vote came as the employees ratified a new three-year contract with the newspaper.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 28 With Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam now its undisputed leader, Ethiopia's secretive council of military rulers has turned from a collective revolutionary, body into a one-man dictatorship.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 28 The chairman and the counsel of the Special Bus Subsidy Program Study Commission charged today that New Jersey bus companies were overpaid $1.5 million in state subsidies between July 1, 1975, and June 30, 1976, and returned only $20,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP) The National Park Service said today that it would assume control March 31 of Valley Forge Park, the site where George Washington's Continental Army spent its "winter of despair" in 1777-78.
J. Paul Lyet, chairman of the Sperry Rand Corporation, has been named general campaign chairman for the United Fund of Greater New York's 1977 fundraising drive, which begins in April.
It began for Dave Day with a bamboo curtain rod, Honest, Right next to the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks that ran through his backyard in Edison, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) A House subcommittee, rejecting arguments that loopholes could allow violations by Japan, agreed today to expedite agreements permitting that country and three others to fish within the United States new 200mile offshore limit.
VIENNA, Feb. 28 The finance ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began a two-day meeting here today to discuss aid for poor nations and international monetary questions.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 28 The Nassau County Board of Supervisors declined today to approve the selling of leases for a proposed $20 million shopping center for Mitchel Field, probably killing the proposal for this year.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28 When a former Yankee said, "It's great to be young and a Yankee," he wasn't thinking of the many young pitchers who dot the Yankee camp this spring.
BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 28 (Reuters) Twenty-two people were killed and 85 injured in a head-on collision between two suburhan commuter trains near here today, police headquarters said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The temptation is strong to look for another Jimmy Carter among the state governors who have been meeting here in their annual midwinter conference. But the truth is that even Jimmy Carter some of his former colleagues would say particularly Jimmy Carter didn't look much like a future President when he used to attend these meetings as the Governor of Georgia.
ATLANTA, Feb. 28 (AP) Attorneys for the Atlanta Braves notified Commissioner Bowie Kuhn today that they would seek an injunction against Kuhn's suspension of the team owner, Ted Turner.

Two incidents of the past weekend warn that time is running out for the City of New York to take the precise measure of its fiscal crisis and save itself from the disaster of bankruptcy. And it is certainly no time for the parties negotiating the city's next reprieve to allow their talks to break down or to play brinkmanship.
Only three of the 330 passengers aboard the London-to-New York jet late Sunday knew they were sitting on top of a ton-load of treasure stained-glass windows from Canterbury Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Field Marshal Amin had originally demanded that the meeting be held today and had said that no American would be allowed to leave the country until it was held. It was then put off until Wednesday with the official Continued on Page 8, Column 4.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The General Accounting Office, citing hundreds of cases where Federal officials had financial interests in companies they were regulating, today recommended strengthened conflict-of-interest rules and a new Government agency to enforce them.

What is happening in the subways? A spate of publicity over recent crime has raised public concern, spurring intensified patrolling by the 2,954-man transit police force. Budget-dictated service cuts including shorter four-car and five-car trains in off-pealz hours have aggravated congestion. According to the Transit Authority, each day in the subways brings about a dozen "open felony complaints," or crimes against riders with no policemen present.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 If a fire had swept through New York's largest hotel, the story would have been all over the front pages. Television news shows would have been full of dramatic film: flames leaping out of windows, firemen making daring rescues, survivors telling their tales of escape. The numbers of dead and injured would have been spread through headlines and radio broadcasts until they had become common knowledge.
A spring cleanup campaign to repair thousands of potholes and sweep 6,000 miles of city streets, parks and sewer catch basins was announced yesterday by Mayor Beame.

MANILA Americans used to say with a measure of pride that whatever the wrongs of colonialism, the United States left behind in its former possession, the Philippines, a firmly founded democratic system.

A few years ago, investing in the stock market was a relatively simple process. A person called his broker, had some advice relayed from the research department and then proceeded to buy or sell a stock.
DETROIT, Feb. 28 (AP) Roy Abernethy, former president and chief executive officer of the American Motors Corporation, died today in Tequestra, Fla. He was 70 years old.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 28 (UPI) The price of gold, already at its highest levels in over a year, shot up again today while the dollar eased on most European money markets. The Swiss franc came under renewed pressure.
John Dickson Carr, author of 120 mystery novels and hundreds of short stories, died of cancer Sunday in Greenville, S.C., where he made his home. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Prices paid to farmers for their products, rose 2 percent in the month ended Feb. 15, lifting the index of prices they receive back to the point where it stood a year ago, the Agriculture Department reported today. The rise was the third consecutive month of increases.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 More evidence that the American economy was hard hit in January by the severe cold weather and drought showed up today in two key Government indicators of business activity.

LAS VEGAS Nev., Feb. 28 (AP) A local television station reported today that it had received an anonymous telephone call from a man demanding $500,000 ransom for Mr. Bramlet. The police said that they doubted the caller was involved in the case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The number of schoolchildren below the poverty level dropped by 569,000 throughout the country in the first half of this decade, but the South accounted for more than that total and the number actually rose in other areas.

Prices of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds declined sharply yesterday as New York City's financial difficulties deepened once again. Bonds of the state agency dropped as much as 2 points, partly because the Secretary of the Treasury, W. Michael Blumenthal warned that he might not approve the city's emergency loan application and partly because of news reports that the city's unions Walked out of city debt negotiations yesterday.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 28 (UPI) The Government said today that it planned to recruit 12,000 men aged 38 to 50 into the Rhodesian security forces and that the use of women "cannot be overlooked" in the fight against black nationalist guerrillas.

LOS ANGELES "When someone points out that I'm Asian," said 17year-old Kimi Sumner, "I feel odd. I think of myself as being totally American. Sometimes it's easy to forget, but people make you remember."
John Herr, a real estate finance executive and former investment banker, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Huntington, L.I.

HONG KONG, Feb. 28 The Soviet Union's chief representative at the border talks with China left Peking today after an evidently unsuccessful three-month effort to achieve progress in the long-deadlocked negotiations.

SEOUL, Tuesday, March 1 The police today overpowered two middle-aged women, each under 5 foot tall, as they emerged from a Protestant prayer service on the national holiday commemorating the independence movement against Japan. The women were driven away in police cars, held down in the rear seats by burly plainclothesmen, who sat on them.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 Governor Carey's proposed $100 million cut in the state's personal income tax will almost certainly not survive the legislative bargaining over the 1977-78 budget, key members of both parties said today.
SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 28 (UPI) Six people were killed today when troops charged a downtown square in which 2,000 supporters of a defeated presidential candidate were barricaded.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28 Ch. Galanjud's Blue Chip, a boxer owned by Gale and Jud Streicher of Scarsdale, N.Y., and handled by Jane Forsyth of Southbury, Conn., was selected best in show yesterday at the 66th annual event of the Elm Citv Kennel Club.

ATLANTA, Feb. 28 G. Thomas Peterson, the Plains Airport operator who spent much of the last two years flying Jimmy Carter around the United States, is seeking a top job with the Federal Aviation Administration and has added his increasingly busy grass strip to the growing list of real estate for sale in the President's home town.
Frank J. Bowden, a nationally ranked tennis player of the 1930's and 40's, died yesterday of a heart attack in Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old and resided in Chatham, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The leaders of 21 major environmental organizations announced today that they would organize a nationwide citizens' campaign to rally support for President Carter's decision to cut funding for 19 big Federal water projects.

ABERDEEN, Miss., Feb. 28 (AP) The State of Mississippi plans to sell a mixture used to attack fire ants that includes the insectide Mirex, which has been shown to cause cancer in some animals in laboratory tests.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 For all its peculiarities, Richard Strauss's "Intermezzo" is a delightful work. Although it had its premiere in Dresden in 1924, it had to wait 53 years before receiving its first American stage performances here, last weekend. The opera was given Friday night and last night at the Walnut Street Theater, under the auspices of the Curtis Institute of Music.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 A SenateHouse conference acted today to accommodate President Carter's economic stimulus package within the more rigorous budget procedures of the Congress.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 1 A Uganda radio broadcast today, monitored here, quoted President Idi Amin as saying that American residents of Uganda were free to go anywhere they like, inside or outside the country.

SAN DIEGO, Feb. 28 Representatives of the American tuna fleet will urge Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps at a meeting in Washington tomorrow to authorize transfer of their vessels to foreign flags to escape what they call "utter economic disaster."

New York city's Board of Higher Education voted last night to allow out-oftown state residents attending the senior colleges of the City University of New York to pay the same undergraduate tuition charges as students living in the city, effective this fall. Present tuition in the upper division of the four-year colleges is $462.50 a semester for city residents and $712.50 for those from out of town.

Negotiations on New York City's latest fiscal emergency broke down yesterday afternoon when leaders of the municipal labor unions stormed out of their talks with bankers at City Hall, and Mayor Became accused the banks of stalling and holding "a gun at our heads."
Taxpayers who sustained the worst of this winter's relentless snowstorms may find a measure of immediate financial relief in the tax law.

HAVANA, Feb. 28 (Reuters) Cuba today extended its fishing waters to 200 miles and, in a clear reference to the United States, declared itself ready to open negotiations with neighboring countries. The United States also extends its fishing waters to 200 miles as of tonight.

Eli Lilly, the late pharmaceutical manufacturer, left 85,223 shares of Eli Lilly Company common stock, valued at more than $3 million, to the Save the Children Federation, according to David L. Guyer, the federation's executive director.

Belle Bloomfield Dorfman, who, playing under her maiden name, was a regular participant in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournaments, died Sunday in the University of California at Los Angeles Hospital after suffering a heart attack on a visit there. She was 80 years old and lived at 333 West 56th Street.

The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of equipment for industry, achieved record results for the quarter and year ended last Dec. 31, with profit increases of 56.2 percent and 99.7 percent, respectively.
The battle between the use of acrylonitrile and polyester in making plastic softdrink bottles appears, at least temporarily, to have been won by polyester.

Three prominent social scientists and the deputy chancellor of the New York City Board of Education will join the Russell Sage Foundation in the fall to direct a program with new emphasis on the study of New York City's problems and institutions.

There's a medieval quality to Nilda Getty's work. The exhibition of her oxidized sterling and fine silver body jewelry, belts and objects d'art at the Kruger Gallery, 842 Madison Avenue, between 69th and 70th Streets, through March 25, brings to mind the armor that knights errant were as they rode out to rescue the lady fair.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, reporting to the Security Council on his recent Middle East mission, warned today of grave dangers unless agreement is reached on resuming negotiations for a settlement.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 28 More than four months after an Arab-imposed ceasefire officially ended the Lebanese civil war, heavy fighting continues daily in southern Lebanon between Palestinian commando units and right-wing Christian militias relying on Israeli support.

The Cobbs Creek Expressway in Philadelphia is unlikely ever to carry a car, truck or bus. Nor are vehicles likely to travel segments of Interstate-695 and I-95 in Boston, I-291 and I-86 in Hartford, I-95 and I-70S in the District of Columbia or I-80N in Portland, Ore.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 28 The Federal Government said today that it would sue the State of Maine to recover land for the Passamaquoddy and Penobscot Indian tribes unless an out-of-court settlement was reached by June 1.

PRINCETON, Feb. 28 Interest is higher than usual in this year's Princeton University student government elections tomorrow: one of the three candidates for chairman, the highest office, is a declared homosexual and gay activist.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 28 The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company filed suit here today seeking recovery of more than $625,000 from Robert P. Beasley, who maintained an illegal political slush fund for Firestone from 1970 to 1973. Mr. Beasley, 63 years old, retired last May 31 as vice chairman of Firestone, the world's second-largest rubber company.

As various species of birds, fish and animals tremble on the edge of extinction, it is pleasing to realize that one endangered group, this nation's alligators, is doing very well.
Two armed bandits overpowered two guards and the driver of an armored truck in Brooklyn yesterday and escaped with $70,000 in cash and $350,000 in checks, the police reported.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 Al Bramlet, the head of the culinary union in Las Vegas, telephoned his daughter last Thursday afternoon and has not been heard from since. The search for him has gradually intensified until it now has Federal officials avidly though unofficially interested.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 President Carter symbolized a promised new era of Federal-state cooperation today by inviting four dozen governors to the White House for a two-and-a-half-hour meeting with his Cabinet and top advisers.

A key part of the Beame administration's plan for New York City's fiscal recovery the diversion of $50 million in Federal community-development funds to help meet normal city expenses is being bitterly opposed by an expanding coalition of neighborhood and antipoverty groups from all over the city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) At the request of Alexander I. Solzhenitsyn, the trial lawyer Edward Bennett Williams has agreed to help defend an imprisoned Soviet dissident.
Despite adverse economic news, the stock market advanced slightly yesterday in the slowest trading in more than three months.

BONN, Feb. 28 One of West Germany's most prominent nuclear physicists had frequent contacts with an internationally sought terrorist over a period of at least six months in 1975-76, the Government in Bonn has charged.

Governor Carey's commission on postsecondary education intends to recommend today that two new and primarily state-financed systems of public higher education be established to replace the existing City and State Universities.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced that it will file suit in the Venezuelan Supreme Court to recover its investment in a nationalized oil concession near Lake Maracaibo.

A move by the Securities and Exchange Commission to make the Boeing Company disclose the identities of 18 highly-placed consultants it had hired was blocked at least temporarily yesterday by a Federal Appeals Court order. The court ruled that the names of the consultants, contained in a motion filed by the S.E.C., remain under seal.

Three suits one alleging fraud by New York City and seven large banks, and two others challenging the constitutionality of the Municipal Assistance Corporation are at the heart of the banks' uneasiness over participating in a solution to New York's moratorium debt problem.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) A top Justice Department official agreed today to investigate whether an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation broke into the home of a member of Congress or spied on her campaign operations for the bureau.
Daniel P. O'Connell, the strong-willed patriarch of Democratic politics in Albany, died there yesterday of a respiratory ailment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Carter Administration told a Senate subcommittee today that it had reversed the Ford Administration's policy and would support passage of a law barring American companies from taking part in an Arab economic boycott of Israel.
Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has Donald I. Baker, the holdover antitrust chief from the Ford Administration, that his services as an assistant attorney general won't be needed after May 31.

The St. Joe Minerals Corporation has instituted the fourth round of price increases this year for lead. The company said it was raising its price by 2 cents to 31 conts a pound, effective immediately. Other concerns following suit included: NL Industries Inc.; the Bunker Hill Company, a subsidiary of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, and Amax Lead and Zinc Inc., a subsidiary of Amax Inc.
KUWAIT, Feb. 28 (UPI) A Japanese company will begin construction work on a Kuwaiti naval base under a multimillion-dollar agreement signed today.

Union representatives and a broad spectrum of religious groups leveled repeated attacks and criticism at the labor and hiring policies of J.P. Stevens Company at a crowded annual stockholders' meeting yesterday.

Zoning is often interpreted by builders as a challenge to see how minimal their compliance with the regulations can be. In the case of incentive zoning, in which the builder is allowed bonus space in exchange for providing desirable public features, the assumption is that a bigger building will be offset by environmental benefits. Openspace zoning, in particular, has given builders 20 percent more floor area in return for a street-level plaza.

LOS ANGELS, March 1 (AP) Margaret McComb, wife of Marshall McComb a California Supreme Court Justice, has been named conservator for her husband, giving her the right to make nonjudicial decisions for the 82-year-old judge. Mrs. McComb said that the judge could no longer care for himself or his property.

WASHINGTON, March 1 President Carter said today that he favored extending a special Federal loan program for New York City for "five to six years" beyond its June 30, 1978, expiration date. But the President, in impromptu remarks to Defense Department employees at the Pentagon, said there would be no Federal help to solve the city's immediate threat of bankruptcy.

DETROIT, March 1 The first of a long list of prospective jurors were questioned today at the start of the trial of two Filipino nurses, accused of poisoning patients at the Veterans Hospital in nearby Ann Arbor. Selection of the 12-member jury is expected to be prolonged.

MEDICARE has proved to be something of a Catch-22 for people over age 65. It was originally designed to help take up some of the slack left by private health-insurance plans. Rising medical costs have so eroded the value of Medicare, however, that private health insurance has become more important than ever.

Miss Comaneci's illness has caused the cancellation of a five-city American tour by five Rumanian gymnasts, slated to begin March 15.

Miss Hayami is a painstakingly precise technician and an orderly musical thinker. Her rather literal, almost petit-point style would not appear to be suitable to everything in the repertory, the Romantics, for instance, but in the music that she did choose to play such an approach had its strong points.

MONTREAL, March 1 Quebec concluded successfully today its first sale of bonds on the Canadian market since the separatist government came into power last November.

The recent news that a Brooklyn construction worker got a kidney transplant by way of Moscow puzzled us. The kidney was flown here after being removed from a young victim of a Moscow automobile accident. Since the United States boasts many more auto accidents than the Soviet Union, it struck us as odd that any American should have to look to the Russians for a used kidney.

William Allen Patty Sr., a tax-law specialist who was a retired vice president, director and general counsel of the National Liberty Corporation, an insurance company, of Valley Forge, Pa., died Saturday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He lived at Pleasant Valley Farm, Lambertville, N.J., and was 70 years old.
In an effort to reverse lagging registrations which would endanger the university's future the City Universiy has begun a wide-ranging program of inducements to make enrollment more attractive.

FOR THE THIRD year, the dancer Rudolf Nureyev has given a solo season with his friends at the Uris Theater. The pattern re- mains constant, only the program varies. And the present program is possibly the most interesting of the three. While it does not show Mr. Nureyev as a pure classicist, it does offer most aspects of his dramatic persona.

THE famous 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux has been under attack almost since the time it was prepared by the Bordeaux Chamber of Commerce for an international exposition to be held that year in Paris.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1 People predicted that Reggie Jackson's presence on the Yankees could create problems, and no sooner did the expensive, outspoken, uninhibited star arrive today than the Yankees had trouble.

UNIONDALE, L. I., March 1 You have to be virtually perfect to beat the Montreal Canadiens these days. Tonight at Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders were perfect almost. But a two-minute lapse in the second period allowed the Canadiens to score three goals and go on to win, 5-4.

VIENNA, March 1 The president of the oil cartel's policy-setting ministers' conference said today that he thought a compromise to end the current price split within the group might be achieved before July.

An intrusion into the home of a Queens couple by two would-be robbers ended in a shootout last night that left one of the intruders dead and the other seriously wounded, the police reported. Also wounded were the husband and a friend of the couple's who had foiled the robbers by shooting it out with them.

Fourth-quarter earnings of the Warner Lambert Company, a producer of drugs and optical and scientific products, fell by 31.6 percent to $21 million, or 27 cents a share, from $30.7 million or 39 cents a share, for 1975's final quarter.

BONN, March, 1 A West German atomic physicist accused by the Government of having "close relations with international terrorists and their sympathizers" denied it today and demanded a formal exoneration from the Interior Ministry.

Dr. Adele Franklin, founder of an innovative and influential program for elementary school children in underprivileged areas of New York City, died Monday in South Bend, Ind., where she had been hospitalized for two years. She was 80 years old and had lived at 470 West 24th Street.

LONDON, March 2 Foreign Secretary David Owen said today that the United Nations Human Rights Commission had turned down a British proposal for an investigation of developments in Uganda but that Britain would continue to press for an inquiry.

MOSCOW, March 2 In response to the Carter Administration's complaints about Soviet violations of human rights, the official press has been counterattacking the United States as a land of political arrests and paper freedoms.
A police officer fatally shot a 29-yearold former mental patient last night after he lunged at him and another officer with an ax, a police spokesman reported.

The major New York City banks have informally submitted stringent new proposals for an independent agency to control city budgets, but City Hall aides said the proposals were "stiffer" than what had been offered so far and were very likely "unacceptable" to Mayor Beame.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 This is the place where it all fell apart for Rutgers last year. The Spectrum proved to be the chamber of horrors, the gym where the flame went out on Rutgers's hopes for an unbeaten national championship team, crushing team pride like a stale cigarette butt.
WASHINGTON The highly charged and often unfocused argument over whether the United States can finance future prosperity without major policy changes seems suddenly to have vanished.

The Puerto Rican Traveling Theater has found a permanent home in the Broadway area. The five-story building at 304 West 47th Street, a former firehouse, will be converted into a modern plant for the group, now celebrating its 10th anniversary. The company, directed by Miriam Colon, performs in English and Spanish.

The wind chill factor is doing some people a lot of good. The manufacturers of potions that help keep hands smooth are rubbing their own soft hands with pleasure a they contemplate what one of them calls an "explosion" in the hand care market.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 2 The tall blond trooper with the flashes of the Rhodesian Light Infantry on his uniform sat in a mountain hotel along the Mozambique border nursing a beer and reflecting on the Government's successes in the struggle against black insurgents.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the Boeing Company for alleged payoffs to high government officials in Canada, Japan, Portugal and Egypt, according to court records made public today.

ATLANTA, March 2 (AP) The national Center for Disease Control issued a warning today that at least 600 Americans who attended an arts festival in Lagos, Nigeria, may have been exposed to a particularly severe form of malaria.

When the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, a wholesale drug distributor, took on a $405 million contract last year to administer. North Carolina's Medicaid Program through computerized processing methods, some investors assumed that the company would soon teach the bureaucrats a lesson in efficiency.
PARIS, March 2 West Germany has firmly rejected a renewed effort by the Carter Administration to persuade it to stimulate the German economy with expansionary, short-term measures.
After 50 years of grappling with disputes in labor, commerce, insurance and consumerism, the American Arbitration Association is stepping into the ring with husbands and wives.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 2 Bette Davis, whose movie career began almost 50 years ago and spans more than 80 films, was honored by Hollywood last night when she became the first woman to receive the Life Achievement Award of the American Film Institute.
The rumor winds that have buffeted Barbara Walters at ABC News for months have now shifted to her colleague, Harry Reasoner, and to the president of the ABC News division, William Sheehan.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. David Crocker had an unusual problem, He was a rich kid, part of the "ruling class," and he didn't particularly want to be.

On the eve of the resumption of talks aimed at averting the bankruptcy of New York City, bank officials said yesterday that they were optimistic that a solution could be worked out. But union officials reiterated their opposition to the stringent financial controls that the banks are demanding.
TORONTO, March 3 At first, she thought it was merely a bruised ankle. It hurt but not that much. Then, she saw blood flowing from a deep gash.

And so, Doctor, how do you feel about allowing a baby to cry? Dr. A: Well, I wouldn't pick the baby up too readily. You know it teaches them that you're going to respond to every whim. Oh, it's hard, sure, but you have to learn to restrain yourself and let the baby cry it out, at least for brief periods.
"Sameness in food and habits depresses; variety stimulates," an ancient though anonymous Chinese philosopher is supposed to have said.

MOSCOW, March 3 Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet Union's most celebrated human-rights activist, has been locked in a mundane struggle familiar to millions of ordinary Soviet citizens. He is trying to move into a new apartment.

The excessive portions of income that more and more families are paying for adequate housing mark a significant new form of "housing deprivation" in the United States, according to a major study made public yesterday.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 3 Mayor James Robinson of Montgomery unexpectedly resigned today, saying that he was no longer willing to "bear the burden" of criticism for the way he handled a police department scandal over the last 14 months.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) President Carter today appointed a Georgia woman as Under Secretary of the Treasury and a University of Massachusetts vice president to be Under Secretary or Housing and Urban Development. Both will be paid $52,500 a year.

WASHINGTON, March 3 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Amsterdam Stock Exchange have begun discussions on options trading that could lead to a major breakthrough in the international regulation of securities.

BRUSSELS, March 3 (AP) Prime Minister Leo Tindemans has asked two of his Cabinet ministers to resign, starting a political crisis that could topple his coalition Government and lead to general elections a year early.

LYONS, France, March 3 (AP) Eugenie Brazier, whose quiet rebellion against ostentation in French cuisine brought her to the highest ranks of the predominantly male world of great chefs, is dead at 81.
MOSCOW, March 3 (Reuters) The American Embassy today delivered its second protest this week to the Foreign Ministry following the seizing of two Jewish activists who tried to meet a diplomat.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 Real estate development loans to a spa in a remote area of Southern California have seriously depleted the reserves of a union pension fund, and two trustees resigned in protest when the loans were made, according to confidential sources.

WASHINGTON, March 3 Six weeks after President Carter took office, fewer than half the major sub-Cabinet positions in his Administration have been officially filled, and some Administration officials privately say these delays in appointments are hampering the functioning of various departments and agencies.

ONLY TWO BLOCKS long, Beekman Place has been called the most exclusive enclave in Manhattan. John D. Rockefeller 3d lives there, as do Huntington Hartford, Mark Goodson, Irving Berlin, Julie Newmar and Princess Ashraf Pahlavi, the Shah of Iran's twin sister.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 3 Allegations of brutality on the part of the Ulster police during questioning of suspects believed to belong to the Irish Republican Army led today to demands for an independent inquiry into interrogation methods.

CAIRO, March 3 Foreign ministers from some 60 Arab and African countries began work here today on a program for political and economic cooperation between black Africa and the Arab world. They were immediately confronted with a plea from an African delegate that those Arabs with oil wealth share it more generously.
LONDON, March 3 (AP) Gold rose 25 cents to close at $144.875 an ounce in London today, a day after the International Monetary Fund gold auction in Washington brought an average price of $146.51.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, March 4 (AP) Thai insurgents ambushed a convoy in a mountainous northern area yesterday, killing 29 civilians with automatic-rifle fire and grenades in what military authorities here described today as one of the costliest attacks by rebels in the 12-year-long conflict with the Government.
"Last night around 11 o'clock, suddenly no one could remember what day it was," said the banker. They had to stop to figure it out. "Do we have to get this thing in this morning or the next?"

SOME DAY, perhaps some New York museum will give us a retrospective exhibition of the art of Richard Lindner. Paris has already had one, and it seems odd that New York, where this German-born painter has lived much of his life since the 1950's and which has so decisively influenced the iconography of his art, should be denied a comprehensive survey of his extraordinary oeuvre.
AKRON, Ohio, March 3 (AP) B.F. Goodrich Company has proposed a binding arbitration plan intended to avert what it calls "the trial by ordeal" of strikes.

Bowie Kuhn approved Charles O. Finley's $400,000 sale of Paul Lindblad, the relief pitcher, from Oakland to the Texas Rangers yesterday. But the baseball commissioner said he would keep a sharp eye on future dealing by the controversial owner of the A's.

A year and a half ago, a charitable way of describing Mayor Beame's role in New York City's fiscal crisis was that it was on the sidelines. Today, there may be a sense of deja vu about much of the city's emergency, but one thing is different: Mr. Beame is in the middle, handling the negotiations and himself accepting the enormous risk of failure.

Another new magazine for women is in the works. This one, Savvy The Magazine for the Executive Woman, is the creation of Judith Daniels, former managing editor of The Village voice and New York magazine.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 The New York Mets made "a final offer" today to Dave Kingman and also executed two technical steps to keep him from becoming a free agent immediately; they renewed his 1976 contract under the rules and cut his pay the maximum of 30 percent.

PARIS, March 3 Some members of a group of militant Roman Catholics who are demanding a return to Latin masses beat a priest unconscious this morning inside a church that the group has been occupying in the Latin Quarter since last Sunday.
WASHINGTON, March 3 President Carter has decided to name Daniel O'Neal chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, it was learned today.
President Carter's negative comments on unionization of the armed forces have focused attention on the often heated debate over the subject that has agitated the services in the last three months.

Emphasizing that he spoke as a "political independent," Donald I. Baker, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division of the Department of Justice, declared here yesterday the division had a tough, strong hard-working staff of professionals and that he hoped "for a continuation of the present antitrust program under the Carter Administration."

WASHINGTON, March 3 The Navy's quest for another Nimitz-class nuclearpowered carrier foundered in the well of the House today when a proposal for further funding of the $2.2 billion ship was voted down, 262 to 161.
BUENOS AIRES, March 3 The Argentine military, Government today banned the publication and circulation of antihouse here and ordered the confiscation of its publications now on sale.

Claude Arpels, the president of VanCleef Arpels, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on a charge that he had given gifts to an agent of the Internal Revenue Service who was auditing the tax returns of the well-known Fifth Avenue jewelry store.

The credit markets, responding to news of smaller-than-budgeted Federal spending a substantial decrease in factory orders and declines in the nation's money supply, moved toward higher prices and lower interest rates yesterday for a sec ond day.

LONDON, March 3 Britain's new Foreign Secretary, David Owen, said today in his first major speech that the Soviet bloc must recognize that "concern for human rights is not a diversionary tactic but an integral part of foreign policy in the Western democracies."

NASSAU, the Bahamas In the sudden growth of international banking in the Bahamas, no institution has played as prominent a role as Citibank, the United States's second largest bank and, in the scope of its global activities, the most truly international bank in the world.

TRENTON, March 3 The State of New Jersey asked the State Superior Court in Elizabeth today to order the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to help pay the $50 million cost of building a new approach to the Newark International Airport.

Federally insured savings and loan associations reported net new savings receipts of $4.8 billion in January, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday. This was the second largest volume on record, exceeded only by the $5.1 billion of net savings received in January 1976.

WASHINGTON, March 3 Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that "the investigation of all substantial leads in the Korean C.I.A. case is continuing" and that he intended to prosecute cases where proof of criminal violations was found.

WASHINGTON, March 3 Tip O'Neill of Massachusetts has just moved into his new headquarters as Speaker of the House of Representatives, and it is now becoming clear in Washington that when this gentle giant moves anywhere, people tend to get out of his way.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, March 4 (AP) A Vietnamese Foreign Ministry spokesman, quoted by Hanoi's official press agency, said today that Vietnam was prepared "to consider and to settle" the question of Americans missing in action in the Indonchina war.

WASHINGTON, March 3 Mayor Beame made a whirlwind visit here today and left with a grab bag of promises that he interpreted to mean: 10,000 federally supported housing starts in New York in the next 12 months and a speed-up in selling off city-held mortgages to obtain $200 million by June 30.

Two men were arrested in Norwalk, Conn., late yesterday afternoon, as they returned a blue van to a rental agency, and were charged with the murder on Wednesday of two young mothers in the quiet Westchester community of Lewisboro, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, March 3 Without opposition and with little debate, the Senate approved today a bill that would give President Carter the broad authority he requested to reorganize the Government.
A plan that could give the improverished South Bronx a new shopping center and college campus and 3,000 new jobs was announced yesterday by Bronx community and political leaders.

NEWARK, March 3 Eight of Newark's nine City Council members called today for the resignation of the head of the city's public school system on the grounds of poor leadership and failure to carry out essential educational reforms.

Increasingly strained relations between Governor Carey and organized labor broke into the open yesterday when the 29-member executive council of the New York State A.F.L-C.I.O. rejected the Governor's invitation to meet with him at dinner next Wednesday.

MIAMI, March 3 (AP) A Federal grand jury has indicted five men for fraud in an alleged investment scheme that bilked former Vietnam prisoners of war out of $1.9 million through a now-defunct bond firm, the authorities said today.

Sandy Stewart, who used to sing on Perry Como's television show and who won a Grammy Award for her record of "My Coloring Book" in 1962, is being rediscovered by enthusiastic audiences at the Ballroom, where she is resuming the career she once thought she had left behind.

The Carter Administration yesterday endorsed the idea, strongly espoused by the outgoing Republicans, that American industry was running short of investment capital and needs tax concessions and other Federal aid to stimulate fresh investment.
Prices of gold and silver futures fell yesterday after climbing spectacularly for several sessions.
Firemen will return to the so-called "People's Firehouse" in Brooklyn for the first time in 15 months under a compromise reached last night between the city and community activists.

The Abercrombie Fitch Company, the nine-store chain catering to affluent sportsmen, announced yesterday that it might soon emerge from the Chapter XI provisions of the Bankruptcy Act after having reached an agreement in principle on a repayment arrangement with the official creditors' committee.

MADRID, March 3 The leaders of the Spanish, Italian and French Communist parties called today for the "full application" of the 1975 Helsinki accords, which included pledges by both Eastern and western countries of respect for human rights. But the three leaders did not specifically mention recent attacks on dissidents in the Soviet bloc countries.

The Flushing National Bank, whose suit upset New York City's moratorium on repaying $1 billion in short-term notes, was awarded $790,000 yesterday by Justice James Gibson of State Supreme Court, the judge designated to handle the case. In addition, Flushing National is to receive 6 percent interest from June 30, the date the notes matured.

Veterinary specialization is unlikely to merit bold print in The New York Times usually, but on Dec. 9, 1976, it printed a headline "Doctor of Bovinity." FOLLOWING HIS success with "The Threepenny Opera" at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center, Richard Foreman has returned to his tiny shadowbox loft theater for a new Ontological-Hysteric Theater opus, "Book of Splendors: Part Two (Book of Levers): Action at a Distance."

Edgar Ansel Mowrer, Pulitzer Prize winner, foreign correspondent and columnist, author of a dozen books, and the reporter who for millions of Americans was the man on the scene with the Third Reich, entered journalism accidentally as a favor to his older brother.

WASHINGTON, March 3 There are 129 embassies in this city, from Afghanistan to Zambia, housed in buildings that range from converted hotels to Georgian-style mansions, a part of the official Washington landscape whose real function is only vaguely understood.

FALUN, Sweden, March 3 (AP) Josef Rusko, a virtually unknown Czechoslovak ski jumper, scored the biggest upset of the season by winning the 70-meter special-hill contest at the 28th Swedish Nordic games tonight. The 20-year-old produced two nearly flawless jumps.
YAPHANK, L.I., March 3 Ronald Parr is heading for the most grueling homestretch that his race track, Parr Meadows, will ever see.

WHEN it comes to gimmicks, I'm as susceptible as the next gardener. Some novelties really do work as well as they say, which is why, I suppose, I keep trying out the new gardening gadgets. Others well they're like planting mushroom spawn around the Alamo. Who needs them? And they just don't work.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 3 (UPI) Bjorn Borg, starting his match with a show of temper, rallied and beat John Lloyd, 0-6, 6-2, 6-4, today in the third round of the United States national indoor tennis championships. The 20year-old Swede, who cursed an official and demanded his ejection from a match yesterday was obviously upset today by a pregame remark made by a public address announcer and put up no fight in the first set.

Thomas Spinelli and Michael Strolla, two former officials of Chemical Bank branches in the Bronx, pleaded guilty yesterday to income-tax charges involving payments they received for exchanging large amounts of cash for narcotics dealers.

LEWISBORO, N.Y., March 3 New York and Connecticut police were searching today for a blue van and two men whose burglary of a home in this quiet Westchester community ended at dusk yesterday in the murder of two young mothers.

The Leningrad Symphony Orchestra, identified with Dmitri Shostakovich's Symphony No.7, inspired by the heroic resistance of Leningrad to the Nazis in a 900-day siege, will be playing its most famous orchestral work at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8 P.M.

GRANNIS, Ark., March 1 The large number of Indochinese refugees brought here to ease the labor shortages of a poultry-processing plant is dwindling rapidly as many find they cannot earn enough in the recently depressed industry to pay the rent on their company-owned mobile homes.

The New York Rangers' half-hearted playoff drive sputtered again last night in a 4-1 loss to the Boston Bruins in Madison Square Garden. The defeat left Coach John Ferguson wondering whether his team of youngsters and older players really wanted to be in postseason play.

The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor, had a 4 percent earnings rise in the fourth quarter and a 17.9 percent rise for the full year. The higher earnings were attributed to "fine performances by the aerospace and marine groups," David S. Lewis, chairman, reported yesterday.

HACKENSACK, March 3 A Year-old taxi-licensing fee that has all but eliminated cab service at the Meadowlands sports Complex in East Rutherford was declared illegal and invalid today in State Superior Court.

ANTHONY CAVE BROWN, the Washington-based British journalist who specializes in military-diplomatic affairs, was walking down the hall on the 13th floor of the modern military records section of the National Archives when he spotted a rickety wooden cart stacked with a number of tattered document boxes, Each box was labeled "MED Official History."

As a result, it is the only band in town that offers bass-saxophone duets that, as played by Sam Parkins and Vinnie Giordano galumphing through "Sweet Georgia Brown," for instance are wondrously deep-throated swinging things.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Two hundred thirty of the nation's wealthiest individuals paid no Federal income taxes in 1975, the Treasury Department reported today. But the agency predicted that that number would shrink substantially for 1976 because of changes in the tax law.

Herman Ausubel, a Columbia University history professor and an authority on Victorian England, died yesterday of cancer at his home at 35 Claremont Avenue. He was 56 years old.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 3 What seemed to have the makings of an international skiing controversy was settled this morning at this plush Sawtooth Range resort. Austrian officials withdrew their protest and agreed to have their World Cup teams compete in downhill races at Heavenly Valley, Calif., March 11 and 12. The decision followed a series of discussions between Austrian and American officials.

On the eve of the resumption of talks aimed at averting the bankruptcy of New York City, bank officials said yesterday that they were optimistic that a solution could be worked out. But union officials reiterated their opposition to the stringent financial controls that the banks are demanding.

WASHINGTON, March 3 Louis T. Gambaccini, director of rail transportation for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, has been offered the job of administrator of the Urban Mass Transit Administration here.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (Reuters) Factory orders fell 2.1 percent in January from the December level to a seasonally adjusted $105.35 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday dismissed charges that Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic chairman; Councilman Stephen Kaufman of the Bronx, and Jerome Glanzrock, a former Bronx Democratic district leader, had tried to intimidate a weekly newspaper in the Bronx.

DETROIT, March 3 The domestic automobile industry reported today that sales of new cars in the Feb. 21-28 period fell only 40 units below the year-earlier level and that deliveries for the full month were up 2.4 percent from February 1976 despite lingering effects of the bitterly cold winter.

In their fourth annual concert in New York since 1974, Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann, a cello-piano duo, gave the first performance of Benjamin Lees's "Dialogue for Cello and Piano."

MINEOLA, L.I., March 3 A primary contest for the Democratic nomination for Nassau County Executive appeared likely today as David H. Peirez announced his candidacy.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 3 (UPI) The Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, with Prime Minister Fidel Castro of Cuba at his side, presided last night over the renaming of the country and a governmental shuffle, according to the Libyan press agency.

Two-tiered copper pricing lasted just one day as all major producers raised their prices for refined copper to 71 cents a pound yesterday. Asarco Inc. and the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company, which led the latest round of price hikes on Wednesday with increases of 2 cents a pound to 70 cents, decided early yesterday afternoon to tack on another penny and meet their competitors at 71 cents a pound.

Three human characteristics lack of consideration for others, need for recognition and approval and greed for power create damaging competitiveness on the job among managers, according to a survey just released by the American Management Associations. The A.M.A. is a nonprofit research and educational organization supported by business.

Suzanne Tanzer Pogany of New York and Weston, Conn., was married yesterday morning to H. Jerome Berns of New York and Palm Springs, Calif., a widower. He is vice president, secretary and associate of the "21" Club.

Dr. David M. Levy, a pioneer in child psychiatry who introduced the Rorschach test for measuring personality traits and general intelligence to the United States and coined such terms as "sibling rivalry," died Tuesday in his apartment at 993 Fifth Avenue. He was 84 years old.
SACRAMENTO, March 3 The first state bill regulating the controversial genetic research called recombinant DNA was introduced today in the California Legislature.

TOKYO, March 3 (AP) Linda Fratianne of Northridge, Calif., won the women's world figure skating championship today, saving herself with grace and technical control after a fall in the important free-skating event. The 16-year-old United States champion, received 10 ordinals and 189.26 points, which means that eight of the nine judges gave her first place and one gave her second.
GRANNIS, Ark., March 1 This southwestern Arkansas hamlet probably received the biggest population percentage increase from the influx of lndochinese refugees of any community in the country.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 3 Lord Faulkner, a prominent Protestant politician and former premier, was killed today in a riding accident near Saintfield, County Down, 12 miles south of Belfast. He was 56 years old.

Klaus Tennstedt, suffering from what is described as severe bronchitis, was unable to conduct his second round of concerts starting last night with the New York Philharmonic. Into the breach jauntily stepped David Gilbert, the assistant conductor of the orchestra. This was probably what he has been dreaming about ever since he took the post. This is what every understudy dreams about.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) In an action that could lead to higher sugar prices, the International Trade Commission agreed today that the domestic sugar industry is being jeopardized by rising imports.

LLYN FOULKES has not shown in New York since 1975, when his exhibition at the Willard Gallery was widely noted for its ghoulish wit and its readiness to turn the conventional picture-process inside out. He has now returned to town and can be seen (through March 19) at the Gruenebaum Gallery, 25 East 77th Street.

They released their prisoners last night unharmed and surrendered peacefully early today.

JERSEY CITY, March 3 Mayor Paul T.Jordan sat in the audience at the Downtown Holiday Inn today as William Macchi, the man he wants as his successor, formally announced his candidacy.

DETROIT, March 3 The Islanders got the first laugh tonight in their game with the Detroit Red Wings when Lorne Henning scored his sixth shorthanded goal of the season,a little more than 3 minutes from the start.
