Many years ago a science fiction writer published a short story about how human beings might get to the moon via free-enterprise financing. Moon concessions were sold to various corporations, giving one the monopoly of prospecting for diamonds, another the exclusive right to manufacture soft drinks, and so forth. With the money thus raised, the first man was sent to the moon.

MOSCOW, March 4 The Government newspaper Izvestia today accused several leading dissidents, all of them Jews, of working for the Central Intelligence Agency. Tonight, according to Jewish sources, apartments of several of the dissidents were being searched and some of them believed that arrests were imminent.

The athletic exuberance that makes Danny Williams Grossman's dancing such a pleasure to watch characterizes his choreography as well. Mr. Grossman showed a gymnastically graceful duet to audiences in the Delacorte Theater last summer that was tantalizing. And he brought his full company to the American Theater Laboratory on Thursday evening for his official debut as choreographer. The company and program proved very good.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (Reuters) The Securities and Exchange Commission said it reached an agreement with the Allied Chemical Corporation in settlement of a complaint charging Allied with antifraud violations under the Securities Exchange Act. S.E.C. said Allied failed to disclose potential financial losses it might suffer from discharging toxic chemicals, including Kepone, into the environment from its own and other facilities.

NORTH PLATTE, Neb., March 3 In the great sweep of the High Plains from here southward to the old "dust bowl" areas, thousands of acres of range and crop land are so dry today and the cover on them is so sparse that they are on the verge of destruction by the wind.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.I., March 4 In the finished basement of Giants Stadium, where the National Football League's best-pampered 3-11 team plays, Clyde Powers was driving golf balls, talking about printing and feeling sorry that he was not working with handicapped children.
The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the rule making organization for accounting practices, yesterday issued two technical interpretations to clarify application of its accounting standards.
William Miller, a lawyer specializing in government tax policy, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

TOKYO, March 4 (AP) Irina Moiseyeva and Andrei Minenkov of the Soviet Union regained the ice dancing title tonight at the world figure skating championships. The Russian pair, champion in 1975 and runner-up last year, was the unanimous choice of the judges for first place after an elegant and theatrical free-skating program, receiving nine ordinals and 207.82 points.
After the cold and the snow came the deluge. Yesterday's downpour, actually a preview of the first spring shower, brought a swift change from arctic to rain gear.

The municipal labor unions, locked in a seemingly irreconcilable clash with the city's banks over solving New York's money problems, believe that the current crisis will he solved next week through intervention by Albany or Washington, if necessary, and that it will not end in the unions' caving in or in default.

NEWARK, March 4 The New Jersey Supreme Court is preparing an opinion that could lead to the jailing of five Newark City Councilmen for their refusal to vote the necessary funds for revaluation of property in this city.

Hundreds of people in Bucharest were reported to have been killed in a strong earthquake that rocked Southern and Eastern Europe. The center of the Rumanian capital was said to have been nearly destroyed. The quake, which according to a witness lasted about five minutes, was centered north of Bucharest. [Page 1, Columns 2-4.]
A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday ordered the closing by June 5 of the debtridden French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center at 330 West 30th Street.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, thanks to the rising profitability of its 21 operating subsidiaries, is prospering mightily.

OTTAWA, March 4 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today asked the national regulatory body for broadcasting to investigate charges that members of the French-language news staff and other personnel of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the government-owned network, have shown a bias in favor of independence for Quebec.

The major New York City banks, in a long-awaited counterproposal on the future structure of city finances, urged yesterday the formation of a new statedominated Budget Review Board, with sweeping powers over city budgets, a suggestion that was swiftly rejected by Mayor Beame.

MOSCOW, March 4 A State Department medical team reported today that Soviet health authorities had twice refused to provide basic data requested for an investigation into unusual blood counts found among American Embassy personnel here.
BONN, March 4 President Carter's open support of dissidents in the Soviet Union is beginning to cause nervousness in Western Europe as a result of Moscow's increasingly bitter reactions.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., March 4 (UPI) Charles Morrow Wilson, author and journalist, of Putney, Vt., died of cancer Wednesday in a hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 71 years old.

Maria T. Cueto, director of the National Commission of Hispanic Affairs for the Protestant Episcopal Church, refused to answer a Federal grand jury's questions yesterday concerning a Puerto Rican terrorist group known as the FALN.

The Singer Company announced yesterday that its own audit committee had found that the company made numerous questionable payments to officials of foreign countries since Januay 1971, including payments of $1.5 million to procure business in five operations abroad.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) The Senate confirmed today President Carter's nomination of Judge Wade H. McCree of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit to be Solicitor General, the No. 3 post in the Justice Department. He will be the highest-ranking black in the department.

MADISON, Wis., March 5 (AP) Iowa grabbed five individual titles, including a second consecutive 177pound championship by Chris Campbell, and rolled up 107 points today to capture the Big Ten wrestling cham- pionship with ease.

For most New Yorkers, the streams of Manhattan survive only in street names or old maps. Maiden Lane recalls the time when young Dutch washerwomen soaked dirty laundry in the brook along that street. Canal Street was such a swampy place that High tides sometimes bisected the island. And the name Gramercy Park was derived from the Dutch Krom Moerasje or Crooked Little Swamp.

IN ITS HEYDAY, five or six decades ago, the boards of the Palace Theater in South Norwalk supported the substantial talent of Mae West, Webber Fields, Houdini and other headliners. Like the Danbury Opera House and many New England theaters, the 1,000-seat art deco Palace was strictly legit playing everything from trained seals to "Il Trovatore."

At a human rights rally here yesterday for Vladimir K. Bukovsky, the deported Soviet dissident, cheers and applause erupted from the audience of Ukrainian and Russian emigres when the chairman reminded them that the day was the 24th anniversary of the death of Stalin, "the most disgusting dictator in the world," as one speaker declared.

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Eaton of New York City and Gallatin, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Louise Eaton, to Roger David London, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. London of Pound Ridge, N.Y.

In St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon, Deborah Anne Proctor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dean Wesley Proctor of New York, became the bride of Robert Burnett Ill, son of Edmund Waldemar Ill. Jr. of Mantoloking, N.J., and the late Jeanne McCormick Ill. The Rev. Gerard Di Senso performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

It should have been a happy moment for Jimmy Jackson. His Boys High team had just captured the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track championship at the 102d Engineers Armory, the first title for Jackson since he took over the coahring reins in 1973.

EUGENE R. KELLEY'S broadside attack on Special State Prosecutor Alfred J. Scotti, Suffolk District Attorney Henry F. O'Brien and the entire state Democratic party organization last Monday has left the Police Commissioner's fellow Suffolk Republicans shaking their heads with dismay and anger.

There were some 23,000 motor cars and 17 million horses in the United States on March 4, 1902, when members of nine fledgling automobile clubs met in Chicago and founded the American Automobile Association.

I WAS rather disappointed the other Sunday, that dreary snowy one. I was rather hoping that come big event would engulf us a storm or the sudden return of the Bicentennial, something really jolting and I would be in the position to write a major Long Island work, "A Sunday to Remember."

THE XEROX CORPORATION has filed a new patent infringement suit against the International Business Machines Corporation over its plain paper copying and duplicating equipment. Xerox previously sued I.B.M. in 1970, 1972 and 1973. I.B.M. denies it has infringed on Xerox's patents.

THERE is an important segment of the populace that will not eat fish. To them, fish means canned tuna and sardines, codfish cakes and that unspeakable thing called a fish stick. To them, fish means grease and breadcrumbs and nothing at all to do with the sea.

A glimpse from China of the world of Mao Tse-tung including the changing guard in Peking, the role of women and of the proletarian arts will soon appear in the United States in the form of a biography of Chairman Mao's widow, Chiang Ching.

Edgar Degas today is so universal a favorite that the Metropolitan Museum cannot fail to delight its public with its "Degas in the Metropolitan" exhibition. This consists of everything by Degas that is in the Museum's own collections, together with much related material from the same overflowing source. The show runs right through the summer (until September 4) and it offers us a manifold education.

When Mrs. D. Scott Severns decided to have a buffet supper after the recent concert in honor of Marian Anderson and Young Audiences, she also decided to use as a centerpiece a plain white plate with a dozen eggs around the rim.

STAMFORD'S HARTMAN Theater Company must feel very secure it has allowed competition to open directly across the street for a three-play season. Housed in a cinder-block rectangle that seats 99 people on folding chairs. The Company Store as the members of the Hartman Theater Conservatory, a two...

"HE WHO CUTS his own firewood warms himself twice." We've gone that old saying one better since installing a woodburning stove in our house. When the oil bill arrives each month, it is so low that our hearts, too, are warmed.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) The pilot was at fault in the fiery crash of an American Airlines jetliner that killed 37 persons on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands last April 27, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.
MILWAUKEE, March 5 (AP) Fifty years after a daring young Charles A.Lindbergh captured the world's fancy, the Spirit of St. Louis will fly again.
Angela M. Lyons, controller of the New York Public Library from 1964 to 1969, died Saturday at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. She was 77 years old and lived in Tudor City.

If the city fathers of New York are angered by the reluctance of the city's banks to lend them more money and alleviate the ongoing fiscal crisis, they need look no farther than Walter Bigelow Wriston to find a scapegoat for their woes.

KYALAMI, South Africa, March 5 The South African Grand Prix, won today by Niki Lauda of Austria in a Ferrari R312B, was marred by a bizarre accident in which a Welsh driver, Tom Pryce, and a South African track marshal were killed.

It is undoubtedly a rarity to find a novel of entertainment that is this well written. One immediately wants to consult some nonexistent oracle to help formulate the distinctions between literary, that is, serious, fiction and "mere" entertainment. One easy difference may be that the former usually concentrates on complexities of character and the latter on plot.
Helayne Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norris L. Hill of Venice, Fla., was married there yesterday afternoon to C. Giles Smith Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Smith of Rye, N.Y.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 5 In keeping with a kind of tradition that America's top men skiers are best at home sites Phil and Steve Mahre, the 19-year-old twins from White Pass, Wash., provided a surprise ending today to World Cup competition with a 1, 3 finish.

NEW CITY Putting muscle behind its heraldic motto, "Stronger Through Struggle," Rotterdam rose like a phoenix from the ashes of World War II. The port got top priority. Ring roads were built for easy access; new housing mushroomed; the Continent's largest concert and congress center was linked to a downtown pedestrian shopping mall. The landmark 15th-century St. Laurens Church was restored, museums opened and parks laid out.

Never in my career have I run into such curiosity about my travels as I did after the three trips I made to Russia in connection with "The Volga," a 60-minute television special, which I wrote, produced and directed for the National Geographic Society and WQED, Pittsburgh, and which will be telecast on Channel 13 this Tuesday at 8 P.M. Everyone wanted to know what it was like to work there.

PITTSBURGH, March 5 The executive board of the Pittsburgh branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that it planned to oppose the nomination of Mayor Peter F. Flaherty as Deputy Attorney General.

Maria T. Cueto, the former director of the Protestant Episcopal Church's National Commission on Hispanic Affairs, was ruled in contempt of court yesterday for her refusal to testify before a Federal grand jury that is looking into terrorist bombings claimed by the F.A.L.N.

If it seemed upon Jimmy Carter's victory that economics, domestic and foreign, would dominate the launching of the new Administration, now the specter of foreign policy is creeping back into the political arena. The old issues remain SALT, international economic cooperation, relations with the poor and wealthy third world, normalization of ties to China and Vietnam and so on. But an odd new issue has appeared: human rights.

DESPITE assurances of additional state aid from incometax revenue and declining enrollment, many New Jersey school districts are asking their municipalities for more money from local property taxes in their budgets for the 1977-78 fiscal year. There will be public hearings on the budgets this week.

INTERNATIONAL economic problems have slipped quietly into the background in this country during the early months of 1977 and quite naturally, since serious domestic issues and the effects of the abnormally cold weather have usurped so much attention. Before long, however, there could be a change in focus.

SENATOR FRANK J. DODD'S recent attempt (Feb. 6) to masquerade a deepwater port under the banner of environmental pro tection misrepresents the entire issue of environmental quality while urging support of a facility that is both illconceived and unwanted.

WASHINGTON In a sense, President Carter's espousal of human rights reflects a peculiarly Western concern. In most parts of the world, outside North America and Western Europe, there is no tradition of political freedom. Moreover, modern technology has given autocrats an unparalleled ability to direct, control and discipline their people.

In front of a palatial estate in Bel Air, tires crunch on the gravel parking lot and an unsteady saxophone howls the last bars of "Misty" in the cool evening air. "That's Bobby," notes an early dinner guest. "He's practicing for 'New York, New York,' the film about big bands he's shooting with Marty Scorsese."

MARCH is sort of an inventory month a look back and a look forward to summer garden plans. Will there be a vegetable patch this year? Based on poor harvests from last season's efforts, there may be some gardeners who decide to give up vegetables this summer and go all out for flowers.

The engagement of Martha Dandridge Bowers to Frederick Clifford Spogen 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spogen Jr. of Herkimer, N.Y., has been announced by Helen Wolcott Bowers of Fly Creek, N.Y., mother of the future bride.

Mr. and Mrs. James Frank Gilliam of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Gilliam, to Todd Durwood Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton D. Jacobson of Charlottesville, Va.

LOS ANGELES, March 5 Despite predictions two years ago that thousands of California doctors would relocate rather than pay malpractice insurance premiums as high as $26,956, a year, few physicians have left the state as their insurance rates rose as much as 327 percent, according to a report by the Rand Corporation.
The high price of coffee is encouraging many to consider other sorts of hot reviving drinks. For me, many herbs make healthful, refreshing teas. Some I find are more desirable than others.
For more than 15 years, both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal courts have played activist roles in implementing the securities laws.

Back in the days when the sun never set on the British empire, travel books were fun sometimes a delight to read. From Henry Fielding to Henry James to E.M. Forster, writers lavished on them all the talent and care due a work of art. Most of their readers were armchair travelers, for tours were then costly and time-consuming ventures to be planned well in advance and reflected on long afterward.

A belated happy birthday to Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari. The centennial of his birth came and went last year without anyone paying much notice, but London Records has just released two betterlate-than-never tributes to the composer: a performance of his most popular opera, the one-act farce "The Secret of Susanna," and a disk of overtures, intermezzos and dances drawn from five of his 13 operas.
The Soviet roll-on, roll-off ship, Skulptor Vuchetich, will be at sea today on the return leg of "record breaking" trans-Atlantic voyage.

WANTAGH ONCE a week, Lynn Bernstein visits a home in this Nassau County community to see a woman who suffers from a severe case of depression. Talking to the woman, Mrs. Bernstein helps her "work through" her fears and anxieties, bringing in the other members of the family from time to time to discuss their involvement in the woman's illness.

WHEN water starts seeping in through a crack or hole in the basement wall, most people think that repairs cannot be made until later in the year, after the ground has thoroughly dried and water is no longer seeping. This is true if ordinary patching cements are used, but special hydraulic cements can be used to plug holes and cracks in masonry even while water is still running through them.

WASHINGTON Four years after the draft was ended, the first serious questions are being raised, within the military and in Congress, about whether the nation can continue to maintain a two million-man military force on a volunteer basis.

THE IMPENDING "Battle Of Long Island Sound" will not be a delayed post-Bicentennial pageant to be staged by enthusiastic Rotarians from Stamford and Jaycees from Darien, arrayed in homespun blue uniforms and launching oak-ribbed longboats from the Stamford Yacht Club in the general direction of an imaginary British flotilla bobbing unsuspectingly off Huntington Harbor.

GENEVA, March 5 Some cracks have begun to appear in the overwhelming Communist, Arab and third world majority that had previously succeeded in largely confining the investigations of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to South Africa, Chile and the Israeli-occupied Arab territories.

Alex Haley writes about music affectionately and vividly in "Roots," his best-selling account of the successful search for his African ancestry. Talking drums send their messages from Juffure, the West African village where Haley's great-great-great-great-great grandfather Kunta Kinte is born and spends his youth, to neighboring communities.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 5 The Yankees have notified Sparky Lyle, their No. 1 left-handed relief pitcher, that they will take disciplinary action if he doesn't report to training camp by tomorrow.

In the final section of "A Moveable Feast," Ernest Hemingway's rich memoir of getting started in Paris in the 1920's, he wrote about Schruns and other neighboring villages of the 15-mile-long Montafon Valley on the Swiss-Austrian border.

PANAMA, March 3 The United States and Panama failed to achieve a major breakthrough during last month's round of canal treaty negotiations, but for the first time "the truly important substantive issues" were discussed in depth, according to Panama's chief negotiator.

MIAMI Cuban women here have shed a refugee mentality and adjusted to life in the United States faster than men and, in the process, have abandoned the submissive role their mothers had in Cuba's male-dominated society.

It must be disconcerting to the United States beyond the Hudson River to watch a virtually bankrupt New York City being dragged once more toward the brink of insolvency. The noisy struggle among our banks, unions and officialdom over the next phase of debt management is real enough, but they deserve a bit more understanding and patience if those qualities can still be mustered for Our Town.

PASCO, Wash. Some of the farmers who cultivate dry wheat here in the Columbia River basin are on the verge of deciding to plow under their winter crops and leave the ground fallow to save some of the precious moisture that remains after the worst drought in the West since the 1930's.

The jet was delayed at Kennedy Airport for six hours. The travel agent who had secured our cut-rate fares on Argentine Airlines ($636) apologized. "There has been a problem. You have read the papers?" He smiled helplessly.

Dorothy Hamill, America's figure skating queen, was recently trained to the International Best Dressed list for her hairstyle, not her clothes. Not since Sonja Henie, the blond and bejewelled star from Norway, took to the ice in a modified version of the ballet dancer's tu-tu in the 1930's, has there been a significant development in iceskating fashion.

WILLIAM C. SEITZ was unquestionably one of the leading figures of art in America. Had he been only a scholar, he would be grandly remembered for his vital perceptions into the work of artists such as Monet, Turner and Toulouse-Lautrec.

AS April 15 approaches, truckloads of tax returns are piled into the two major Internal Revenue Service centers for the North Atlantic region, in Andover, Mass., and in Holtsville. At the Holtsville facility, 2,400 seasonal workers have joined the 1,600 year-round employees to expedite the processing steps known as "the pipeline."
Howard E. Saft, a New York businessman, has received a three-year prison sentence in a white-collar crime case involving millions of dollars of bank loans for a jewelry company that went bankrupt.
Dr. and Mrs. Igor Tamm of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Elizabeth Tamm, to William James McKee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKee of Ardmore, Pa.

WHEN water starts seeping in through a crack or hole in the basement wall, most people think that repairs cannot be made until later in the year, after the ground has thoroughly dried and water is no longer seeping. This is true if ordinary patching cements are used, but special hydraulic cements can be used to plug holes and cracks in masonry even while water is still running through them.

SOMETHING strange is happening to New Jersey Republicans. Their well-known reputation for snatching defeat from the jaws of victory may be ruined this year if any more gubernatorial candidates take themselves out of the picture and leave the party relativeiy united.

LONDON, March 5 Prime Minister James Callaghan sets out for the United States next week in the hope of forging as close a relationship with President Carter as he had with former President Gerald R. Ford.

JERUSALEM From the Rabat conference of Arab states in October, 1974 to the fall of the Tell Zaatar camp in Beirut almost exactly two years later, the Palestine Liberation Organization indisputably led and spoke for the Palestinian people. During this period, the principle of Palestinian self-determination was recognized by the United Nations on the organization's terms even though the Palestinians rejected Israel's rights to political sovereignty.

Muddy Waters has been an imposing figure in the blues, probably the music's most imposing figure, since Alan Lomax recorded him for the Library of Congress in 1942. His Chess records of the 50's were so powerful and intense that few other bluesmen have come close to matching them. But lately Mr. Waters has been ill, and at his apparance during the Newport Jazz Festival last summer he was a shadow of his former self.

The engagement of Catharine Kim Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Walker of North Haven, Conn., to Per Torbjoern Bergstroem, son of Mr. and Mrs. Goesta Bergstroem of Storfors, Sweden, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A fall wedding is planned at the United Church on the Green in New Haven.

Suzanne Lindsay has a favorite necklace made of big navy beads and an old silver hashish box from Turkey. Once when she was wearing it, a policeman stopped and frisked her. Considering the way Suzanne usually dresses, however on an ordinary weekday she might wear the hashish-box necklace over a white silk shirt with a pair of navy Saint Laurent slacks.

On the island of Yamaca (the old West Indian spelling for Jamaica, also called the Isle of Many Rivers), many people would refer to the coin pictured here as "boonoonoonoos," which means something that is really nice. (Something that is not very nice would be "mecky mecky.")

I WOULDN'T exactly say it's sweeping the country. Or that as an idea it has fired the imaginations of the divorce judiciary or members of the bar who practice matrimonial law. Most judges, in fact, favor traditionally neat, uncomplicated solutions to family problems and wish they had never heard of it. But I think joint custody is, and should be, here to stay.

WHEN early Christian settlers on the Island buried their dead in the 17th and l8thcentury graves behind a church or, perhaps, in woods overlooking the sea, they marked the graves with carved stones reflecting how they viewed life and death. The beautiful, curious designs cut in the stones show a unique cross section of thought, carving and history from all over the Northeast of colonial America.

FEW bodies of water have inspired poets and painters as much as the Hudson River did in the 19th century, and it is little wonder. The river, which was once known as the "Rhine of America," was a magnificent panorama of nature, with its widely awesome stretches of water, the grandeur of its surrounding mountains, the graceful sloops that plied its waters and the sumptuous homes of the rich looking down upon its unspoiled wilderness.

Tina Gardner Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Gardner 3d of Middletown, Ohio, and Winter Park, Fla., was married yesterday evening to Peter Jason Locke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Locke of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Edwin W. Marohn performed the ceremony.

AFTER a string of successes in luring business from neighboring New York, Connecticut is now going further afield in its search for jobs and industry. A highpowered team of 11 Connecticut businessmen and officials is to leave Saturday for a week-long foray into West Germany in hopes of quickening the flow of German industries into the state.

The engagement of Mary Louise Gruber, an admissions counselor at Ursinus College, Collegeville, Pa., to Stephen J. Pollack, a vice president and shareholder with Drexel Burnham Company, member of the New York Stock Exchange, has been announced by the bride-to-be's mother, Mrs. Dempsey Gruber of Pottstown, Pa. Mr. Pollack is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pollack of Orwigsburg, Pa.

The river, which was once known as the "Rhine of America," was a magnificent panorama of nature, with its widely awesome stretches of water, the grandeur of its surrounding mountains, the graceful sloops that plied its waters and the sumptuous homes of the rich looking down upon its unspoiled wilderness.
TOWER CITY, Pa., March 5 A rescue team reached a miner trapped for more than four days in a flooded anthracite coal mine here and began efforts to bring him to the surface.
OPELIKA, Ala. If Jimmy Carter had listened to Millard Grimes, Mr. Grimes ruefully admits today, "he'd be only as close to the White House as the next tour."

POLITICAL "bosses" clearly constitute a potential issue in the bitter and unprecedented struggle over the Republican Domination for Nassau County Executive. The Republican county chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta, has decided on the basis of polls and informal soundings to attempt to deny renomination to the incumbent County Executive, Ralph G. Caso, and support instead the Hempstead Town Presiding Supervisor, Francis T. Purcell.

COULD it happen again? Could it happen in the United States? These are the basic questions being discussed in a popular University of Bridgeport lecture series, "Holocaust: Public Policy Implications," being presented this semester at 7:30 on Monday evenings through May 16, free to the general public.

WASHINGTON Old soldiers never die, they lobby. They do it so well that President Carter was given some friendly, but blunt, advice recently from the chairman of the House Committee on Veterans Affairs: Don't mess with the Veterans Administration.
The recent record cold wave may be melting from memories as spring approaches, but the havoc it played with the economy was starkly frozen in January's statistics.

The coming mayoral election and the city's fiscal crisis were satirized last night in patter, song and dance at the annual revue staged by The Inner Circle, an organization of New York political reporters, past and present.

Mickey Mantle's advice to promising high school baseball players: "There is good ball being played in college, and college ball is definitely replacing the minors. I tell kids to go to college, and that's where my four boys are now."

"Haywire" is a Hollywood childhood memoir, a glowing tapestry spun with equal parts of gold and pain. As a hook it is an absolute beauty a Hollywood beauty, to be precise with all the charm that term implies, the deceptive simplicity, the complex hidden machinery and, above all, the terrible cost.

LIVERPOOL, England, March 5 With some ifs, no ands and one definite butt, John Conteh retained his World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title tonight in a 7-minute-6-second bout against Len Hutchins of Detroit.

ANYONE in Fairfield County who still thinks that buses are for schoolchildren, mass transit is for cities and suburban streets are only for cars is in for a surprise sometime in the next few months, as towns from the Byram River to the Housatonic and north to Candlewood Lake begin to develop full-scale bus systems.
The 12-Meter yachts Enterprise and Intrepid begin six days of match racing Tuesday off San Diego in preparation for the America's Cup trials this summer.

TOKYO, March 5 (AP) Minoru Sano of Japan says he hates the compulsory figures, and that could be one reason why Vladimir Kovalev won the men's title in the world figure skating championships tonight, giving the Soviet Union three gold medals in the four events.

WASHINGTON March 5 The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, said today that he had reluctantly decided to support the nomination of Paul Warnke as chief United States disarmament negotiator, but said that he would not use his leadership position to seek to persuade other senators.
Two thoughts sprang most conspicuously from President Carter's informed, personably and only sometimes treacly telephone conversations with assorted Americans yesterday afternoon.

The last two decades have seen an almost incredible profusion of journalism students in the United States. Enrollments increased 93 percent between 1970 and 1975, and 481 percent between 1960 and 1975. For the first time in years, however, new figures show there may be a slackening of student interest in journalism programs.

Fantasies, especially tripledecker ones, require an unholy amount of imagination: you have to start from scratch, become God, create a world. Trilogies, from Mervyn Peake and Tolkien to Isaac Asimov and Ursula LeGuin, have been the opportunity for some talented and sometimes ingenious people to write at length and give their worlds the wealth of imaginative detail needed to convince.
Office leasing activity, a barometer of the city's economic health, is rebounding after several years of stagnation.

Allen Ginsberg, who was at the Other End last night, is not normally thought of as a nightclub entertainer or even as a musician. But not only did he hold forth in those capacities, he also may have started a trend of 1960's cult figures descending on Greenwich Vilage nightspots, since Timothy Leery has been booked into the Bottom Line on April 25 and 26.

LIKE your favorite supporting actor, Nino's will rarely steal the show. On the other hand, you can almost always count on getting a solid, professional performance. Nino's has been playing its role and well since 1953 when Nino (now retired) brought his brand of North Italian cooking to a rambling, 200-year-old house in northern Westchester.

WHEN Patrick Cocchiarella was an undergraduate at the University of Bridgeport in 1968, some students were grumbling about the proposed institution of an Army Reserve Officers Training Corps on campus.

HUNTINGTON CLAIRE SAUER'S election to the Suffolk County Legislature in 1975 was a political as well as a personal triumph. The victory came in a heavily Republican district just a few years after Mrs. Sauer underwent surgery for a malignant tumor on her face.

AFTER months of anxiety and some acrimony, the residential purity of Montclair, an imageconscious Essex County town, has been preserved. The Marlboro Inn, which might have become a midtown oasis of gracious dining with alcoholic refreshment, a place where wine corks might have popped and ice could have been stirred with gin and dry vermouth, will remain dry.

Allen of Long Island City, Queens, were married yesterday in St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church in Los Angeles by the Rev. Frank Meskell, a chaplain at Claremont College.

WHEN water starts seeping in through a crack or hole in the basement wall, most people think that repairs cannot be made until later in the year, after the ground has thoroughly dried and water is no longer seeping. This is true if ordinary patching cements are used, but special hydraulic cements can be used to plug holes and cracks in masonry even while water is still running through them.

It would do so by greatly revising the standard deduction.

Few bridge writers are good bridge teachers, and vice versa. There is no . particular reason why these two abilities should go hand in hand.

M.A.C. "STRETCH" A surrendering of principal payments of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds paid last Feb. 1 to the city sinking funds and the municipal employee pension funds, yielding $90 million. The major New York city banks had refused to do the same for their M.A.C. bonds.

W. Allen Wallis, chancellor of the University of Rochester, was elected chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting at a special meeting yesterday. Robert S. Benjamin announced last month that he was resigning the chairmanship, but he remains a board member.

WARRENSVILLE HEIGHTS, Ohio, March 9 Cory C. Moore, a black former marine, released a white diabetic hostage today and then surrendered peacefully to the local authorities after hearing President Carter say at his news conference in Washington that he would talk personally with Mr. Moore.

BOSTON, March 9 Tass, the Soviet press agency, has had some heartfelt comments to make lately on the fate of human rights in the United States. "The American judicial system," it said, "is truly ruthless toward dissenters, against anyone who actively comes out against the United States' aggressive course in the international arena. . . ."

BERKELEY, Calif., March 9 A former University of California student has charged at a news conference here that an R.O.T.C. instructor at the Berkeley campus helped him get a job as a mercenary with the Rhodesian Army last year.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) Iranian students have been a target of an elaborate spying operation by the Chicago Police Department for seven years, court papers charge.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 9 Rumania and the United States agreed today to collaborate in monitoring this country's geological situation during the critical weeks ahead to see whether Friday's severe earthquake will be followed by aftershocks.

The three-hour-long, achingly clumsy "Mohammad, Messenger of God" does perform one backhanded service for the religion of Islam. It is, of itself, a convincing justification for the traditional Islamic hostility to pictorial representation.

Some years ago, in the old Madison Square Garden. Saturday morning basketball clinics for thousands of youngsters were commonplace. The local college coaches were the lecturers and several of the Knick players served as "props."

The $1 billion package to pay off New York City's moratorium debts unveiled at City Hall yesterday was stitched together from sources that city officials had long been reluctant to turn to, or had discovered only in the last week or two, fiscal aides asserted.
WASHINGTON, March 9 The Carter Administration must soon deal with a trade time bomb.
A 21-year-old Essex County College woman student was stabbed to death in Newark in an apparent robbery early yesterday, less than a block from her home.
Margaret Trudeau, the wife of Canada's Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, flew here from Toronto yesterday to continue what she described as a longplanned vacation devoted to photography.
OTRANTO, Italy Two ships, painted bright yellow, pulled out of the small port here the other day and headed for a buoy three miles offshore. Their job is the talk of this community and all of Italy.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would ban the use of saccharin in foods and beverages, because the artificial sweetener had been found to cause malignant bladder tumors in laboratory animals.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) Vice President Mondale listened to a barrage of complaints from Democratic senators today and then promised that the Carter Administration would do better about consultation on major decisions and appointments.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 9 Mayor Thomas E. Sharpe said today that the Justice Department had agreed to conduct its own investigation of a fatal shooting here on Feb. 14 of a 29-year-old black man by a white policeman.

WHITE PLAINS, March 9 The Will Rogers Memorial Hospital and Research Center, which shut down its institution in Saranac Lake, N.Y., in late 1975 that had cared for actors with respiratory ailments since the 1930's, is moving its equipment to the Burke Rehabilitation Center here under an affiliation agreement announced today.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 9 (UPI) The Illinois House dealt the equal rights amendment a setback today, voting 100 to 66 to retain the requirement for a three-fifths vote for ratification.

MADRID, March 9 (Reuters) The Spanish Government today liberalized strike laws in an effort to win labor support before general elections in June, but also gave employers more scope in laying off workers either for disciplinary or economic reasons.
The Canadian dollar fell below 95 United States cents in New York yesterday its lowest level in more than seven years, dealers said.

WASHINGTON, March 9 Following are the texts of an exchange of letters between Kenneth S. Axelson and Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal concerning Mr. Axelson's withdrawal from consideration for nomination as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury:

CHICAGO, March 9 The Hanafi Moslem sect was organized and is led by Hamaas Abdul Khaalis, a 55-year-old former New York resident, who once headed a community program in Harlem to help school dropouts.
Mohammad had left Mecca and huge crowds were gathering in Medina to greet him when, without warning, the movie screen at the Rivoli Theater in mid-Manhattan went black and the lights came on.

The $1 billion package to pay off New York City's moratorium debts unveiled at City Hall yesterday was stitched together from sources that city officials had long been reluctant to turn to, or had discovered only in the last week or two, fiscal aides asserted.
CLEVELAND, March 9 Frances Payne Bolton, a member of Congress for nearly 30 years, the widow of a Congressman and the mother of another one, died early this morning at her home in suburban Lyndhurst.
Chekhov's characters are caught in time, in the emptiness of Mother Russia gone dry, in a tired countryside already undermined by the distant city, and by dreams and departures.

In the struggle for survival between the municipal Sydenham Hospital in Harlem, and nearby Arthur C. Logan Memorial Hospital, a private, voluntary institution that is in bankruptcy proceedings, the New York Health and Hospitals Corporation has conceived what it concedes is an unsportsmanlike tactic to force the closing of Logan.

ALBANY, March 9 Stunned by Governor Carey's veto last week of their carefully devised bill for a June primary election date this year, Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature came forward today with separate plans to establish a permanent primary schedule embedded in the State Constitution.

A leading West Coast brokerage firm disclosed yesterday that it and a number of other brokers were under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine whether they had given preferential treatment to an over-thecounter trader for a "large institutional investor."
The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will each add a woman floor member today, bringing the number of women members at these once all-male institutions to three apiece.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) Brady Tyson, the American diplomat who apologized in Geneva yesterday for what he said was the United States role in the subversion of the Allende Government of Chile, was called home today for instruction in diplomatic procedures.

Mercedes Randall, a prominent pacifist and for many years a member of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, died yesterday in her home at 16 Claremont Avenue in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) Charles Manson, the former California cult leader, appealed today to the Supreme Court his 1971 conviction of multiple murders in Los Angeles.

President Carter's decision to lift travel restrictions abroad removes a symbolic roadblock to visiting four proscribed countries, but the major hurdle remains getting an entry visa from the Government involved.
A $430 million acquisition will be held up for several months to permit the Orphan's Court division of the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery, Pa., to give its approval, it was learned yesterday.

Two of the Police Department's "super chiefs" were shifted yesterday, diminishing the chance that one of them, who had been sounded out about running for President of the New York City Council, would quit police work for politics.

So little support for early action to regulate fluorocarbons was voiced at a weeklong international conference on threats to atmospheric ozone that the United States may defer plans for a follow-up meeting.

The cost of a bachelor's degree at New York University has risen to between $22,450 and $23,560 under a new schedule of higher tuition and fees, according to the university's president, John C. Sawhill.

MANILA, March 9 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos is sending his wife to Libya hoping that her "personal diplomacy" will help stalled negotiations there with southern Philippine Moslem insurgents, official sources said today.
Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference in Washington yesterday morning, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:
NORFOLK, Va., March 9 (AP) Ruling the Navy failed to negotiate in good faith, a Federal judge ordered it to pay Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Co. about $20 million to $30 million.

SYRACUSE In the belief that if teen-age girls recognize the lines boys entice them with, it will help reduce unwanted pregnancies, Dr. Sol Gordon has been collecting and publicizing these stories, ranging from the classic, "Want to see my etchings?" to the more inventive "If you say no I'll become mentally ill."

The F.W. Woolworth Company, one of the world's largest retail store chains, reported yesterday an 8 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings and a 20 percent gain for all of 1976. Including the equity of earnings of its British subsidiary, the consolidated income was fractionally lower for the quarter but 9 percent higher on an annual basis. Foreign exchange translations cut the British subsidiary's earnings sharply for the quarter and year.

QUEBEC, March 9 Premier Rene Levesque opened the new session of the Quebec provincial legislature yesterday by indicating a double strategy of reassurance and exhortation to persuade voters to support his idea of an independent Quebec.
Natalie Branitzka von Hoyer, a Russian-born ballet dancer and teacher, died Tuesday at Parsons Hospital in Flushing, Queens. She was 68 years old and lived in Sea Cliff, L.I.

New York State authorities have asked Touro College to return $822,533 in state tuition grants that, they asserted, the college improperly received on behalf of 1,209 students enrolled in special programs for adults.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Senate confirmed Paul C. Warnke today as the nation's chief arms negotiator, but the vote of 58 to 40 fell short of the broad demonstration of support the Carter Ad- ministration was seeking.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) Business has demonstrated little enthusiasm for increasing plans for spending on new productive facilities this year, the Government reported today. Spending for last year turned out to be lower than originally estimated.

WASHINGTON, March 9 President Carter, shifting to the offensive against Congress today, has shown for the first time since taking office his willingness to do battle with foreign policy conservatives on Capitol Hill on the crucial issue of arms agreements with the Soviet Union.

TOWER CITY, Pa., March 9 (AP) Work on drilling a second hole into Big Lick Mountain in search of five missing coal miners was stopped shortly after noon today when the drill struck water at the 355-foot mark.

The Ballroom's laudable and adventuresome "Broadway at the Ballroom" series in which noted composers and lyricists from Broadway sing and discuss their work is offering its final presentation this week. Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice opened Tuesday and will continue through Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 At the request of the Environmental Protection Agency, a Federal judge in West Virginia issued a temporary restraining order today shutting down an FMC Corporation plant in Charleston that was discharging carbon tetrachloride into the water supply.

CAREY, Ohio, March 9 (AP) A dynamite blast felt 100 miles away in Michigan tore through a rock quarry in rural Wyandot County today, hurling debris for a mile and causing damage to homes in a five-mile radius. There were no reports of injuries.

Wealthier countries, notably Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and West Germany, are being pressed to contribute toward a substantial and rapid increase in the lendable resources of the International Monetary Fund. American officials disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) When President Carter is weighing some important policy decision, he does not have to ask his wife for her advice.

GENEVA, March 8 A number of diplomats said here today that the credibility of United States foreign policy has been damaged by the statement yesterday by Brady Tyson expressing "profoundest regrets" for the part he said American officials and private groups had played in the subversion of the Allende Government.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 9 (AP) A Federal court decision overturning a Rhode Island law that required communities to bus students to regional, nonpublic schools will affect 13 Roman Catholic schools and about 1,000 of their out-oftown students.

Even the participants seem confused as the city's fiscal crisis reaches another climax with all the dignity of a professional wrestling match. Mayor Beame's surprise announcement of a plan to raise the money needed to pay off the city's short-term debt must confound an already bewildered citizenry.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 9 Foreign Minister Pieter K. van der Byl said today that the Carter Administration, by rejecting Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's proposals for a settlement with black moderates, is in effect condemning Rhodesia and evenually much of sub-Saharan Africa to Soviet domination.

WASHINGTON, March 9 Seizing the initiative in advance of President Carter's, comprehensive energy policy statement, Senator Henry M. Jackson plans to introduce tomorrow a bill to compel electric power plants and factories to burn coal in their boilers instead of oil or natural gas.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to confirm Paul C. Warnke as the disarmament negotiator:

Some time during the current year, W.R. Wirth Jr., general manager of Foote, Cone Belding, New York, will wend his way to the Chicago office to take on a big corporate job with a broad domestic and international overview.
Though the clothes were contemporary, Andrew Goodman, the chairman of Bergdorf Goodman, called it "a nostalgic occasion."
PARIS, March 9 (Reuters) Working mothers will receive a two-year leave of absence from their jobs when they bear a child under a new "Mother's Charter" approved by the Cabinet today.
Just because CBS has become a major force in consumer magazine publishing largely through acquisition doesn't mean it is committed to that route.
The Knicks don't need a new coach as much as they need a new chemist. And that's really the reason Willis Reed has succeeded Red Holzman, beginning next season.
Mayor Beame yesterday announced that 1,380 city workers over the age 55 would be kept on the job in anticipation of Congressional action extending funds that were to expire Monday.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 9 (UPI) Newly elected opposition members of Parliament said today that they would not take their seats in the legislature, charging that the balloting in this week's election was rigged.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) The retail price of a small can of orange-juice concentrate might be going up by a nickel over last year's average because of frost damage to the Florida citrus groves, new Agriculture Department crop estimates indicated today.
WASHINGTON, March 9 Kenneth S. Axelson withdrew his name late today from consideration for nomination as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Department, the agency's second highest post.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., March (AP) Catherine Parker Jones, an Associated Press newswoman, died today at St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie. She was 58 years old.

It must be confessed that there is initally an urge to half-smile at the startling tales of the thousands of people all over town humble shopkeepers and homeowners and landlords and tenants stealing electricity and gas from Consolidated Edison, the city's ultimate power broker.

TRENTON, March 9 The chairman of an Assembly committee stunned a public hearing today by accusing the State Department of Environmental Protection of making "a drastic departure" from the Legislature's intentions with its proposed rules for controlling spills of oil and other hazardous substances.

WASHINGTON, March 9 President Carter today outlined a new approach to a Middle East solution that would establish a sovereign and recognized border between Israel and the Arab countries but would also allow a possibility of Israeli defenses extended beyond those frontiers "for the foreseeable future."
HOUSTON "It's a busy time," said George A. Alcorn, who, with his two brothers, explores for oil around the Gulf Coast. "The opportunities are super, the demand is so high and the price is right."

ATLANTA, March 9 Who said you can't fool all of the people all of the time? The Islanders, who had fooled all of the Atlanta Flames five previous times (7-0, 6-3, 8-3, 4-2 and 5-4) this season, fooled them for the sixth and final time tonight.

ALBANY, March 9 The Assembly today passed two bills to restrict redlining the refusal by banks to make mortgage loans in certain geographic areas and a third that would allow savings bank depositors to elect the bank's trustees.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would ban the use of saccha- rin in foods and beverages, because the artificial sweetener had been found to cause malignant bladder tumors in laboratory animals.

While CBS Radio awaits the results of a more thorough national ratings survey by Trendex, a 10-city telephone study by Arbitron has found that approximately 30 percent of homes with radio tuned in to President Carter's two-hour call-in program on CBS last Saturday afternoon.

WASHINGTON A panel of experts has advised the United States Postal Service to get involved quickly in electronic transmission of funds and messages, but so far they have received a cool reception from postal managers.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 9 (UPI) Maj. Gen. Westside T. Larson died Monday in Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital. He was 83 years old. In World War II, he headed the Atlantic coast antisubmarine air command.

KAMPALA, Uganda, March 8 (AP) President Idi Amin, dressed in a blue track-suit top, white shorts, gray socks and canvas sneakers, strode across the lawn of the presidential lodge, smiling and waving to the hundreds of guests gathered for his weekly basketball game.
A Canadian toy maker has decided to move part of its manufacturing operation to an abandoned handbag factory in Perth Amboy, Mayor George J. Otlowski said.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 9 (AP) The Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation said today that laboratory tests made for it did not show that the chemical Mirex was present in some fish taken from Lake Ontario last fall.
The Temporary Commission on City Finances has called for a Federal takeover of all welfare costs, asserting the move would save municipalities in New York State $800 million a year.

American retailers are increasing their orders for made-in-Europe women's apparel, according to manufacturers exhibiting at the European Fashion Fair. The fair has drawn more than 4,500 buyers from large and small retail stores who came to inspect the fashions of 228 European companies at the four-day show which ended yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) A bill collector who asked to testify about abuses in the collection industry was "threatened or intimidated into not appearing," a House subcommittee chairman said today.
BRUSSELS, March 9 (Reuters) Prime Minister Leo Tindemans of Belgium today abandoned efforts to run the country with a shaky minority coalition and called a general election for April 17.

Bob Gaillard, who led the San Francisco Dons to their best basketball season since the days of Bill Russell, was named the college coach of the year by The Associated Press yesterday. The Dons had won 29 games this season before bowing to Notre Dame last weekend.
WASHINGTON, March 9 Scientists agreed today that genetic engineering was closer to reality than most persons realized, but disagreed sharply on whether its advent would be more blessing or disaster.

New York City housing officials said yesterday that the city's plan to raise cash by selling parts of more than 100 Mitchell-Lama housing mortgages would not bring about higher rents or cooperative carrying charges in the projects involved.
MAHWAH March 9 Stimulated by the mild temperatures, the sap flowed freely this morning, at about a drop a second, from 11 tapped sugar maple trees at the Ramapo Valley County Reservation.
LOS ANGELES The letter appeared as a full-page advertisement in the Hollywood trade papers on Feb. 24.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 Not a bad day for Jerry Grote, the No. 1 catcher for the New York Mets the last 10 years and one of the 800 baseball players chasing the rainbow in Florida's 18 spring training camps.
The towing away of illegally parked cars was reduced yesterday as longshoremen picketed Pier 76 on the Hudson River waterfront to protest against police use of the pier as a temporary car pound.

A group of midtown businessmen and civic leaders, members of Community Board 5, came out yesterday against pending zoning changes in New York City that would ban socalled massage parlors and sharply curtail the number of pornographic movie theaters, topless bars, peepshows and "adult" bookstores in Times Square and other commercial districts.

CAIRO, March 9 The first conference of leaders from black Africa and the Arab world ended here today with delegates from both regions declaring that they had obtained more benefit from the talks than they had dared to hope.

The Eliot Feld Ballet made it to Broadway for the first time last night, and made it in a suitably spectacular way. It opened its first season at the City Center 55th Street Theater with a new duet created by Mr. Feld for Christine Sarry and the company's guest artist, Mikhail Baryshnikov. Mr. Baryshnikov will be dancing with the Feld Company three times during this two-week engagement.

There are two exceptionally good dramas on the schedule this evening but, true to irritating form, they are running in overlapping time periods. "The Bar Mitzvah Boy," an import from the British Broadcasting Corporation, is on Channel 13 from about 8:30 to about 9:45 (this is a fund-raising week and times are flexible). "A Circle of Children," starring Jane Alexander and Rachel Roberts, is on CBS from 9 to 11.

WASHINGTON, March 9 Small bands of gunmen, most saying they here members of the Hanafi Moslem sect, invaded city hall and two other buildings in downtown Washington today, killing one person, wounding at least 13 and taking several dozen others hostage.
Six landlords and five "torch" or arsonist suspects were arrested yesterday and charged with conspiring to set at least four fires in the Fordham section of the Bronx.
VOICES Two major spokesmen from the worlds of stage and verse can be heard today in public appearances.
Fears of double-digit inflation rates in a key set of Government statistics helped to push stock prices lower yesterday, with weakness in glamour issues particularly evident.

HIALEAH, Fla., March 9 Thoroughbred racing's most spectacular space shot of the young season took off on schedule today at Hialeah Park when unbeaten Seattle Slew won his first start as a 3-year-old by nine lengths in track-record time. In the winner's circle, he wasn't even breathing hard.
In a sudden and surprising move, Mayor Beame last night unveiled a plan to raise the money needed to pay the city's $983 million short-term debt without the assistance of New York City's major banks.

Walter Neumann, former acting supervisor of the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, was convicted of perjury yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on a charge that he had lied to the Department of Investigation when he denied shooting at birds and pigeons at the zoo.
LONDON, March 9 (AP) The price of gold dropped again in Europe today after nearly two months of almost steady rises. The dollar was firm.

Prof. Paul A. Samuelson of M.I.T., himself a Nobel Prize winner, once remarked that the person who solves the problem of stagflation the mixture of economic stagnation and inflation that has afflicted the Western world through most of the 1970's should get the Nobel Prize in economics. Thus far it does not appear that Charles L. Schultze, W. Michael Blumenthal, Bert Lance or anyone else in the Carter Administration is in the running.

WASHINGTON, March 9 President Carter and his Director of Central Intelligence, Adm. Stansfield Turner, took opposing stands today on whether criminal penalties are needed to protect national security against unauthorized discosures of classified information.

A French-Canadian player who has sunk his roots in this city after l6 seasons with the Rangers and an unemployed semipro goalie hoping for a home in New York held the spotlight last night in Madison Square Garden as New York defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 6-4.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Senate confirmed Paul C. Warnke today as the nation's chief arms negotiator, but the vote of 58 to 40 fell short of the broad demonstration of support the Carter Administration was seeking.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it had received contracts worth more than $100 million to supply a nuclear reactor system, a nuclear fuel fabrication system, a turbine generator and other services to a group of four Spanish electric utilities.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 9 A 32-year-old man was taken into custody this afternoon in connection with the disappearance this morning of a 10-year-old girl from her home in South Farmingdale.

The American Kennel Club took 93 years to elect a woman vice president. Nan R. Ayling of Kings Park, L.I., a 28-year employee who worked her way through the ranks to administrative posts, assumed that office this week.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 9 Prince Charles, who is in Kenya on a photographic safari, is himself the quarry in a journalistic hunt mounted by a Fleet Street caravan.

TETON VILLAGE, Wyo., March 9 He never thought it would happen, but it did. Paul McCollister, the founder of the Jackson Hole ski area in this lofty Grand Teton country, is still puzzled over what became of winter.
A 21-year-old Essex County College, woman student was stabbed to death in Newark in an apparent robbery early yesterday, less than a block from her home.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 9 For most of his 12 years as a Baltimore Oriole, Paul Blair was recognized as the best center fielder in baseball. He also was recognized as one of the best talkers in baseball. Motormouth his teammates called him.
In a sudden and surprising move, Mayor Beame last night unveiled a plan to raise the money needed to pay the city's $983 million short-term debt without the assistance of New York City's major banks.
WASHINGTON, March 9 Visiting Professor of Diplomacy Henry A. Kissinger returned to academia today after an eight-year absence.

LONDON, March 9 After almost three weeks of deadlock, hopes rose today for a settlement of a wildcat strike that has crippled British Leyland Ltd., the country's biggest automobile producer, and set back the Labor Government's efforts to project a positive economic image.
WASHINGTON, March 9 As President Carter had forecast, no one asked him today at a White House news conference about boxcars filled with snow, baseball games in Cuba or justice for Ottawa Indians.
WASHINGTON, March 9 Kenneth S. Axelson withdrew his name late today from consideration for nomination as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Department, the agency's second highest post.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, March 10 Small bands of gunmen, most saying they were members of the Hanafi Moslem sect, invaded city hall and two other buildings in downtown Washington, yesterday, killing one person, wounding at least 13 and taking nearly 150 persons hostage.

After two days of losers, Angel Cordero was back in the groove. The jockey, who returned from California this week, got his first winners of the New York season three of them. His scores included the $36,425 Cicada for 3-yearold fillies.
A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that it was permissible for a prosecutor to stage a crime in an effort to catch corrupt prosecutors and judges.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) A Federal study on treating the painful heart condition known as angina pectoris concluded that coronary bypass surgery was not necessary in many cases in which it was used, researchers said today.

Technical experts yesterday began studying a compromise plan that operators of the British-French Concorde say would enable the plane to operate at noise levels at Kennedy International Airport no louder than those of many subsonic aircraft.

WASHINGTON, March 9 President Carter said today that he intended to withdraw American ground forces from South Korea in four to five years, enunciating a critical point in a new policy on Korea that is taking shape in the Administration and the Congress.
The shares of the Eason Oil Company have fluctuated widely this week, presumably on speculation that the tightly held concern may be for sale.
A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that it was permissible for a prosecutor to stage a crime in an effort to catch corrupt prosecutors and judges.

Oil imports rose to record levels for the third consecutive week while a revised estimate of domestic petroleum production for February placed United States output at 7.95 million barrels a day, the first drop below the eight million mark since the mid-1960's.

CHICAGO, March 9 After five days of deliberations, a Federal court jury today acquitted the Freeport Minerals Company and a subsidiary, the National Potash Company, of conspiring to control the production, distribution and sale of potash in North America from 1969 through 1974.

WASHINGTON, March 9 Citing Franklin D. Roosevelt's Depression-era recovery programs, President Carter asked Congress today for a $1.8 billion jobs program that he said would benefit young people, the nation's largest bloc of unemployment.

LONDON, March 9 (AP) A reporter for The Sunday Times of London has been expelled from India, the paper announced today. It said that Ian Jack, who has been covering the Indian election campaign, had been told by Indian authorities to leave "by the first available plane."

LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP) The Los Angeles Rams have traded the rights to Ron Jaworski, a quarterback, to the Philadelphia Eagles for the rights to a tight end. Charles Young, the Rams announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 President Carter today outlined a new approach to a Middle East solution that would establish a sovereign and recognized border between Israel and the Arab countries but would also allow a possibility of Israeli defenses extended beyond those frontiers "for the foreseeable future."
PHILADELPHIA, March 9 "Times have changed . . . things are different . . . I'm feeling better . . . you don't look a day older . . . "

The New York City Sanitation Department puts the official date for the end of winter in the middle of April, when the snowplows are put on summer leave. The Hayden Planetarium pronounces the vernal equinox this year on March 20 at exactly 12:43 P.M. The National Weather Service says only that these last two days have been "unseasonably warm."
TORONTO, March 10 (AP) Some oil refiners in Ontario are seeking increased exports of gasoline and fuel oil to the United States to reduce unusually large stores, industry spokesmen say.

TRENTON, March 10 Two New Jersey brothers whose empire of insurance firms collapsed in bankruptcy in 1975 were charged today with stealing more than $8 million in insurance premiums in what was called the largest fraud case ever brought in the state.

Paige Brook, the New York Philharmonic's assistant principal flutist since 1952, was the featured artist in an evening of Baroque music for flute and strings Wednesday at Tully Hall. The program included Telemann's Suite in A minor and two works by Bach the Suite in B minor, and Cantata No. 209 ("Non sa che sia dolore"), in which solo flute and soprano are equally prominent.

Lonnie Shelton was more overpowering, Bob McAdoo scored less but was more effective, and the Knicks hustled and played one of their few team games last night. The combination gave New York a 108-104 victory over the struggling Portland Trail Blazers at Madison Square Garden.

Three-fourths of New York City's subway cars run with doors, lights or windows that are broken, misisng fire extinguishers or other defects, a transit study group charged yesterday after a fourmonth survey.
Before many weeks are out, the city will be in the position of conducting an environmental review whenever a discretionary zoning action is deemed to have a "significant" effect on the environment.

LOS ANGELES (AP) Army experts using "mock-killer chemicals" carried out a successful simulated assassination of President Nixon and the Congress in 1969 and 1970, a former researcher contends.
With a strong challenge to Aqueduct's ticket-sellers to mend their ways, James Heffernan took over the New York Racing Association's parimutuel operation yesterday.

HARTFORD, March 10 Dick Stockton took the best that Tony Roche could offer tonight, then rallied and won the opening match of the eighth World Cup tennis tournament between the United States and Australia.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 10 The last metropolitan entry in the National Invitation Tournament was eliminated tonight when Rutgers went down before St. Bonaventure in overtime, 7977.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) Federal Power Commission lawyers who were vocal in their criticism of gas producers were given transfers or made to feel unwelcome by superiors, a number of former senior F.P.C. natural gas attorneys said today.

Taking pains to explain that he had a significant constituency, although he has never held or run for public office, Edward N. Costikyan, onetime leader of Manhattan Democrats, announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday.

A Newark building superintendent was held without bail on charges of stabbing a college student to death a block from her home. The superintendent, John Reddin, 35 years old, appeared before Judge Martin Oliveres in Municipal Court, Newark, and was arraigned on murder charges in the death of Mildred Webb, 21, a neighbor. He was sent to the Essex County Jail to await a hearing.
World prices of raw sugar, the most hardly responded yesterday to the actions taken by Ottawa and Washington to ban saccharin.

JOHANNESBURG, Friday, March 11 A draft South African white paper outlining a proposed newspaper bill is understood to provide for heavy fines and prison sentences for any reporter who contravenes the Government's press code, which, among other things, would make it an offense to report on events in a manner that brings South Africa into disrepute abroad.

The hospital management company stocks were regarded as undervalued by some Wall Street analysts even before the slump that occurred after the Carter Administration indicated it would propose legislation to limit annual increases in hospital charges.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 10 (Reuters) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith reshuffled his Cabinet today following the resignation of his Defense Minister and the creation of a new post to oversee the struggle against guerrillas.

The Federal Food and Drug Administration plans to consider classifying saccharin as a drug, instead of a food additive so that doctors could prescribe the noncaloric artificial sweetener among overweight Americans and the millions of patients with diabetes and other disorders for which weight control plays a crucial role.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The 75millimeter howitzers that usually fire 19 times to welcome visiting heads of government were missing from the sunny Elipse of the White House when British Prime Minister James Callaghan arrived today, so fearful were officials that gunfire might shatter the fragile peace at siege sites only blocks away.

BURLINGAME, Calif., March 10 The teamsters' union and the United Farm Workers signed here today an agreement that leaders of both unions said would end the decade-long strife over organizing agricultural workers in the West.
WASHINGTON, March 10 Wholesale prices, which often foreshadow prices at the retail level, rose by 0.9 percent in February, the biggest jump in 16 months, the Labor Department reported today.

MIAMI, March 10 When Brian (Buddy) Allin won the Doral-Eastern open here in 1974, he was known as a hero of the war in Vietnam, a former artillery officer who had been decorated four times. All that is far behind him now, and so, for that matter, is the 1974 victory. What Allin is trying to do now is recover the swing he had then.

In 1967, Herb Larkin was an all-city basketball player at Richmond Hill in Queens. The other night Larkin was visited by some all-city players of 1977 at Goldwater Hospital on Roosevelt Island. Larkin is confined to a wheel chair, paralyzed nine years ago by an injury suffered while playing basketball.

TOKYO, March 10 Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda, preparing for his departure next week for a meeting in Washington with President Carter, indicated today that there were differences between the two leaders over foreign policy and the question of human rights.

The first clash between the Carter Administration and Congress over the right of Cabinet officers to refuse to testify at legislative inquiries has arisen in connection with the scandal-scarred Central States pension fund of the Inter national Brotherhood of Teamsters.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Of all the unsettled legacies of the war in Vietnam, perhaps none is so emotional and divisive as the issue of amnesty for those who evaded the draft or deserted from the armed services in that protracted conflict.

ALBANY, March 10 (AP) Three men serving life terms for the assassination of Malcolm X were placed under special security in the New York State prison system today after the gunmen holding hostages in Washington demanded that the convicts be turned over to them.

TRENTON, March 10 Dr. Oscar B. Sussman, the head of the New Jersey Consumer Health Services, has been rebuffed in his effort to force 200 state officials to pay 14 cents a mile for commuting to work in state-owned cars.
MESA, Ariz., March 10 (AP) Dick Allen and Charles O. Finley, two of baseball's most controversial figures, joined forces today when Allen agreed to a one-year contract with the Oakland A's.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Concerned about possible repercussions in Israel and the Arab countries. Carter Administration officials have taken steps in the last 24 hours to try to convince both sides that President Carter's new Middle East proposals did not mean an end to American even-handedness in negotiations.

WEST BERLIN, March 10 The Soviet Ambassador to East Germany suggested today that President Carter's support for dissidents and human rights activists in the Communist bloc was "designed to torpedo" an improvement of East-West relations.

The interviews were conducted by Harold Steele of radio station WMAL, as reported by Reuters; Phil Walters of WBBM-TV in Chicago, a station owned by CBS, and Robert A. Dobkin of The Associated Press:

WHITE PLAINS, March 10 A Westchester County grand jury today indicted William Profit, Samuel Ayala and James Walls Jr. in the murders last week of two Lewisboro mothers, Sheila Watson and Bonnie Minter, during a burglary in Mrs. Watson's home.
The credit markets shrugged off news of sharply rising wholesale prices and a February rebound in retail sales yesterday and then apparently were surprised by a decline in the money supply.
The February jobs figures issued at the end of last week by the Labor Department in Washington raised some eyebrows and a number of questions in political and economic quarters around the country.
KINSHASA, Zaire, March 10 (AP) Mercenaries from Angola have invaded southern Zaire and occupied three important mining and communications centers, the Zaire Government said today.

Gerald (Jerry) Ehrlich, the first full-time tennis coach at Columbia University and a ranking Eastern amateur tennis player in the 1930's, died yesterday at his Closter, N.J., home after a long illness. He was 59 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 10 Three Federal agencies plan to conduct a joint study of the usefulness of marijuana in preventing nausea in persons who must take a powerful anticancer drug.

Sarah Stifler Jesup, director of development and alumni affairs at the Collegiate School in Manhattan and the centennial fund-raising consultant to the Fresh Air Fund, died yesterday of cancer at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. She was 41 years old and lived at 170 East 83d Street.
The United States Lines paid about $1.6 million in rebates to shippers from 1970 to 1973 and made a number of political payments in the period, it was announced yesterday.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, March 10 (Reuters) Riot policemen fired rubber bullets today at Basque demonstrators here protesting the death of two alleged members of the Basque nationalist guerrilla group E.T.A. in a shoot-out with the police two days ago at a roadblock near this northern summer resort.
Sugar futures showed only a small rise yesterday while cocoa futures declined sharply, much to the surprise of many market observers.
LONDON, March 10 (Reuters) A wildcat strike that top management said threatened the future of The Times of London ended tonight when the employees went back to work.

The stock market shook off its latest case of inflation jitters yesterday and produced a late rally led by International Business Machines and sugar-related issues. The glamour sector also recovered from its slump on Wednesday.

An 18-year-old youth convicted of stabbing 30-year-old J. Karen Singer to death last September in Central Park was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday by Justice Alvin Klein in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

MOSCOW, March 10 Signs are emerging that the Kremlin feels it has weathered its recent confrontation wih the Carter Administration over human rights.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 10 Coffee buyers, mostly from the United States and Western Europe, are providing the Uganda regime of Idi Amin with increasing amounts of money that, according to Uganda refugees, is used largely to maintain the country's army, police and security apparatus.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 10 (UPI) A mistrial was declared today after a jury failed to reach a verdict in the trial of a man charged with threatening to assassinate former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller with a cyanide bullet.

NEW ORLEANS, March 10 A nationally known oceanographer said at an international oil spill conference here today that one of the best ways to prevent massive oil spills was to make the spills so unprofitable for the oil industry and insurers that proper controls would be made voluntarily.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 10 The announcement by Zaire today of an invasion came after recurring reports over the last two weeks of renewed fighting in northern Angola involving National Front troops.

The National Council of Jewish Women presented Vice President Mondale with its John F. Kennedy Award for public service last night at the council's 32d national convention at the New York Hilton Hotel.

A Newark building superintendent was held without bail on charges of stabbing a college student to death a block from her home. He was sent to the Essex County Jail to await a hearing.
