The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners yesterday approved free "his and her" dual listings for New Jersey Bell Telephone customers who want their names in the telephone book. De Dietrich (USA) Inc., announced yesterday that is was building a complete manufacturing facility at Union, N.J., that will enable it to build glasslined pipes and fittings. The plant will include a huge reglassing oven that will require 2,200 kilowatts of electricity for its heat source.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The Senate overwhelmingly approved tonight a $4 billion public works bill to ease unemployment after approving a formula far more generous to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut than was legislation approved by the House of Representatives. WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) Consumer spending in February rebounded from the effects of the severe winter weather, increasing 1.8 percent from the January level, the Commerce Department said today.

Revere Copper and Brass Inc. has agreed in principle with Alcan Aluminum Corporation, a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminum Ltd., to sell Revere's aluminum reduction plant in Scottsboro, Ala., for about $140 million. BOSTON, March 10 John Ferguson's fiery temper contributed to the New York Rangers' ruin tonight as they suffered their worst defensive collapse this season and were drubbed by the Bruins. 10-3, at Boston Garden.

The itching continued, however, and now, more worried, Mrs. Nabney went to a skin specialist.

Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, who is now living at the Pierre Hotel and fighting extradition to Italy to face bank-looting, charges, asked Judge Thomas P. Griesa of the Federal District Court in New York yesterday for 30 days to file new court papers.

The Boeing Company announced that it would take a 15 percent participation in the Peabody Holding Company, recently formed to take over the Peabody Coal Company, the world's largest coal mining property. WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) Two state regulators of bill collectors testified today that Federal regulation was needed because state laws could do little about collectors' calls from another state.

CLEVELAND, March 10 William P. Inman came to work today with a bitter taste in his mouth. Yesterday the Government proposed a ban on saccharin, a product that generates for his employer, the Sherwin-Williams Company, 4 percent of its earnings and 1 percent of its revenues annually.
The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said yesterday that an agreement in principle had been reached for Houston to acquire Pott Industries Inc. for stock valued at about $162.3 million.

The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the largest non-American company and part owner of the Shell Oil Company here, yesterday reported a profit increase of 109 percent for the fourth quarter on a sales gain of 39.6 percent. The humor, what there was of it, fell flat, and the singing, what there was of it, did little to redeem a dreary evening.

BONN, Friday, March 11 (AP) United States and West German officials ended a second round of talks today on halting the spread of nuclear-weapons technology with no sign of easing their disagreement over a German-Brazilian atomic sales agreement.

United Cerebral Palsy of New York will take over the management of a fifth of the Willowbrook Developmental Center for the mentally retarded on Staten Island, under an agreement signed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

Two operators of a Franklin Square, L.I., nursing home have been indicted on a charge of taking $335,000 in kickbacks from their suppliers over the last six years, New York State's special prosecutor for nursing homes said yesterday.
Three letters containing low-powered incendiary devices ignited at a post office in lower Manhattan last night and early today, according to the police.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) Bowing to bitter protests, the Continental Illinois National Bank of Chicago today dropped a proposed $50 million plan to invest tax-exempt pension funds in farm land.

WASHINGTON, March 11 The Carter Administration is willing to discuss how to create and pay for huge stockpiles of major commodities that could be tapped to stabilize global commodity prices. The Administration's decision to enter international negotiations is considered a major concession to developing nations.
WASHINGTON-A replacement heart valve invented in research at Union College, Schnectady, N.Y., uses mechanical means to mimic the action of a natural valve.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 11 Reggie Jackson, the man the Yankees wanted this winter and got, made his debut today, but Toby Harrah, the man the Yankees wanted and did not get, overshadowed him.

HARTFORD, March 11 "No chance of Australia winning this World Cup," said Jimmy Connors tonight, and then the world's No. 1-ranked tennis player went out and routed John Alexander of Australia, 6-1, 6-4.

Westchester County established a women's center in White Plains and drew a cheer from an open-house gathering by announcing that the name of the county's Office of Manpower Training had been changed to the Employment and Training Office.

Randall M. Dubois, a consulting engineer specializing in transportation, died Thursday in Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital, after a short illness. He lived at Wolver Hollow Road, Oyster Bay, L.I., and was 61 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 11 Like pretty girls and haunting refrains, the remembrance of campaigns past came bubbling up at the White House today.

LONDON, March 11 Striking toolworkers of Britains biggest automobile maker, Leyland, refused today to return to work. With shouts and insults they dismissed the pleas of Hugh Scanlon, president of their union, to end their three-week stoppage and reconsider "the enormity" of their refusal.

WASHINGTON, March 11 Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall said today that his department's occupational safety and health program had been "sabotaged from the beginning" by the Nixon and Ford Administrations and was now in a state of "chaos."

TRENTON, March 11 State prison officials described today, in the wake of the two days of Moslem terrorism in Washington, how they have managed to keep opposing factions among 500 Black Moslem inmates separated and thus avoiding trouble.

HOUSTON, March 11 When the Government of Taiwan presented the city of Houston with a statue of Confucius a few months back, it was Nikki Van Hightower, the city's official Advocate for Women's Rights, who spotted the inscription on the base and quickly branded the Chinese sage "the sexist of his time."

The body of a young Brooklyn woman who was eight months' pregnant was discovered yesterday in a cardboard box on a sidewalk in the garment center. Ten hours later the police took into custody a part-time elevator operator in a building she had visited.
ALBANY, March 11 Barry Fleishman fully expects hopes, in fact to be over the hill within two years or so.
DETROIT, March 11 Mark Belger did something different tonight. He won a race from the front, leading from start to finish. And it hurt.

WASHINGTON, March 11 The Food and Drug Administration's decision to ban the use of saccharin in foods and beverages prompted a Congressional challenge today and demands to curb the powers of the agency.

UNIONDALE, L.I., March 11 (AP) Mike Bantom scored 6 points and pulled down 10 rebounds in the third quarter to spark the New York Nets to an 82-73 victory over the Phoenix Suns in the National Basketball Association tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 11 Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal today approved New York City's request for a $255 million short-term Federal loan as a key part of the plan to tide the city over the shoals of threatened bankruptcy.
L. Power Biggs, noted organist, died on Thursday afternoon in Deaconess Hospital, Boston, following an operation for bleeding ulcers. He was 70 years old.
HUGHESTON, W.Va., March 9 The steep mountainside was obviously not virgin land, but neither did it have the ravaged, moonscape look that is characteristic of strip mines.

JERUSALEM There can be little doubt that the Palestine Liberation Organization has finally decided to announce its new position on how the Israeli-Palestinian conflict can he resolved. After almost two years of cautious and somewhat hesitant announcements, we finally hear that a two-state solution of the conflict has in fact been adopted by the P.L.O.

OTTAWA, March 11 The hordes of Canadians who flock to the United States' southland for winter vacations more than a million to Florida alone, according to travel industry figures have discovered that their holidays in the sun are costing them substantially more this year.

GENEVA, March 11 Allard K. Lowenstein, the American delegate, said today that the annual session of the United Nations Human Rights Commission that ended today had been "far more balanced" because the United States had managed to get the group to discuss the issue of Soviet dissidents.

Interstate Stores Inc., which has been operating under the Chapter X provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since June 1974, yesterday filed a plan of reorganization with the Federal court. Court hearings on the proposal will be held May 9.

LONDON, March 11 (AP) The price of gold dropped $1 an ounce today in both London and Zurich. The dollar closed narrowly mixed.

It was about 25 years ago that the New York City Opera staged "I Quattro Rusteghi" by Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari. For some reason it did not stay in the repertory, and more's the pity. Thursday night, however, the Manhattan School of Music plugged this particular gap in the repertory with a charming little production of the opera.

The body of a young Brooklyn woman who ws eight months' pregnant was discovered yesterday in a cardboard box on a sidewalk in the garment center. Ten hours later the police took into custoy a part-time elevator operator in a building she had visited.

CAIRO, March 11 (Reuters) Five persons arrested by the Egyptian police have confessed to being Libyan agents sent to Cairo to carry out acts of sabotage during the meeting here of Arab and black African leaders, Egypt's official Middle East News Agency said today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) When Iran's Abassador, Ardeshir Zahedi, learned that he would negotiate face-to-face with the leader of a band of Moslems holding 134 hostages, he turned to a man of religion for help.

NEW DELHI, India, March 11 (UPI) The Socialist Party leader, George Fernandes, began a hunger strike today to protest Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's refusal to let him out of prison so he can campaign for next week's election.

WASHINGTON, March 11 President Carter, in an apparent gesture to the military and his Senate critics, has named a representative of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to the American delegation that will discuss arms control matters in Moscow later this month.

WHITE PLAINS, March 11 Robert Moses, who years ago conceived the idea of a bridge across Long Island Sound from Rye, N.Y., to Oyster Bay, L.I., insisted here today that such a bridge was "inevitable," and he appealed for Westchester County support for it.

MADRID, March 11 The Government tonight proclaimed a new amesty that is expected to free a large number of the approximately 170 political prisoners accused or tried under the Franco regime who are still in jail.
TOKYO, March 11 (Reuters) Toyota, Japan's biggest automaker, announced today that it exported a monthly record of 110,400 vehicles in February.

Cries of "Police! Freeze!" stunned patrons into instant silence on the first floor of a lavish New York City after-hours club at 6:30 yesterday morning. In fact, all was so quiet that dancers, gamblers and other customers on the second floor did not know there was a "bust" until they saw the police who had hounded up the carpeted stairway to yell "Police! Freeze!" at them.

PARAMUS, March 11 Officials of this Bergen County community, the home of four heavily patronized shopping centers, asserted today that they would strictly enforce this Sunday a local "blue law" that bans a wide range of commercial activity.

Dr. Sanford Meyerowitz, a psychiatrist and associate dean of the University of Rochester's School of Medicine and Dentistry, died of cancer yesterday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 50 years old and a resident of Rochester.

News of the Food and Drug Administration's plan to ban saccharin sent scores of sweet-toothed and diet-conscious New Yorkers to the nearest market yesterday to stock up on products that contain the artificial sweetener.

In light, preweekend trading yesterday, soybean futures inched down in the nearby months, which oall for delivery of old crop beans. May closed at $8.20 a bushel, down from $8.23. The new crop months of November, January and later showed gains.

TOKYO, March 11 In an economic move weighted more by psychology than substance, the Bank of Japan announced today a reduction in its official discount rate to 6 percent from 6 percent.

Rowny to participate in the talks. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will head the American delegation.

The Board of Regents of the 27-campus University of Wisconsin system yesterday chose Edwin Young as chancellor of the university. The 59year-old Mr. Young, a labor economist who received a doctorate from Wisconsin in 1950, is now chancellor of the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus and served as president of the University of Maine from 1965 to 1968. He will succeed John C. Weaver, who steps down from the $55,000-a-year presidency June 30.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 13 (UPI) Steve Baker started his Yamaha on the pole position today and outran Ken Roberts for victory in the rainshortened $102,800 Daytona 200-motorcycle road race. Officials had planned to run two 100-mile legs, separated by an hour, because of tire safety problems. But a heavy rain began falling shortly after Baker won the first leg and the second segment was canceled. Baker was declared the official winner.

Mideast Regional basketball doubleheader at Indiana University's Assembly Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, who is chairman of the Government Operations Committee, said today that he would introduce tomorrow a bill to create a separate department of education. Most education programs are under the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and are included in a $9 billion budget.

Responding to criticism that the new lines it recently adopted for New York City's 33 Council Districts were cosmetic and were pushed through hastily, the City Council has begun a new effort to redistrict Council seats to better reflect natural neighborhood lines. The National Invitation Tournament, which resumes tonight with a Madison Square Garden doubleheader, had a good first-round road show. It is, he said, tantamount to "advertising to neurotic people" who are inspired to attempt "suicidal and ridiculous" acts. His solution: to restrict the press by law in its coverage of violent crimes.

CHANTILLY, Va., March 14--The people of this hamlet have lived for nearly 10 months in the path of the Concorde landings at Dulles International Airport, four miles north of here. They seem to have settled into an amiable if not enthusiastic accommodation with the noisy supersonic airliner.

PORTLAND, Ore., Mar 14 (UPI)--Govr. Robert Straub proposed today a single national welfare system based on the minimum wage and offered Oregon as a test site.

Two youths charged with being "designated felons" for the murder of an 80-year-old woman in her Brooklyn apartment were ordered held yesterday for a hearing on Thursday.
The top-ranked New York team survived the semifinal stage of the district grand national team contest here Sunday, but only after a bitter battle in which defeat seemed in the cards.

WNET's fund-raising drive, now more than halfway through a 14-day special program festival, so far has enlisted 13,208 new members who have pledged $378,613. At that rate, the public television station is likely to raise about as much money as it did last March while signing up fewer members.

CEDARHURST, L.I., March 14--When the big jets on their approach to Kennedy International Airport fly over this community, conversations stop. Teachers pause in their lessons, clergymen halt their sermons and the old men on the park benches in front of the village hall fall silent until the planes pass.

The price of Olympia Brewing Company shares has been cut in half in the last seven trading sessions in the over-the-counter market with company officials expressing bafflement at the development.

It's a nowhere place, really, of disintegrating identity, but it's well known to Government engineers who specialize in studying data about decibels.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 14--In an attempt to stimulate domestic savings, the Mexican Government today announced plans to issue 2 billion pesos-- about $90 million--worth of "petrobonds" that will have a maturity value pegged to the world price of oil.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 14--Archibald Cox, former Watergate special prosecutor, was retained by the University of California today to present oral arguments to the Supreme Court in its appeal on the constitutionality of its special admissions programs for minority students.

WASHINGTON, March 14--Robert S. Strauss, recently named President Carter's Special Trade Representative, said today the United States had got "short shrift" in agriculture in previous trade negotiations and served notice that in the current round "we're not going to give anything away."

Sheeran announced that the company had been granted a 9 percent rise.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14 --No matter what happens to his $3.5 million right arm. Catfish Hunter is prepared to complete his five-year obligation to the Yankees.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 14 (UPI) --Dr. Ulysses S. Grant 4th, grandson of the Civil War general and 18th President of the United States, died of leukemia Friday at St.John's Hospital. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 14--American officials said today that the international economic conference scheduled for London May 7 and 8 would focus on energy, the North-South dialogue between the rich and poor countries, trade questions and broader economic issues relating to management of the recovery from the world's deepest postwar recession.

ATLANTA, March 14--The 12-way contest to select a successor tomorrow to Andrew Young as the representative from Atlanta's racially mixed Fifth Congressional District seems almost certain to end without a clear victor, requiring a second election on April 5 to pick a winner.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 14 (UPI)-- The search for Al Bramlet, the labor leader who led a strike last spring that closed most of the hotel-casinos on the Las Vegas Strip, was called off today after a week of scouring the Nevada desert.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 14 (Reuters)-- President Idi Amin plans to address Americans and Britons living in Uganda, the Uganda radio reported today.

James Callaghan, the British Prime Minister, has returned to London after visits with President Carter and the Canadian Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, and, the British Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday, he will appear March 24 in a televised Carterstyle telephone call-in with viewers. Was the program inspired by Mr. Carter's March 5 radio call-in, in which he answered the questions of 42 citizens?

New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission is prepared to increase taxi fares by as much as 13 percent when it meets tomorrow to vote on the industrysought increase, commission members said yesterday. However, a minority was pressing yesterday for a smaller increase.
PARIS, March 14--National political leaders of the center-right conceded today that the leftist opposition had made considerable gains in yesterday's nationwide municipal elections.

MOSCOW, March 14 (Reuters)--Byambyn Rinchen, a Mongolian writer whose outspoken espousal of his country's cultural heritage once got him jailed and another time won him a major prize, died in Ulan Bator on March 6, according to a Mongolian official. He was 72 years old.

Bert Lance, director of the Office of Management and Budget, told some 1,000 paper industry executives yesterday that too much paperwork and government red tape meant that "we are denying ourselves the reality of having a viable economy."

Nobody loves the Food and Drug Administration. The brouhaha over saccharin is only the latest such episode; the F.D.A. has been there before with vitamins, cyclamates, tainted cranberries, mercury-laden fish, oral contraceptives, and deceptive cancer cures. Once again it is caught in the crossfire between nervous consumers and powerful industries. It is charged, on the one hand, with admitting harmful additives into the American diet, and, on the other, with colossal overregulation.

ONCE AGAIN, true to infuriating form, television has two outstanding dramatic productions running against each other. Tonight at 9, CBS has "The Deadliest Season" and PBS ends its fine "Childhood" series with "An Only Child," based on a short story by Frank O'Connor. Each represents a significant artistic achievement for a medium that can use all the significance it can grab in any given week.

ANYBODY here remember the spring coat? A neatly tailored thing it was, often in navy blue gabardine, with a white pique collar and perhaps a flower on the lapel. Most had tiny waistlines, circled with black patent leather belts, though some seasons the coat turned up with swashbuckling fullness so it could slide over that other concomitant of spring, the tailored suit.

DETROIT, March 15 The General Motors Corporation is expected to drop the slow-selling subcompact Chevrolet Vega and its sister car, the Pontiac Astre, at the end of the 1977 model year, according to informed sources.

A MIDDLE-AGED New Yorker who noticed that his hearing was getting progressively worse purchased a hearing aid directly from a retailer. In the next few years, his hearing deteriorated still further. When he finally sought medical attention because he developed pain and discharge from his ear, he was found to have what had become an inoperable cancer affecting his ear.

NBC-TV IS GOING forward with its scheduled presentation next month of "Jesus of Nazareth," a six-hour television film by the noted Italian director Franco Zeffirelli, despite a campaign against the program by various evangelical religious groups.

Walter H. Annenberg has withdrawn his proposed gift of $40 million to finance the Fine Arts Center of the Annenberg School of Communications at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a day after a public hearing on the project.

The wheels are in motion for a new enclosed three-level shopping mall in the so-called "Hub" section of the South Bronx. WASHINGTON March 17 The Jewish Defense League threatened today to stage a demonstration by armed, angry Jewish youths outside the headquarters of the Hanafi Moslem sect on Sunday. The Hanafi response was a warning of "blood baths" against "all Zionist Jews", if the demonstration was carried out.

The timing of the appearance made comparison with the Eagles. which performed at Nassau Coliseum on Tuesday and will be at Madison Square Garden for a sold-out show on Friday, virtually inescapable.

WASHINGTON, March 17 The staff of the National Association of Securities Dealers will present data to its board here tomorrow indicating that a plan for trading call options on 11 over-the-counter stocks is economically feasible.
Two boys one 12 years old and the other 15 were held yesterday for trial April 12 in the fatal beating of an 80-year old Brooklyn woman.

Paying his first visit to New York City since, taking office two months ago, President Carter was whisked under heavy guard to the United Nations last night, but even the strict security measures could not stifle his craving for contact with the people.

One of major league baseball's better pitchers, Luis Tiant, has ended a threeweek boycott of spring training and will report to the Boston Red Sox camp in West Palm Beach, Fla., today.

A new repertory opens its first production tonight in Brooklyn. The group: the BAM Theater Company. The play: "The New York Idea," a revival of Langdon Mitchell's crisp and funny turn-of-the-century look at divorce and marriage in the smart set.

WASHINGTON, March 17 The Senate Finance Committee today in effect approved President Carter's $50 tax rebate, the cornerstone of his economic stimulus program this year, by narrowly rejecting two Republican amendments offering permanent-tax cuts instead.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 17 With a knockdown in the final round, Jimmy Young completed a startling upset of George Foreman by earning a unanimous 12-round decision over the former heavyweight champion tonight at the Roberto Clemente Coliseum.

Only hours after he warned against a unilateral rush into renewed diplomatic relations with Cuba, Gale W. McGee, former Senator from Wyoming, was unanimously approved by the Senate to be Ambassador to the Organization of American States. Before the voice vote, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee heard Mr. McGee day that "I don't think we ought to be racing pell mell" toward renewed relations with Cuba. NEW BRUNSWICK, March 17 Dr. David Spain, director of pathology at Brookdale College in Brooklyn, testified today that an examination of Joanne Chesimard's bullet scars and X-ray reports supported her version of how she was shot during a gunfight on the New Jersey Turnpike nearly four years ago.

Charlton Joseph Kadio Hinman, a Shakespeare scholar and inventor of the "Hinman Collating Machine," a device that made possible the comparatively rapid collation of individual pages of Sheakespeare's printed texts, died Wednesday at the Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 66 years old.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 17 Pete Worstell, at attack, scored three goals and one assist today to lead the Maryland Lacrosse team to a 13-3 victory over Princeton on Poe Field.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) The black activist who is the Carter Administration's chief civil rights lawyer says that courts should not order citywide school desegregation to remedy limited instances of illegal racial segregation.
No matter what, the Kaminsky International Kazoo Quartet five strong and members of the Fie on Arts Ensemble will take over Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17 President Carter brought his campaign for human rights to the United Nations tonight, asserting that the world body had allowed "its human rights machinery, to be ignored and sometimes politicized."

The British Petroleum Company, a major company that operates in all phases of petroleum, reported yesterday that its profits had doubled in the fourth quarter of 1976 and were up 8.5 percent for all of last year, reflecting increased sales and improved prices.

WASHINGTON, March 17 This city is on the verge of another fundamental debate on the new Carter Administration's policy in the Middle East, and the debate has been building up in an odd and almost offhand way.
CASABLANCA, Morocco The rich, of Morocco are becoming more opulent, and the poor are finding survival more difficult.

NEW DELHI, March 17 Outside a pink and yellow government building on one of this quiet capital city's broad leafy boulevards, newly posted guards stood at attention today, holding rifles with bayonets. Across the street, pedestrians stopped from time to time for a long, respectful look.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 17 (UPI) The body of a man, possibly of Al Bramlet, the missing leader of a Culinary Workers Union local, was discovered in the desert about 40 miles southwest of here today.
Unless the main dirt track at Aqueduct shapes up in a hurry, Kentucky Derby candidates in the Bay Shore Stakes may find themselves running six furlongs instead of seven.

WASHINGTON, March 17 The Carter Administration's top economic policy team has agreed to a stringent new program requiring Federal agencies to measure the impact of regulations on the economy before they are imposed.

The city gets a new movie house this weekend the Jean Renoir Cinema which is a product of unlikely parts: an unprepossessing theater space in the East Village, a letter of approval from the 82-year-old French film maker, and a partnership composed of a soap opera ingenue, a precocious film aficionado and a female projectionist.

Mounted police officers supported by almost 100 foot patrolmen charged into a crowd of some 5,000 rowdy teen-agers who had gathered in Central Park yestertay to drink and watch the St. Patrick's Day Parade.
SACRAMENTO (AP) A husband or wife who quits a job to move to another city with a spouse is eligible for unemployment benefits, the California Unemployment Insurance Board has ruled.

DETROIT, March 17 The United States auto industry is expected to build 210,272 cars this week, the highest weekly total since late 1973 when the Arab oil embargo started the industry on a two-year slump, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
Now that interest rates on tax-exempt bonds have eased somewhat from record levels, investors are scouring the market for high coupon tax-exempts. They do so, in at least one case, at their peril.

The plot is almost a familiar one, The Invisible Man, pursued by the police strips off his face bandaging and clothing to make his traditional, foolproof escape. However, here the story takes an unfamiliar twist. The poor, hounded chap, forgetting to remove his underwear because it's comfortable enough to be unnoticed, is snared by the long arms of the law.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 The New York Mets made it five out of seven in spring training games today. They scored a 5-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, a team that had just executed a rare play in baseball a nine-man trade with Charlie Finley that was not blocked by Bowie Kuhn.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 17 The head hunters are here, working in much the same way their opposite numbers operate at a convention of university professors. In this case the targets are touring golf professionals, and the head hunters are promoters, sponsors and representatives of tournaments who are recruiting players for their events, working hardest on the big-name players such as Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Lee Treviso.

WASHINGTON, March 17 Panama's negotiating team flew secretly to Washington last weekend for a daylong discussion with the United States delegation of issues to be resolved for a new Panama Canal treaty.
WASHINGTON, March 17 Employment quotas can and do work in reversing patterns of job discrimination, Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 The Senate Finance Committee today in effect approved President Carter's $50 tax rebate, the cornerstone of his economic stimulus program this year, by narrowly rejecting two Republican amendments offering permanent tax cuts instead.

Four city employees, on loan to Deputy Mayor Stanley M. Friedman, Mayor Beame's chief political adviser, opened an office at 51 Chambers Street three weeks ago to "improve the Mayor's scheduling and coordinate city agencies."
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) Soybean futures prices bounced around like a rubber ball on the Chicago Board of Trade today, advancing 23 cents, then closing mostly lower under late profit taking.

BONN, March 17 A West German sprinter says that "90 percent of the members of the West German national track and field team are on pills and shots," and acknowledges that he has been taking steroids for years.

Glenn Hagan is the unheralded member of the St. Bonaventure basketball team. The primary job of the 6-foot junior backcourt man is to set up Essie Hellis and Greg Sanders, his high scoring forwards, and to dribble, make steals and stay out of the limelight.

OF THE VARIOUS Chinese regional cuisines that have become popular here during the last 10 or 15 years, that of Hunan is perhaps the most subtle and intriguing. Set halfway between Szechwan and Canton, this province offers dishes reminiscent of both the chili fired specialties every bit as hot as those of Szechwan, along with a complement of dishes as gently and soothingly seasoned as those of Canton.

Franklin M. Jarman, who was ousted as chief executive officer of Genesco Inc., the country's largest maker and retailer of apparel, but allowed to remain chairman, will resign by Aug. 1. However, he will be paid $431,667 in 28 monthly installments after that date. He will also receive a paid club membership in New York and use of a 1977 Continental automobile.

WASHINGTON, March 17 Sol M. Linowitz has resigned as a director of the Marine Midland Bank of New York to avoid "even the slightest suggestion of a conflict of interest" in connection with his role as a negotiator for a new Panama Canal treaty, the State Department said today.

By 1985, a thin margin is expected to exist between the industrialized world's thirst for imported oil and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' desire to quench it, according to the latest study on future world supplies.

LAS CRUCES, N.M., March 17 The Lost Dutchman Mine is much more famous and the fabled Seven Cities of Cibola is richer by far. But any day now, barring bad weather or judicial intervention, the "treasure" of Victorio Peak may surpass them both as the stuff of which lush and fevered fantasies are spun. Then again, it may not.

DETROIT, March 17 Action by Congress and the Carter Administration to stop importing Rhodesian chrome will not cause any immediate problems for the auto industry," according to spokesmen for the major auto manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, March 17 State Department officials said today that the North Korean's remarks were an interesting development but were part of mixed signals emanating from Pyongyang.
PHOENIX, March 17 The hottest property in Phoenix these days is an outof-town newspaper.

CHICAGO, March 17 William J. Fulton, a reporter for The Chicago Tribune for more than 40 years and its correspondent at the United Nations from 1949 until his retirement five years ago, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital, Sarasota, Fla. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) The House Government Operations Committee today approved President Carter's requested Government reorganization authority by vote of 39 to 3, clearing the way for final Congressional action by next week.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 17 (AP) Butch Lee hit a driving layup with less than a minute to play to give Marquette a 67-66 victory tonight over Kansas State in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest regional semifinals. Marquette will play Wake Forest, which beat Southern Illinois, 86-81, in the second game. The Warriors were behind by 8 at the half and dropped behind by 10 several times during the second half.
CHICAGO, March 17 Richard J. Daley, who died last December, dominated the 26th annual St. Patrick's Day, parade today just as he did in the 21 years that he was Mayor.
An angry Mayor Beame yesterday directed the city to take four major sports powers to court to prevent the Jets from playing the first two home games of their season in New Jersey.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 16 Chances are no one will ever know who won Pakistan's elections last week, but there is no doubt that democracy lost.

WASHINGTON, March 17 In what could be a precedent for wider representation of consumers in regulatory proceedings, the Federal Energy Administration agreed today to pay for intervention by Consumers Union in cases involving costs and prices of three major oil refining companies.

VIENNA, March 17 The Czechoslovak Government has returned the unused writing paper and envelopes that policemen seized from Paul Hofmann of The New York Times when he reached a border station Feb. 12 on his way out of the country, but it kept notebooks and other documents.

William A. Baxter, executive vice president of Frank B. Hall Company, an international insurance brokerage concern, resigned Wednesday following a company investigation that uncovered some $400,00 worth of expanses authorized by Mr. Baxter and others "which were incorrectly recorded" on a subsidiary's books, the company announced yesterday.

The Hare Krishna movement was called a "bona fide religion' yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Queens who threw out two indictments against officials of the movement. The indictments had charged them with illegal imprisonment of two members and attempted extortion from the father of one of the believers.
WASHINGTON, March 17 President Carter, in a letter to members of Congress, has attempted to assuage resentment generated by his suspension of funds for 19 water resource projects in his 1978 budget.

Mary Lucy McGrath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. McGrath of New York, was married yesterday to Teddy F. Walkowicz, chairman and chief executive officer of the National Aviation and Technology Corporation. Only members of the immediate families attended the civil ceremony, which was at the McGrath home.
Dr. Chih Chiang Teng, an ophthalmologist, died Monday at University Hospital. He was 72 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

MIAMI, March 17 (AP) A vice president of the Southeast First National Bank of Miami, the largest bank in Florida, has been suspended as bank and Federal officials continued an investigation into the disappearance of $1.1 million, a spokesman said today.

Tonight, New York scored an impressive 115-107 National Basketball Association victory over the Denver Nuggets in McNichols Sports Arena.

COLLECTORS of musical instruments and memorabilia are finding lately that the pace is quickening. The first specialty musical instrument auctions two in fact were held here last fall, and the sale at Sotheby Parke Bernet resulted in two world records. A Ruckers double virginal fetched $65,000, the highest price paid at public sale for a keyboard instrument. And the events set the record for total sales of this kind $515,160.

IN JOHN VON HARTZ's new comedy revue, "A Little Wine With Lunch" (at the No Smoking Playhouse), lunch is a time for a con frontation and revelation. Eating can be incidental, although the wine never stops flowing. If there is a lesson to be learned from this delectable, vintage entertainment, it is in vino veritas and laughter.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) Record growth in the aggregate size of Americans' paychecks last month helped pull personal income out of its weather-induced stagnation, the Government reported today.

Ronald Timmons, a 19-year-old Bronx youth who was the cause of a public outcry over the treatment of youthful offenders when he jumped a low bail of $500 that was set despite his long juvenile record, pleaded guilty yesterday to robbing and beating an 82-year-old woman in her Bronx apartment.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 17 Kamal Jumblat, the slain leftist and Druse leader, was buried today in his home village southeast of here in the presence of tens of thousands of mourners. There were increasing reports of revenge killings, and his followers brought the Moslem half of Beirut to a halt with a general strike.

BUCHAREST, Rumania Energy experts here say the severt March 4 earthquake apparently has not affected this nation's oilfields, but there has been an official admission that they are approaching depletion.

CLINTON, Mass., March 17 Everyone on the street here today was wearing a touch of green, from a carnation to a complete outfit, and by early after noon the three bartenders on duty at the Old Timer Bar were moving fast to keep up with the growing throng of St. Patrick's Day celebrants. This heavily Irish New England mill town was settling back to normal after a visit by the President of the United States.

ALBANY, March 17 Governor Carey today rejected the recommendation of a fact-finding panel that all of the state's Civil Service employees be given an immediate 5 percent pay raise. The matter now seems certain to go the Legislature for a final decision.

Kresge Company, has taken exception to a vote of the company's directors approving a change in the company name of K Mart Corporation. WASHINGTON, March 17 The Federal Power Commission ordered Texaco today to show cause why it should not be prohibited from delivering natural gas to its Port Arthur, Tex. refinery from Federal fields offshore Louisiana.

The nation's money supply rose $1.5 billion during the week ended March 9, reversing in part the declines of the previous two weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported Yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 The Federal Bureau of Investigation, besieged by thousands of citizens who want to know what the bureau has in its files about them, will summon 400 agents here this summer in an effort to eliminate a backlog of Freedom of Information requests.

Walter M. Perry, a retired executive of Johns Manville, died Monday at his Darien, Conn. home. He was 71 years old. A graduate of Cornell University, he joined the company in 1936 and retired in 1970 as production manager in the international department.

WHAT IS Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" about? Love adrift, finally drowned in a sea of tragedy? Yes, in part. Yet it is also a study of Renaissance society, its hierarchy, its rigidity, its aspirations, its perils. At one level Romeo and Juliet are swept up in a personal tragedy, but at another it is a social tragedy. It is also an Italian tragedy. Full of sun and menace, of grandeur and passion.

WASHINGTON, March 17 Special agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service arrested two men today in connection with the shooting death of a rare and protected bald eagle on Long Island last December.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 17 With their latest skirmish already engraved in the lore of their intense rivalry, the New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox both chartered buses out of here this morning, the Yankees heading for Vero Beach and the Red Sox for West Palm Beach.

CAIRO, March 17 Yasir Arafat and other Palestinian leaders attending the Palestine National Council voiced welcome today for President Carter's statement on the need for a Palestinian homeland. WOODBURY, L.I. For 50 years Anna C. Schreiber worked as a saleswoman in a Manhattan department store. She retired on a pension of $48.50 a month and Social Security. She soon realized that inflation had eaten up the value of her only income. So, Miss Schreiber, who was an elder in the United Presbyterian Church, sought refuge in a church-sponsored home. She entered it two years ago thanks to Medicaid.

LONDON, March 17 (AP) The price of gold hit $149.25 an ounce in London today, repeating the 18-month peak it reached last week, then eased a bit at the close. The dollar dipped against most European currencies.

UNITED NATIONS N.Y., March 17 President Carter shook hands with a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization during a reception tonight following his speech in the General Assembly hall here. However, he later said he had no intention of following up with further contacts until the P.L.O. gave up its platform dedicated to the destruction of Israel.

Ben Jonson's "The Alchemist" will be performed by the Meat and Potatoes Company tonight, tomorrow and Sunday evening at 8 P.M. at 58 West 39th Street. Tickets are $2.50.

President Carter has now learned, if he did not already know it, that the most thankless action a President can take is to challenge the pork-barrel traditions of Congress. In a daring move last month, Mr. Carter picked out 19 Federal water projects, already approved, for review and reconsideration, and indicated that their funding would be dropped from the 1978 budget if they were found economically wasteful, environmentally harmful, or both.

WASHINGTON, March 17 The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, made a strong plea today for a stringent code of ethics to restore the public's confidence in the Senate as efforts were made to defeat a proposed limitation on income and honorariums.
NEW DELHI, March 18 (AP) Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi accused her political enemies and the press today of trying to foment "chaos and anarchy." The opposition accused her of "seeing phantoms."
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 17 (AP) The police here made two easy arrests when an angry bar patron chased two suspected robbers into the arms of a group of patrolmen.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) The nation's black newspaper publishers were urged tonight to help forge a new economic and political force.

KINSHASA, March 17 At this distance from the invaded area, with no telephone connections to a region 1,500 miles away, it is difficult to discern fact from the host of rumors circulating here. But according to Western diplomats who themselves have had no chance at firsthand observation, the invasion began on March 8.

THOSE WHO VIEW Sunday morning as the time to lounge at home in bathrobes with endless pots of coffee would have a hard time imagining Manhattan's stylish brunch scene, never livelier than during the spring.
The notion that things were looking very much like spring was dashed yesterday by an abrupt replay of winter.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 18 (AP) The military Government has disclosed details of a new foreign-investment law designed to speed the flow of capital into Chile's ailing economy.

The inflation rate in the last year has been slower for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area than for any of the 12 other major metropolitan areas in the country, according to Consumer Price Index figures compiled by the Bureau of Labor statistics.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) For the first time since 1950, Americans are free to travel anywhere in the world without restrictions on the use of their passports.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 18 (UPI) Al Bramlet, the slain culinary workers union leader, probably was the victim of men to whom he owed a personal debt and not the target of a professional "hit" man, District Attorney George Holt said today.
The storm yesterday that deposited as much as 12 inches of snow in New England and upper New York resorts has given many ski areas in the north country a well-needed booster shot.

In an unusually blunt assessment of city labor practices, an advisory panel chosen by Mayor Beame called yesterday for an end to "unqualified" political appointees in city government and for the adoption of sweeping collective-bargaining revisions to strengthen the hand of management.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 18 The Government handed over 12 black steel caskets containing the remains of American pilots killed in the Vietnam War to President Carter's special commission today. A commission member said that some American deserters may be living voluntarily in Vietnam.

Beethoven's "Grosse Fuge," the contrapuntal edifice that he originally intended as the finale of his String Quartet in B flat (Op. 130), was replaced by him with a more tractable movement and published as a separate work. Some groups nowadays reinstate the great fugue to its place at the end of Op. 130, but because of its length and extraordinary difficulty, most players are glad to pass it by.
The commodity spot-market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 218.7 from 217.3 last week.
Norris Industries Inc. of Los Angeles said yesterday that it would make an offer to merge McIntosh Corporation of Chicago into Norris in an exchange of stock valued at $47 million.

Donald G. Emery, an educator and assistant superintendent of the Board of Cooperative Educational Service for Southern Westchester County, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 58 years old and a resident of the Town of Greenburgh.

KINSHASA, Zaire, March 18 Zairian troop reinforcements are being flown to Shaba Province in an attempt to halt the advance of invading forces from neighboring Angola before they reach the important copper-mining city of Kolwezi.
The Houston Cougars gave Coach Guy Lewis his 400th career basketball victory by beating nationally ranked Alabama, 82-76, Thursday night.

The Long Island Rail Road began an investigation yesterday into the breakdown that disrupted virtually all of its rush-hour service Thursday night, delaying 76,000 riders two to three hours and leaving nearly 15,000 people trapped in tunnels under the East River for two hours or more.

In an unusually blunt assessment of city labor practices, an advisory panel chosen by Mayor Beame called yesterday for an end to "unqualified" political appointees in city government and for the adoption of sweeping collective-bargaining revisions to strengthen the hand of management.

Miriam Ehrenreich Hertz,a former president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, died of a heart attack Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at 1035 Fifth Avenue.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 18 (Reuters) More than 20 persons were wounded here today when the police fired shotguns during riots over the arrest of four opposition leaders, reliable sources said.
In the harsh soil of contemporary language blooms the verbiferous thesaurus, giving color to thought, fragrance to expression, shade to meaning and poetic license to copywriters.

It is not uncommon for Presidential flight arrangements to discommode airport traffic. But the snarl at the Kanawha County Airport in Charleston, W. Va., Thursday was worse than anyone had bargained for.

MEXICO CITY, March 18 Mexico's state oil monopoly, Pemex, said today that the country's total oil reserves greatly exceed a recent unofficial estimate of 60 billion barrels. It added that proven reserves stand at 11.1 billion barrels.

Marcia Lannon Dawkins, deputy commissioner and director of Consular Corps Affairs at the New York City Commission for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps, was married at noon yesterday to Baron CarlHenric Nauckhoff, Consul General of Sweden in New York. The Rev. Dr. Stuart Grayson, associate minister of the First Church of Religious Science, performed the ceremony at the Swedish Consul General's residence.

MAJORCA, Spain, Saturday, March 19 William L. Laurence, a science reporter who was the only journalist to witness the historic nuclear blast at Alamogordo, N.M., in 1945 and later the only newspaperman permitted to fly on the atomicbomb mission over Nagasaki, Japan, died here today of complications from a blood clot in the brain. He was 89 years old.

NEWARK, March 18 Dr. Fred G. Burke, the New Jersey Commissioner of Education, met with Newark school authorities today to discuss new plans for dealing with what he called the city's "educational crisis."

The Long Island Rail Road began an investigation yesterday into the break- down that disrupted virtually all of its rush-hour service Thursday night, delaying 76,000 riders two to three hours and leaving nearly 15,000 people trapped in tunnels under the East River for two hours or more.

The White House has taken measure of the extent and nature of President Carter's campaign promises and, in releasing a 111-page compilation to the news media last month, shared them with the public. The document, prepared by the transition staff before the inauguration, is excerpted here. The public can obtain the document by writing to the White House.

Stefan Wolpe's "Passacaglia" for piano (1936) was the highlight of a stimulating concert Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall by Parnassus, an ensemble of young contemporary music specialists now in its third season.
UNIONDALE, L.I., March 18 Not that anyone was counting, but the New York Nets were mathematically eliminated from the National Basketball Association playoffs tonight.
The occupation at WBAI-FM by the radio station's staff and some listener supporters ended yesterday as five persons who refused to comply with a court order to leave were arrested.

WASHINGTON March 18 Joan Buckler Claybrook, an experienced advocate of consumer causes and Ralph Nader's chief lobbyist here, was formally nominated today by President Carter to head the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that it had been his decision to authorize the temporary release of the Hanafi Moslem leader responsible for taking 134 hostages in Washington last week. One person was killed in the siege and another was seriously wounded.

Walter H. Van Hoesen, who started out as a writer and later turned to freight forwarding, died Thursday at the Ashbrook Nursing Home in Scotch Plains, N.J., at the age of 79. He was a resident of Fanwood, N.J.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 10 The tape-recorded sounds footsteps, the scraping of metal on metal, squeaking door, heavy breathing, drawers being opened were reminiscent of an oldtime radio mystery program.
Janet Sidenburg Limburg, an active sportswoman involved in many community organizations, died Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. She was 66 years old.

Whether people are complaining about redlining or engaging in greenlining, lots of attention is being focused on the urban investment policies of New York banks. Redlining is the practice of refusing home improvement loans or mortgages in certain neighborhoods. Greenlining is the name that some protesters give to their efforts to increase the availability of home loans in Brooklyn.

James A. Cavanagh, gone these 15 months from the vox pop bedlam of City Hall, was attempting to say no comment on the subject of fiscal gimmickry and the city's most recent billion-dollar escape from bankruptcy when he slipped, then plummeted into a seizure of laughter.

Several major copper companies announced yesterday the second price increase for the metal this month. The conflict in Zaire, a major African copper producer, and coming labor negotiations in the domestic industry spurred the rise.

UTICA, N.Y., March 18 Sheriff William Hasenauer of Oneida County suspended five members of his department today pending an investigation into their roles in the "detainment" of County Executive William Bryant early yesterday morning.
PARIS, March 18 Diet haute cuisine, once considered chemically unlikely and morally reprehensible among French gourmets, has finally attained the summit of gastronomic recognition.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 18 Don King, the boxing promoter, announced today that Havana was being sought as the site of Muhammad Ali's next world heavyweight title defense sometime in May against Alfio Rhighetti of Italy.

WEST BERLIN In the cold war, this city of two million people was a brave symbol of Western freedom and prosperity 110 miles inside Communist East Germany. Today, in the anguish of urban decline, some Berliners are wondering whether their city has become a casualty of detente.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) A judge ordered two jailed Hanafi Moslems bound over for grand jury investigation today after testimony that each held hostages at machete point in last week's siege and one slashed a man severely.

KINSHASA, Zaire, March 18 Zairian troop reinforcements are being flown to Shaba Province in an attempt to halt the advance of invading forces from neighboring Angola before they reach the important copper-mining city of Kolwezi.

John J. Riccardo, board chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, received $700,066 in salary and bonuses last year, according to the company proxy statement mailed to shareholders yesterday to announce the annual meeting to be held May 3.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 18 (AP) Santa Barbara's Sandy Neilson, a triple gold-medal winner in the 1972 Olympics, set an American record in the 50yard freestyle today in the national women's swimming and diving championships at Brown University.

Silvia Sass, a Hungarian soprano who in a five-year career has sung with the Vienna State Opera and at Covent Garden in London as well as with the Budapest Opera, made her Metropolitan Opera debut on Thursday night in the title role of "Tosca."

WASHINGTON, March 18 (Reuter) Harold Brown, Secretary of Defense, said that today he might rule American bases off limits to union organizers if a serious attempt was made to sign up military personnel.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) Richard L. Dunham, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, denied today that he sought to penalize staff attorneys who gave testimony to Congress critical of i gas producers or who vocally advocated a public interest.
DANSVILLE, N.Y., March 18 (AP) Nineteen persons remained in critical, serious or guarded condition after a bus accident in Steuben County today that killed a 17-year-old Pennsylvania hockey player.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 18 Unlike Lou Gehrig and Reggie Jackson, Marty Perez doesn't think he's lucky to be a Yankee.
CAIRO, March 18 (UPI) Palestinian leaders rejected today any move to recognize Israel and also denied Yasir Arafat sweeping powers to negotiate a Middle East peace settlement.

Sounding a law-and-order theme that is certain to recur in his expected re-election campaign, Mayor Beame presided yesterday over the rehiring of 200 police officers and then sped off to Brooklyn for more speeches and handshaking that suggested his campaign might have already begun.

Lorne Munroe, the New York Philharmonic's principal cellist, was the soloist in its program on Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall, and his vehicle was the late Benjamin Britten's Symphony for Cello and Orchestra. Written in 1963, it is one of four works the composer created for his good friend Mstislav Rostropovich, the great Soviet cellist. With Britten as conductor, it was given its premiere in Moscow and the work was later recorded by them.

Sister Vincent Therese Tuohy, vicar of the Maria Regina Convent of the Sisters of St. Joseph in Brentwood, L.I., and the former president of St. Joseph's College, died Thursday in Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip, L.I. She was 64 years old.
LONDON, March 18 (Reuters) The Bank of England today took action to restrain the fall in short-term British interest rates and to reduce the flood of overseas funds into London.
UNIONDALE, L.I., March 18 Easthampton High School edged Roosevelt, 87-86, tonight at Nassau Coliseum in the semifinals of the Capital/Southern basketball tournament A division.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 18 President Carter's proposals for moves to strengthen respect for human rights has evoked favorable response from many diplomats, who said today that they had not expected such specific commitments.
CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) A woman known as the "welfare queen" was convicted last night of welfare fraud and perjury for using two aliases to collect 23 public aid checks worth $8,000.

BONN, March 18 Continuing revelations of extra-legal monitoring of conversations by Government agencies have shaken Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's ruling coalition and are raising questions about whether West Germany's secret services are subject to effective legal controls.

LONDON, March 18 The Conservative opposition to Britain's Labor Government forced Prime Minister James Callaghan into a test of strength today, raising the possibility of a general election at a time when the Tories would be considered heavy favorites.
STAMFORD, Conn The tape-recorded sounds footsteps, the scraping of metal on metal squeaking door, heavy breathing, drawers being opened were reminiscent of an old-time radio mystery program.

A Brooklyn school board said yesterday that it would not give its 21,000 pupils the March 29 citywide reading test, now being received in the schools, because its easy availability could result in cheating and other "serious abuses."

Russell Patterson, the illustrator, cartoonist and designer whose slick, sophisticated drawings created many of the fashions of the flapper and collegiate eras of the 1920's, died Thursday night at Atlantic City Hospital of heart failure. He was 82 years old.
The coal and copper sectors continued to forge ahead in the stock market yesterday, while some big-name glamour stocks gave ground.

WASHINGTON, March 18 President Carter promised today to "root out mismanagement and inefficiency" in United States foreign aid programs and to demand from recipients high standards in using the aid and in respecting basic human rights.
LONDON, March 17 (Reuters) British Leyland announced today a record $119.7 million profit for the last 15 months one day after a potentially crippling strike at the company ended.

PARIS Kamal Jumblat, the Lebanese leftist who was murdered by gunmen Wednesday, was both an original personality and a great gentleman. He belonged to a special breed in the Arabized Middle East, which included King Abdul Azziz ibn Saud, who created a country and a dynasty; the Emir Abdullah of Transjordan; Hassanein Pasha, a cultivated explorer who tried unsuccessfully to educate Egypt's last king, Farouk, and Mullah Mustapha Barzani, the brave Kurdish chief.

WASHINGTON, March 18 The Senate Finance Committee voted today for tax bill provisions that would mean lower taxes far 46 million Americans who use standard deductions, higher taxes for two million single persons who take standard deductions and make more than $13,750, and unchanged taxes for all who itemize deductions.

Spring begins tomorrow 43 minutes after midday, according to astronomers at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium. The event is known as the vernal equinox because of the popular belief that it is the time when day and night are of equal length.

WASHINGTON With a new communicatnig system, a utility can read a household meter without interrupting the power it is providing. American Science and Engineering Inc., Cambridge, Mass., received a patent for the method this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 Critics of the oil and gas industry have often accused the companies of crying wolf to keep unfavorable legislation from passing. For once, at least, the industry feels vindicated.

BALTIMORE, March 18 (AP) With no agreement reached in talks today between race track and union representatives, Bowie Race Course officials canceled tomorrow's racing card which included the $118,300 Campbell Handicap.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 18 The North Carolina team looks like a group of altar boys, all those bright young faces on a Tar Heel squad that plays with such intensity. These kids look young enough to ride for half fare on buses, clean enough to squeak after showering. Anyone with 5 o'clock shadow need not apply.
LOS ANGELES, March 18 "It's a cold-blooded way to enter a marriage," said Raoul L. Felder, a New York lawyer. "It's very calculating."

SAN DIEGO, March 18 (AP) More than 7,000 birds have been destroyed in an effort to contain Newcastle disease and save the poultry industry, but breeders warn that the program threatens to wipe out whole species of endangered birds.
ASPEN, Colo., March 18 The wife of a prominent Washingtonian anxiously telephoned an acquaintance in Colorado earlier this week.

ALBANY, March 18 The plan to revise next year's school calendar to include a five-week midwinter break is apparently dead for now. Emlyn I. Griffith of Rome, a state Regent and chief proponent of the plan, has written his fellow Regents suggesting that they postpone a decision on the five-week break until after it has been studied.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation put into motion its much-awaited new "exchange offer" yesterday an attempt to get owners of short-term city notes to swap them for M.A.C. bonds and watched as prices for its bonds tumbled on Wall Street.

WASHINGTON March 18 Increased supplies of water are flowing in streams in the West and Middle West, the United States Geological Survey said today, but it warned that the improvement was temporary and drought conditions "remain serious in many areas."

Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, breathed new life into an old controversy when he said that "the First Amendment has got to be clarified by the Supreme Court in the light of the power of the mass media."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 The New York Mets headed tonight for a fast weekend in the Dominican Republic after nudging the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-1, in 10 innings, for their sixth victory in eight spring-training starts.

Hannah Kahn is primarily interested in dance movement, while Dalienne Majors is most concerned with character studies, and together they presented a low-key but entertaining program at American Theater Laboratory on Thursday evening.

Kaalii Francis, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. George Edward Francis of London, was married here yesterday morning to Geoffrey O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph O'Brien of Red Hook, N.Y. The civil ceremony was performed at City Hall.
PARIS, March 18 Three years ago, the stars stopped shining on L'Escargot Montorgueil. Now, the black rooster has vanished from beside its name.
WASHINGTON, March 18 Consumer prices surged 1 percent in February, the biggest advance in nearly two and a half years, the Labor Department reported today.
LONDON, March 18, (Reuters) The price of gold rose above $150 an ounce on the world's main bullion markets in London and Zurich today for the first time since September, 1975.
LONG BEACH, Calif., March 18 Ted Turner of the Atlanta Yacht Club was favored today to become the first skipper from outside California to win the Congressional Cup.

WASHINGTON March 18(AP) The Carter Administration today supported the busing of school children between Wilmington, Del., and its suburbs as part of a desegregation plan, but it said that the schools did not need to refect the racial makeup of the city.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 18 The ranks of the pro golf tour have dozens of morning glories who occasionally sneak out of the field and lead one round of a tournament, generally the first. Then they vanish, not to be heard from again for another year or two. Sometimes they manage to hang on for a second day.

CHICAGO, March 18 (UPI) A Federal official said today that no evidence contradicted the Chicago Transit Authority's preliminary finding that "human error" caused an elevated train crash in which 11 persons were killed and nearly 200 were injured.
Herman D. Hillman, a retired Federal housing executive, died Thursday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 65 years old and a resident of Rockville Centre, L.I.

A 21-year-old man, said to be retarded, was taken into custody at his Manhattan home early yesterday and charged with fatally stabbing another retarded 20-yearold man in a West Side subway corridor, the Transit Authority police said.

CHICAGO, March 18 (UPI) A group of homeowners filed a suit in Federal court today, charging a real estate cooperative and seven other concerns with racial discrimination in the sale of houses in the tense Marquette Park area. The lawsuit, filed by both black and white homeowners, was the second by the Leadership Council for Metropolitan Open Communities.

When a rock-and-roller who has put in a lengthy regional apprenticeship finally achieves national recognition, there is usually cause for rejoicing. Local rock scenes can be limiting, for there is always pressure to copy the work of established groups. But there is also a maturity that comes from nightly interplay with audiences that really cannot be acquired any other way.
HOUSTON, March 18 (AP) Jennie Bell Morrow Decker, a granddaughter of Texas revolutton hero Sam Houston, died yesterday at the age of 106.

PASADENA, Calif., March 18 The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon, opening 10 days of tournament play that will see almost all the best players in North America in action.

WASHINGTON, March 18 New York and New Jersey transportation officials looked forward today to major benefits from the proposed stretch-out of the existing Federal mass-transit assistance program through 1982 involving $5.7 billion in new funds.

When Johnny Carson and his "Tonight Show" failed to appear on the home screen of television viewers Thursday night, the National Broadcasting Company got 3,800 telephone calls asking why. Of these inquiries all emanating from New York City, 3,000 were made between 11:30 P.M. and midnight.

NORMAN, Okla., March 18 (AP) Nick Gallo of Hofstra University advanced to the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling tournament tonight, while Iowa State took a slim lead in the team race.

The series of programs based on Alec Wilder's book "American Popular Song," which has been running at Michael's Pub since the beginning of last month, is winding up with some high notes and some low notes. SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 The United States Customs Service here said today that it had broken up a major ring that had been smuggling pre-Columbian artifacts into this country from 10 Central and South American nations in the last four years.

LOS ANGELES, March 18 For six months before Howard R. Hughes died last April 5, his top-level employees had urged him to revise a will they thought he had signed that named Noah Dietrich as trustee of the Hughes estate. Mr. Dietrich, a longtime Hughes aide, had fallen out with the reclusive industrialist and had come to be regarded as a Hughes enemy.

Laurence, a science reporter who was the only journalist to witness the historic nuclear blast at Alamogordo, N.M., in 1945 and later the only newspaperman permitted to fly on the atomicbomb mission over Nagasaki, Japan, died here today of complications from a blood clot in the brain. LANDOVER, Md., March 18 (AP) Roger Crozier, appearing in his second game for Washington, played two brilliant periods as the Capitals rolled to a 5-0 National Hockey League victory over the Colorado Rockies tonight.

Kenneth S. Axelson, who last week withdrew his name from nomination as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Department, was cleared yesterday by the J.C. Penney Company to return to its top executive ranks.

Unfortunately, no drug is completely "safe." For example, there is a medication that, when administered in low doses, may cause indigestion and bleeding disorders, and, in higher doses, may result in marked alterations in blood chemistry, stupor, seizures and, on occasion, death. One would hardly expect a medication with such inherent toxicity to be approved for use by laboratory mice, let alone humans.

EAST BERLIN. The beige Mercedes sedan slid out of the night that obscured the Eastern sector of divided Berlin and nosed through the floodlit Invalidenstrasse border checkpoint past the tank barriers, the barbed wire, the red-and-white striped customs poles, stopping at length before the guard post at the exit to the Western sector. An East German police guard checked the East German license plate -IU 27 73 and peered inside the car.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) The Supreme Court gave the go-ahead today to a consumer-information program tire manufacturers say will cost $150 million a year. The Justices let stand the decisions of lower Federal courts that a tirequality grading system planned by the Department of Transportation is valid.

NORWALK, Conn., March 21 Teachers at Connecticut's four state technical colleges struck this morning and set up picket lines in Norwalk, Hartford, Norwich and Waterbury. The State Attorney General's office promptly moved in court to outlaw the walkout.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) The Senate Agriculture Committee voted 14 to 2 today to approve President Carter's nomination of a consumer activist, Carol Foreman, as an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Food and Consumer services.

Coaches of six of the country's leading college basketball programs spent last Sunday in a building on Astoria Boulevard in Queens, far from the sites of the National Collegiate tournament. Their mission? To recruit the player who might put them in the tournament next year Wayne McKoy.

WASHINGTON, March 21 The Supreme Court unanimously upheld today the constitutionality of a former section of the Social Security Act under which millions of retired men are treated less favorably than women in determining their old age insurance benefits.

Explosions like the two in New York City Sunday night always prompt a flurry of bomb scares, so there was nothing unusual when someone called The Daily News yesterday afternoon and said another bomb would go off at the American Bank Note Company plant in the Bronx, where one device exploded Sunday night.

Henry Hardwick Faxon, a Massachusetts surgeon and professor, died yesterday after a long illness in a Waltham, Mass., nursing home. Dr. Faxon, who was a resident of Brookline, Mass., was 78 years old.

The Aluminum Company of America, the world's largest aluminum producer, announced yesterday price increases averaging 5.8 percent on its ingot products, effective Friday. The company said that its unalloyed primary aluminum ingot would go up by 3 cents to 51 cents a pound.

MOSCOW, March 21 Leonid I. Brezhnev accused the United States today of using the issue of human rights to interfere in Soviet internal affairs, and he said it was "unthinkable" that Soviet-United States relations could develop normally on such a basis.

A court order to increase the number of blacks and Puerto Ricans in two construction unions in New York City was overturned yesterday by a Federal appeals court that warned against "overzealous enforcement" of a civil-rights law.

When the news of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's defeat and the losses of her ruling Congress Party reached him yesterday, Prof. Anand Mohan, like a great many Indians living in the United States, reacted with disbelief.

ALBANY, March 21 Governor Carey conceded publicly today that a major portion of his plan to cut aid to local schools had no chance of passage by the Legislature and he indicated that new sources of revenue might be tapped to balance the new state budget, which must be ready for adoption next week.

Westchester County District Attorney's office today refused to prosecute two truck drivers arrested for having radardetection devices in their vehicles, contending that the statute used by the state police in such cases was inadequate.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21 African diplomats used the opening of a Security Council debate on South Africa today to give a warm welcome to Andrew Young, the United States delegate, and to hail the emerging evidence of what they view as a more agreeable policy under the Carter Administration.

HONOLULU, March 21 Mayor Frank F. Fasi of Honolulu was indicted today by the Oahu grand jury on two bribery counts in connection with payments allegedly made for his help in a $50 milliun condominium project.

The 51,500 shares of the Fruehauf Corporation that traded on the New York Stock Exchange between March 8 and March 11 were sold ex-dividend by mistake, the exchange confirmed yesterday. Stock is normally sold ex-dividend a few days preceding the record date, the date by which stockholders must own their shares in order to receive the dividend. During those days, the stock price is reduced to reflect the amount of the dividend.

The National Hockey League's regular-season schedule, a marathon of 80 games for each team, is in its final two weeks, but the racers are still hurrying in a pack toward the finish.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) New orders for factory goods failed to recover in February from the weather-induced January slowdown, and were unchanged for the month, the Commerce Department reported today.

TORONTO, March 21 (AP) A gunman who took over a downtown bank and said that he wanted to be flown to his "pal," President Idi Amin of Uganda, surrendered his last hostages and gave himself up late tonight after holding the police at bay for almost 12 hours.
LONDON, March 21 (AP) The price of gold closed in London today at $152.10 an ounce, its highest level in more than 18 months. The dollar showed a mixed performance in Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 21 Franklin Woodruff, a former Cape May, N.J., housing commissioner and retired industrial specialist for the United States Maritime Commission here, died yesterday in Burdette Tomlin Hospital in Cape May. He was 81 years old.

Two Consolidated Edison employees who allegedly were paid $48,000 in the last four years for turning back the meters on 10 Bronx supermarkets costing the utility about $450,000 were arrested yesterday and charged with grand larceny.

ATLANTA, March 21 (AP) Francis P. Whitehair, a power in Florida politics and a former Under Secretary of the Navy, died yesterday at Emory University Medical Center in Atlanta. He had recently undergone lung surgery. The hospital said he died of heart failure. He was 76 years old.

President Carter's attempts to be just one of the folks led to a curious moment in that town meeting in Clinton, Mass., the other night. At one point a woman got up to complain about the high cost of living, and everybody focused on the President to hear what he proposed to do about it.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, March 21 (AP) President Fidel Castro of Cuba said today that "not a single Cuban" was involved in the invasion of southern Zaire on March 10 by forces identified as exiled Katangan secessionists.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 21 The state won a small commitment today from its principal natural gas supplier that could help it avert a repetition of the economic crippling it suffered for several weeks this past winter because of the unavailability of natural gas.

ARE, Sweden, March 21 (UPI) Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden won a World Cup giant slalom today with a combined two-run time of 2 minutes 46 seconds. He was more than two seconds ahead of Klaus Heidegger of Austria who was runner-up in 2:48:20.

WASHINGTON, March 21 The Carter Administration is considering asking Congress to raise the Federal gasoline tax by 5 or 6 cents a gallon to finance a multibillion-dollar research program to develop new sources of energy, Representative James C. Wright Jr. said today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 The three big companies that expect to produce crude oil at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska urged the Government today to allow them to realize the full market price for their oil to give them a maximum incentive to develop additional reserves and production.

BONN, March 21 While French voters were electing Socialists and Communists to city councils all over the country yesterday West German voters in Frankfurt and Wiesbaden elected conservative majorities to their city councils after decades of Socialist domination.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that the House Assassination Committee had scaled down its budget estimate forthe rest of this year from the original $6.5 million to $2.5 million.

WASHINGTON, March 21 Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda of Japan and President Carter had a mild disagreement about Washington's cherry blossoms when they met on the White House lawn this morning. Then they repaired inside where Mr. Fukuda vigorously defended Japan's export practices.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo, March 21 (UPI) An interim military Government eased security measures today but continued the search for the two surviving gunmen who on Friday killed President Marien Ngouabi, the French Embassy here said.
