JERUSALEM, March 21 Foreign Ministry analysts in Israel said today that the week-lang meeting in Cairo of the Palestine National Council that ended yesterday had resulted in some softening in the anti-Israeli language of the Palestinians, but they added that the meeting had done nothing to alter a basic commitment to the destruction of the state of Israel.

The Oratorio Society's performance of Bach's "St. John" Passion Sunday night in Carnegie Hall was dedicated to the memory of Benjamin Britten. This Passion made an appropriate choice, both because the work was a favorite of the late composer's and because the society had engaged his longtime colleague, Peter Pears to sing the Evangelist. The role is particularly associated with the tenor although he had never sung it before in New York.

In view of her considerable gifts, Juliana Markova's recital Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall was surprisingly unexciting. A native of Bulgaria with much European concert experience, she is a young pianist with an apparently growing American reputation; in fact, Miss Markova appeared under the auspices of nothing less than Lincoln Center's "Great Performers" series.
SENECA, Kan., March 21 (AP) Florence Mae Naismith, widow of Dr. James A. Naismith, inventor of basketball, died last Friday in a nursing home. She was 97 years old.

The 1977 Teacher of the Year is Myrra Leonore Lee of La Mesa,'Calif. Mrs. Lee, who teaches history, is scheduled to be honored today in a White House ceremony and to be introduced by President Carter. She was chosen for the honor from some 40,000 teachers in 47 states and the Virgin Islands in the annual awards program sponsored by the Council of Chief State School Officers, Encyclopedia Britannica and the Ladies' Home Journal.

WASHINGTON, March 21 The Senate Finance Committee approved today the tax elements of President Carter's economic stimulus program, including a $50 tax rebate for most Americans for 1976, a change in the standard deduction benefiting lower and middle-income persons, and business tax credits aimed at spur- ring more investment and the immediate creation of jobs.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 21 An old friend of Bobby Murcer from the New York Yankee days was predicting a successful new career for him with the Chicago Cubs, with whom he signed a five-year contract after having been traded by the San Francisco Giants for Bill Madlock, Murcer, he said, will get to play right field in daylight in warm summer weather and bat cleanup in a "hitters' park" at Wrigley Field.

Robert L. Stone, chairman, president and chief executive of the Hertz Corporation since 1972, is no longer in the driver's seat at the auto rental company. TRENTON, March 21 Persons convicted of using a gun or any other dangerous weapon in the commission of a serious crime will be required to serve a mandatory minimum prison term before being eligible for parole under the terms of a bill passed today by the Assembly and sent to Governor Byrne.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., March 21 (AP) An explosion set off by a welder's torch split a Panamanian oil tanker yesterday. killing the captain and nine crew members, survivors said. Twenty-seven crewmen were rescued today and 12 were missing. Search operations continued at the site, 120 miles southeast of here. The 10 dead were counted among the missing since no bodies had been found.

A court order to increase the number of blacks and Puerto Ricans in two construction unions in New York City was overturned yesterday by a Federal appeals court that warned against "overzealous enforcement" of a civil-rights law.

The stock market posted its fourth consecutive loss yesterday amid growing investor concern over inflation and possible higher interest rates.

Passover, the Jewish spring festival of deliverance, begins this year on April 3. NEW PALTZ, N.Y., March 24 There have been no angry campus confrontations and, unlike the student demonstrators of the 1960's, they have not seized their classrooms or laid siege to the school administrators.

Michtael F. Lauro, chief chemist for the New York Produce Exchange for 20 years until his retirement in 1965, died Wednesday in Hackensack (N.J.) General Hospital after a short illness. He lived at 44 Washington Place, Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and was 84 years old.

At 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, addicts of Paris, motion pictures or both will inaugurate what may be considered the ultimate tribute to Henri Langlois. They will sit down in the Junior Museum Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is fortunately fitted with adult seats, to view an eight-hour, nonstop assemblage by Mr. Langlois of film produced in Paris since the infancy of the industry in the 1890's.
The building materials industry found strong financial footing last year, according to a survey by the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company.

Following Mayor Beame's lead, the Board of Estimate last night abruptly reversed itself and rejected zoning regulations that would have banned so-called massage parlors, "adult" bookstores and movie theaters, and all other so-called "adult uses" from every borough except Manhattan.

TAMPA, Fla. March 24 Baseball's club owners set the stage today for the return of Washington to the big leagues but in the meantime refused to realign the 26 teams into six divisions and rejected the "gimmickry" of wider playoffs involving "wild card" teams as in football.

WASHINGTON, March 24 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has suggested changes that significantly weaken antiboycott legislation now before Congress, it was disclosed today, apparently taking a position at odds with the White House.
Out of a radiant mist on the television screen there strides a tall figure all dressed in white walking toward the camera from a distance. Who is he? A prophet? Seer? Cult leader?

CLEVELAND, March 24 (AP) Services will be conducted tomorrow morning in Cleveland Heights for James T. Flannery, northeast Ohio editor for Catholic Universe Bulletin, who died Tuesday at the age of 59.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) There is nothing in the election law to prohibit an Idaho Congressman from accepting cash contributions for his own personal use as long as he does not use them in his campaigns, the Federal Election Commission ruled today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun studying the use of a Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation logo on Christmas club deposit books issued by the insolvent American Bank and Trust Company.

The Garrett Corporation of Torrance, Calif., proposed yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority begin moves to equip 200 of its New York City subway cars with flywheel energy-recovery systems developed from those tested on two cars in New York last year.

In March 1974, Bryan F. Smith currently a director of Texas Instruments and formerly a senior vice president and chief financial officer, made a speech before the Harvard Club in Dallas about the role of corporate directors. It caused so much comment that the company's executives and directors labored over the points raised and brought forth a report on the resuits late that year.

WASHINGTON, March 24 President Carter said today that he would "respond well" on the question of possible American economic aid for Vietnam if the assistance was arranged as part of successful negotiations to open normal diplomatic relations.

MARYSVILLE, Calif., March 24 (UPI) State officials expressed alarm that hydrilla, a rapidly growing leafy aquatic weed that is the scourge of lakes and rivers in the southeastern United States, has a toehold in California.

Two 14-year-old boys were awarded $500 in damages each yesterday by a Federal judge in Brooklyn because they had been taken into custody by a suspicious police officer while they were taking a walk in East Hills, L.I., on the night of Sept. 5, 1975.

Rise Stevens's office is relatively small for that of a president, but fit is handsomely appointed and personalized by many photographs and souvenirs. The renowned Metropolitan Opera singer, who is now running the Mannes College of Music, apologized for the racket.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo, March 24 (UPI) The military junta here announced today that a special court-martial would try all peope held in the murders of President Marien Ngouabi and Emile Cardinal Biayenda.

RICHFIELD, Ohio, March 24 (AP) Pete Maravich scored 36 points and led a fourth-quarter surge as the New Orleans Jazz defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 92-87, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 24 Adm. Hyman G. Rickover appealed to Congress today to protect the nuclear fleet against efforts of the Carter Administration to eliminate nuclear ships from the budget in cost-cutting moves.

The first question is: Will Mitch Gordon ever locate his wife, Lindy, who has fallen overboard from their 40-foot ketch and is now treading water somewhere in the South Pacific about 70 miles from Tahiti? And the second:
SOME of the finest art that has been made in our lifetime can be seen in the Robert Rauschenberg retrospective which opens at the Museum of Modern Art today and continues through May 17.

Walter F. Mondale, making his first visit to New York City as Vice President, last night defended President Carter's criticism of human rights violations in the Soviet Union, saying that "to turn our backs on the struggle for human rights elsewhere on torture, on political imprisonment, on terrorism, on restrictions on the freedom to emigrate would be to turn our backs on ourselves."

The Cape Verdeans are one of Brooklyn's smallest ethnic minorities, but not too small to celebrate their roots in a special exhibition of photographs and paraphernalia relating to the Ernestina, a deep-water sailing ship that brought many of them to these shores from their windy archipelago 370 miles off the coast of West Africa.

The jury in the murder trial of Lewis 17X Dupree charged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan with the 1972 shooting death of a police office planned to go into its third day of deliberations today when a juror suddenly became ill last night and was rushed to Beekman Downtown Hospital.

President Carter's emphatic stance on the worldwide issue of human rights appears unlikely to set off a backlash harmful to American business abroad. So long as foreign buyers covet American goods, and the Carter policy remains largely talk, countermeasures are believed unlikely, a spot check of American business executives indicated yesterday.

NORMAN, Okla. One morning in the last week of February, residents of much of Oklahoma sound the cars in their driveways spatter-coated with ugly brown mud, the messy result of a heavy nighttime dust storm accompanied by a light rain.

The decoration of Eastern eggs, Ukrainian style, is the subject of workshops for adults all weekend at the Ukrainian Museum. 203 Second Avenue. The eggs are decorated batik-style with Layers of colored paper and beeswax manipulated by heated styluses, then coated with a thin glaze. Egg artists may gain inspiration from the museum's current exhibition of colorful, intricately designed Ukrainian eggs on loan from private collections.

Leone, who retained his titles of president and chief executive officer. Until yesterday, that is, when the company announced that William J. Conroy, executive vice president, had taken over the two top spots.

In an important initiative to uncover anticompetitive practices, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would investigate state boards of accountancy and the private state societies of certified public accountants.

("Fay-Iss") and N.Y.C.M.I.S. ("Nih-smiss"). The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it planned to begin offering a new class of membership next, called options principal memberships. Plans call for the sale of 200 of these seats to individuals who would become registered options traders.

AUGUSTA, Me., March 25 (AP) It's an old story: the telephone company asks for a rate increase and the public utilities commission acts. This time the customers are smiling and the company is not.
PARIS, March 25 Former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac was formally elected Mayor of Paris today by the City Council, filling an office revived after an interim of 105 years.

WASHINGTON, March 25 The Carter Administration took another step today in the direction of normal relations with Cuba by lifting the ban on the spending of dollars by United States visitors to that country.

NEW BRUNSWICK. N.J., March 25 Joanne D. Chesimard. a leading figure in the so-called Black Liberation Army. was found guilty today of first-degree murder in the death of a New Jersey state trooper and was immediately sentenced to life imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) Former President Gerald R. Ford, leaving open the possibility that he might seek office in 1980, said today that he planned an active role in politics and was optimistic about the Republican Party's future.

ST. PETERSBERG, Fla., March 25 Tom Seaver pitched five nearly perfect innings against the Boston Red Sox today and then, reflecting on the recent outbreak of rumors about his future, said he doubted that the New York Mets would trade him.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., March 25 The last-minute fund-raising effort by students and trustees of Briarcliff College to prevent or delay sale of the 75-year-old women's school to Pace University ended today well short of its goal.

The Dow Chemical company of Midland, Mich., said yesterday that it had reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company and partly owned foreign subsidiaries had made questionable payments totaling more than $3 million over a six-year period that began in 1971.

In its 12th copyrighted article on crime in Arizona, Investigative Reporters and Editors Inc. said that Ned Warren Sr., a former convict, was the mastermind of a multimillion-dollar land fraud industry in Arizona.

LAHORE, Pakistan, March 25 With two dozen opposition leaders arrested in the early hours today and security forces across Pakistan ordered to shoot anyone committing arson, looting, damaging property or trying to disrupt communications, the principal opposition figure still at liberty reaffirmed a call for a nationwide protest strike tomorrow.

UNIONDALE, L.I, March 25 Coach Jack Ramsay believes the fortunes of his Portland Trail Blazers depend on a healthy Bill Walton. It is hard to refute that theory after the way the 6-11 center performed tonight at the Nassau Coliseum as the Blazers defeated the New York Nets, 131-103, before 11,163 fans.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) After a year and a half of study, a special commission is proposing a law to establish that the papers that a President generates belong to the people of the United States and are not his personal property.

WASHINGTON, March 25 James R. Schlesinger told a group of citizens today that the Administration was opposed to the development of plutonium fuel systems for nuclear power reactors but would go along with the construction of additional conventional uranium reactors.
W.R. White, a Baptist minister and former chancellor of Baylor University in Waco, Tex, died Thursday at Hillcrest Hospital in Waco. He was 84 years old.

WASHINGTON Specialists at Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., have made an important improvement in magnetic bubble memories. They were granted a patent this week for an inexpensive method of moving the bubbles, which carry bits of information.

DETROIT, March 25 The annual reports issued by major American businesses are usually glowing accounts. The Ford Motor Company report issued today departs from that format-at least on one page headlined, "Not everything went right."

Floreida Bush and James J. Winston of New York and Amagansett, L.I., were married yesterday by Rabbi Howard Posner of Temple Emanu-El, in his study in New York. The bride is a daughter of Rose H. Bush of the Bronx.
BRAZZAVILLE, Congo, March 25 (AP) Former President Alphonse MassambaDebat was executed early today after being convicted of plotting the assassination of President Marien Ngouabi.

After World War II, playground directors in Europe noticed that some children had more fun playing in the rubble of burned-out buildings than they did using the elaborate equipment of conventional parks. So parcels of land were set aside from vacant lots to cultivated acreage and the children were given scrap materials with which to build their own spontaneous playgrounds.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 25 Catfish Hunter got six innings of work out of his ailing right shoulder today in his third outing of the spring and said he was satisfied with the results.

ALBANY I am an upstate Assemblyman faced with the possibility of having not one but as many as five nuclear-reactor plants built in my area. A substantial number of my constituents, although fortunately not a majority of them, are actually looking forward to this because it will mean more jobs.

DEXTER, N.Y., March 25 (UPI) Four mentally retarded persons died early today when fire destroyed a family-care home in this village near the Canadian border. One of the victims was an 18year-old woman who apparently became frightened and turned back from her rescuers.

Few public spectacles are more entertaining than Congress hitting the hallelujah trail. True, a writhing mass of Congressmen in the throes of uplift cannot match such superior media entertainments as the Gilmore execution circus or the siege of the enraged Hanafi, but for connoisseurs of the arts of flimflamming the rustics, a Congress in the heat of piety cannot be beat.

CLEVELAND, March 25 The National Collegiate swimming championships turned into a benefit tonight for the University of Southern California. The Trojans, assured of their fourth straight team title, won five of the six finals on this, the second night of the three-day meet at Cleveland State University.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) The "lost" asteroid Adonis has been rediscovered after 41 years, emerging from the darkness of space just in time for spring. Adonis, discovered in 1936, is one of 22 known asteroids that pass through the earth's orbit as they circle the sun.
The stock market extended its slump to seven straight sessions yesterday, bringing the leading averages to their lowest levels of the year.

WASHINGTON, March 25 Fifty-eight Senators today endorsed President Carter's stand on human rights, just hours before Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance left for Moscow for three days of talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev, probably including a debate on the issue of human rights.
The Long Island Press, bowing to rising costs and increasing competition, ceased publication yesterday in its 157th year.

A man with a pistol held four hostages for more than five hours in an office of the city's Housing and Development Administration in lower Manhattan last night before surrendering to members-of the Police Department's hostage-negotiating team.
The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday that it expected its firstquarter earnings would be 20 to 25 percent lower than last year's $1.65 a share.

An 84-year-old Brooklyn man who was severely beaten in an alleged robbery three weeks ago died yesterday, 13 days after his aged wife succumbed to injuries that the police said had been inflicted in another assault by the same assailant. Two boys are accused of the attacks.

She is the gracious woman by Stanley Steingut's side at legislatve receptions. She volunteers at the hospital. People comment frequently on her charm, her good humor, her intelligence.

An 18-year-old Queens youth has been indicted in the murder and rape of a Brooklyn woman who was eight months pregnant and whom he allegedly choked and forced into a furnace, asphyxiating her, District Attaorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan announced yesterday.
LONDON, March 25 (AP) The price of gold rose $1.25 in London today, closing at an 18-month high. The dollar had a mixed day in Europe in slow trading.

ALBANY, March 26 Agreement on a bill that would require the fingerprinting of juveniles arrested for serious felonies was reached this week by the chairmen of the State Senate Crime Committee and the Assembly Child Care Committee.

The Prague Chamber Orchestra returned to Town Hall on Friday night and once again demonstrated that 36 musicians can function as a superlative ensemble unit without the benefit of a conductor. At a time when most of New York City's institutions are cutting staff and reducing expenses, the New York Botanical Garden has started a new magazine for its members. Called Garden, the 40page bimonthly features articles about plants. It is printed on coated stock with two- and four-color illustrations.

But the homey, fabric-strewn shop it leans these days to a renovated family room in a suburban split is still intact, and the completed orders they run to tennis dresses and wrap-style jerseys still hang on a single rack.

IN CLEAR, logical and matter-offact testimony, a ranking oceanpollution expert from the United States Department of Commerce has told the combined Energy and Environment Committees of the State Legislature that natural forces at sea, and not ocean dumping, created the disastrous, 120-mile-long algae mass along the New Jersey coast last summer.

It may, in fact, be the key to our national temperament on the one hand, expansive optimism; on the other, biting dissatisfaction.

Anthony Hecht's first book of poetry, "A Summoning of Stones," was pub lished in 1954, his second, "The Hard Hours," in 1967. Thirty new poems make his third collection, "Millions of Strange Shadows."

PROPERLY INSTALLED, goodquality gutters and downspouts should last for many years with little or no maintenance, except for occasional cleaning. However, the past winter's heavy accumulations of snow and ice in this area, coupled with the fact that in many cases gutters tend to get clogged with leaves and other debris, make in advisable for the prudent homeowner to inspect his gutters as soon as possible to see if cleaning and/or repairing is necessary.

It happens every spring, that day when you step outside at noon, squint up at the hot sun, and consign your heavy coat and muffler to storage. Carlson, the new chief economist of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, portrays himself as a conservative with a difference, even as a man for all political seasons: "I've met a payroll and carried a few precincts." Thus he summarizes prior roles as a builder, investor and consultant plus a fling at elective politics.

It shows a bust of Lindbergh with a depiction of his plane, "The Spirit of St. Louis," in the background.

Democracy in India, so endangered by months of autocratic government under "emergency decrees" imposed by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, endures: She and her Congress Party have been decisively beaten in a general election. India's 600 million people will now be governed by Moraji R. Desai and the Janata Party, a coalition, its leaders like to say, born in the prison cells where Mrs. Gandhi's regime had consigned them.

NINA G. GARSOIAN, a distinguished scholar of ancient history at Columbia University, will soon shift most of her energies to the contemporary problems and challenges of being Dean of the Graduate School at Princeton University.

Inflation anxieties and the possibility of higher interest rates sent the stock market down sharply last week in slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 32.16 points during the week to finish at 928.86 on Friday. This decline was the largest since the week ended Dec. 5, 1975, when the Dow fell 41.87 points.

Once upon an innocence when our libidos merely had to be tickled instead of hustled, "The Pulps" reigned. The first of them appeared in 1896 when Frank Munsey, the publisher of Argosy, transformed his boy's magazine into an all-adult adventure fiction publication. Each issue consisted of 192 pages and roughly 135,000 words uninterrupted by illustrations. The breather in the hot-paced prose was the advertising.

LANDOVER, Md., March 27-Phil Jackson made a strong case today for his retention as a Knick next season. The 31-year-old bearded philosopher, whose contract ends this season, played a key role in a 109-95 victory over the Washington Bullets at Capital Centre. The Machinery Dealers National Association, which reports on used metalworking machines, said its monthly sales index hit a February record high of 173, a gain of 2 points over the February 1976 level. The index is based on average monthly sales in 1972 taken as 100.

SARAH KERNOCHAN'S novel "Dry Hustle" is an excursion through the back alleys of sex. A dry hustle is a form of con game that involves extracting money under promises of sexual favors. WASHINGTON, March 31 The Carter Administration has requested $6.2 billion for the nation's intelligence operations in the budget for the fiscal year 1978, according to sources close to the Senate Intelligence Committee.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 31 (AP) Andy Bean, who scored a start-tofinish victory three weeks ago in Miami, fought gusty winds for a fiveunder-par 67 and took a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the $235,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) Hamaas Abdul Khaalis, free since his Hanafi Moslem band held 134 hostages three weeks ago in a siege in which one person was killed, was jailed today after a judge was told that a police wiretap had recorded "blood-curdling threats" by Mr. Khaalis.

MAPUTO, Mozambique, March 31 (AP) The Soviet Union and Mozambique signed a treaty of friendship today. It was the first treaty signed by this East African state since it became independent of Portugal in 1975.

A cold front and gusty winds had sent temperatures drooping, but not nearly enough to suit the purists on hand at Forest Hills yesterday for the start of the $30,000 world platform tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, March 31 A team of Justice Department lawyers has recommended to Attorney General Griffin B. Bell that the department seek criminal indictments against at least six present and former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who authorized illegal break-ins by bureau agents in New York.
Mayor Beame announced yesterday that construction work had begun on 1.5 miles of street repairs, financed by Federal public-works funds, in the Flushing, Maspeth and Glendale sections of Queens.
NEW DELHI, March 31 Y.B. Chavan, the new leader of the defeated Congress Party in Parliament, appealed to the new Government today not to be vindictive.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Joe L. Allbritton, the millionaire Texas banker who three years ago bought and has so far saved the financially imperiled Washington Star, disclosed today that he had completed the Governmentordered divestiture of the newspaper company's television and radio properties by trading WMAL-TV here for KOCO-TV in Oklahoma City. Both stations are affiliated with ABC.

Sydney A. Weinberg, an inventor who specialized in developing techniques for the projection of X-ray motion pictures, died an Tuesday at his home in Brighton, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester. He was 67 years old.

Soybean futures prices soared yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, causing no surprise to traders. The rise resulted largely from the previous day's news that China had purchased some 14 million bushels of beans, with origin at the option of the grain companies handling the purchase. This means the beans might be obtained either in Brazil or the United States.

Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens charged yesterday that the City Planning Commission's antipornography zoning proposal was "narrow, ineffective and constitutionally vulnerable" and urged Mayor Beame's new task force on the subject to look at other ways of controlling pornography.

Mary Margaret Brazell and Peter Nelson Ives, members of the class of '77 at Radcliffe-Harvard, were married yesterday in the Memorial Church of Harvard University. The Rev. Peter Gomes performed the nondenominational ceremony.
BONN, April 1 (Reuters) Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said today he believed that the Palestinians must take part in any reconvened Geneva talks on the Middle East.
MILWAUKEE, April 1 The Knicks tonight added slightly to their slimmest of playoff hopes by beating the Milwaukee Bucks, 116-109.

Evan H. Turner, director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, resigned yesterday after 13 years in the post. The resignation was accepted with "deep regret" by William P. Wood, president of the museum's board.

Vance's trip to Moscow, and this miscalculation contributed to the Americans' reaction of surprise when no progress was achieved in ending the impasse on limiting strategic arms.

Tomorrow, Christians observe Palm Sunday, marking the start of Holy Week, which culminates on Easter Sunday. SMITH ISLAND, Md. When the herring come out of northern waters to loray in Chesapeake Bay, it's a sign that spring has arrived. The waterman's fancy turns to thoughts of the crustacean: In his own life cycle, he starts to molt from oysterman to crabber.

Only a small staff was on duty a guard checking doors, a phone operator off the main lobby, an administrator in a backoffice, several doctors attending patients and one or two nurses in most of the 13 wards. Perhaps 55 employees in all were scattered throughout the 10floor, multiwing institution.

The nations of the world have come together for the first time to face up to a growing crisis of water, one of the essentials of life. The event has been marked by the United Nations with a set of four commemoratives stressing the need for humanity to preserve its precious store of water now and for the generations to come.

Miss Diaz, a second year student at the Parsons School of Design in New York, is the winner of the school's J.C. Penney competition in clothing for boys, for which the talented 20-year-old has received a $300 check and the thrill of seeing her design translated into reality.

FRANKLIN PARK, Ill. Robert T. Bloomberg is accustomed to working for companies whose home offices are far away. He used to work in Los Angeles for a company whose head office was in Michigan. Now he works in this industrial suburb of Chicago for a company based in Osaka, Japan.

WESTCHESTER plays a big part in the world's biggest bridge competition, the Grand National Team Championship, which last year attracted some 6,000 teams in North America. In the current season 94 teams entered in Westchester, probably the biggest entry anywhere in relation to population.

It concerns the British relationship with the Indian Maharajahs during the decline of the Empire, and with it the Princely States, in the period from the death of Queen Victoria to Indian Independence in 1947.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 2 (AP) The Philadelphia Pioneers, led by Steve Riddick, an Olympic gold medalist, and Charles Foster, a world-class hurdler, set three meet records today in the 15th Colonial Relays at the College of William and Mary. Four other marks also fell.

THE rural back country of Greenwich, with its imposing estates and homes on minimum four-acre plots, is again shaping up as the focal point in a zoning fight. Four years after plans by the Xerox Corporation to put up a headquarters building on a 102-acre site in the residential area ran into decisive local opposition, town officials are preparing to deal with the implications posed by that opposition.

SARASOTA, Fla., April 2 Researchers reported here today that they were beginning to zero in on special characteristics of cancer cells that could be used to test for or predict the most effective approach to treatment.

TORONTO, April 2 (UPI) Margaret Trudeau, the wife of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada has been using a free pass provided by Air Canada for her trips to New York on photographic assignments for People magazine The Globe and Mail reported today.

Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Duke Jr. of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Deborah Digges Duke of New York, to Robert MacLean Davis Jr., son of Mrs. Davis of Fort Myers, Fla., and the late Mr. Davis.

FOR nine years Werner's Pork Store at 359 Willett Avenue in Port Chester (a village best known for Italian food prod ucts) has been like a knoedel afloat in marinara sauce. BIRMINGHAM, England, April 2 (AP) Politics intruded upon the world table tennis championships today as the powerful Chinese team withdrew its No. 5 player from a match against an Israeli, Shlomo Mendelson, who emigrated to Israel from the Soviet Union seven months ago. Mendelson was awarded the match by default.

Benjamin Appel, a novelist with more than 25 works of fiction to his credit, died yesterday at Princeton (N.J.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Roosevelt, N.J.
